webTitle: Freeserve set to stay in FTSE 100

fields.headline: Freeserve set for last-minute reprieve
fields.trailText: Freeserve, Britain's biggest internet service provider, could win a last-minute reprieve in the FTSE 100's latest clear-out.
fields.body:
Freeserve, Britain's biggest internet service provider, could win a last-minute reprieve in the FTSE 100's latest clear-out.

The company was expected to be kicked out of the London Stock Exchange's flagship index in tomorrow's quarterly listing review, but a flurry of activity in the European ISP market might yet save it from the chop. German rival T-Online, which tried to buy Freeserve in June, is tipped to return for another bid after buying Spanish portal Yacom for E550m (£337m) this week.

"It looks like Freeserve is going to stay in", said one analyst. "The change in management at T-Online, following the resignation of chairman Wolfgang Keuntje, has put its overseas expansion back on track. The Freeserve share price is entirely down to T-Online."

Freeserve, which is 80%-owned by high street retailer Dixons, has seen its share price slump from a March high of 921p to below 300p, leading to speculation that it might leave the FTSE 100. But the renewed speculation about a T-Online takeover pushed the shares up 11% to 315p this week, though they have since fallen back to 309.5p.

The FTSE equity indices committee will promote or relegate stocks after examining tonight's closing prices. The prime candidates for entry include internet security company Baltimore, a stockmarket yo-yo which left the index in June after investors rounded on technology stocks. Palm pilot maker Psion is also in with a chance for a return after its shares soared 22% to 893p this week.

Granada Media will get the biggest fanfare if it wins a seat at the top table only two months after its flotation. Shares in the company have climbed from 515p to 614p after the company bought rival United News & Media's ITV franchises for £1.75bn.

webTitle: Review: Wand/NDR Symphony Orchestra

fields.headline: Wand has power to enchant
fields.standfirst:
Wand/NDR Symphony Orchestra
Usher Hall, Edinburgh
*****
fields.trailText: Günter Wand's performances of Bruckner have long since achieved legendary status. As one of the last survivors of the great tradition of German conductors, Wand and his Hamburg-based NDR Symphony Orchestra have an unsurpassable authority in this most challenging of repertoires.
fields.body:
Günter Wand's performances of Bruckner have long since achieved legendary status. As one of the last survivors of the great tradition of German conductors, Wand and his Hamburg-based NDR Symphony Orchestra have an unsurpassable authority in this most challenging of repertoires.

Making his now customary visit to Edinburgh, Wand closed the international festival with Bruckner's Eighth Symphony.

Wand's approach to the composer has become familiar through his recordings and single-minded focus on Bruckner's symphonies in recent years. Yet nothing can prepare one for the experience of hearing Wand and the NDR orchestra live.

The sheer sound of the ensemble has an elemental power. Grounded in a double-bass section of awesome weight and presence, the orchestra rose in a seamless continuum to the heights of blazing trumpets and perfectly balanced woodwinds.

The completeness of this sonority matched the spiritual range of Wand's interpretation.

The first movement loomed from a chromatic abyss, with only the flowing second subject providing respite. The final climax in this movement was a deathly call to arms, as a trumpet intoned a brutal, dotted rhythm over ominous drumstrokes.

The scherzo introduced a human element to the work's drama, as Wand's supple phrasing caught a vestige of rustic charm.

But this was the apocalyptic merry-making of superhuman forces rather than a homely celebration. Even the trio, ostensibly a pastoral meditation, became a rapt hymn in Wand's vision.

The emotional heart of Wand's performance was the adagio, which transfigured the whole work. Wand was both contemplative and terrifyingly expressive. The movement unfolded as a series of ever-greater circles, as Wand allowed Bruckner's unique structure to flow with unforced grandeur.

If the eventual highpoint of the adagio was unbearable in its intensity, the coda of the finale, and the climax of the entire piece, was utterly devastating.

Bruckner combines themes from all four movements in this closing peroration, a metaphor for the transformation of the work's spiritual landscape. Wand's performance led inexorably to these shattering final minutes. It was as if the totality of the symphony's drama was contained in this single passage, and listening to the conclusion was both humbling and awe-inspiring.

This was as powerful a performance of a Bruckner symphony as it's possible to hear: an overwhelming, cataclysmic revelation.

webTitle: Business: Shop sales and house prices fall

fields.headline: Shop sales and house prices fall
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: City expectations that the Bank of England will leave borrowing costs on hold for the sixth month in a row when it announces its decision on interest rates on Thursday, are boosted today by figures showing a slowdown on the high streets and a sharp fall in house prices.
fields.body:
City expectations that the Bank of England will leave borrowing costs on hold for the sixth month in a row when it announces its decision on interest rates on Thursday, are boosted today by figures showing a slowdown on the high streets and a sharp fall in house prices.

Consumers are reining in their spending, according to figures released today by the British Retail Consortium. It said sales rose by 1.7% in the year to August, the slowest annual rate of increase since last November, apart from the March results which were distorted by the timing of Easter.

"While this month's figures may be a blip, a further month of weak results would suggest that growth rates have peaked at well below the performance of the previous high point in 1997," said Bridget Rosewell, the BRC's chief economic adviser. "The economy may well be slowing."

Retailers reported that they had difficulty attracting customers despite slashing prices. Only internet shopping sites and factory outlets reported a better than usual performance in August.

"Overall this was a disappointing month," said Bill Moyes. "Customers appeared to be thin on the ground, and those who were still shopping had to be tempted by promotions and the continuation of summer sales. Retailers will be hoping that customers return from the holidays ready to spend."

The Nationwide reported yesterday that house prices are falling at their fastest rate in two years. House prices fell by 0.6% in August, making the average home now worth £80,737, some £396 less than in July. This is the third fall in prices recorded by the society in the past four months.

Nationwide said that the current "pause" in house price growth could continue "for quite a few months," but added: "We think it will turn around."

The average rate of house price inflation has fallen again and now stands at 11.2% - in April it was 17.5%.

webTitle: Market forces: A small dose of insanity

fields.headline: Market forces: A small dose of insanity
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: A tale of two markets was how one City dealer summed up trading in the City yesterday.
fields.body:
A tale of two markets was how one City dealer summed up trading in the City yesterday.

With the top half of the London market pausing for breath after last week's strong performance, medium and small company shares took centre stage and pushed further into uncharted territory.

"The insanity of last winter has returned," proclaimed one dealer, as investors - retail and institutional - piled into the lower half of the market, sending the FTSE 250 (up 40.7 points to 7,149.6) and FTSE Small Cap (18.3 points better at 3,629.1) indices to record levels.

FTSE 250 telecoms stocks were the star performers: Redstone Telecom rose 40p to 355p, Atlantic Telecom added 38p to 388, Thus gained 12.5p to 156p and Kingston Communications put on 47p to 623p.

Dealers said the trigger for the move was positive comments from heavyweight broker Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, which started coverage of the sector by telling investors to adopt an "overweight" position. Ironically, Morgan Stanley's favoured play in the sector is FTSE 100 stock Energis , up 15p to 675. It rates the stock a "strong buy" and has set a 750p price target.

Elsewhere, internet-related stocks were chased higher by retail punters. Durlacher , effectively an internet investment trust, was a particular favourite, rising 12p to 115.5p, as was software provider InterX , 105p better at £11.50 and Virtual Internet , 55p higher at 315p. Moneyextra , the personal finance website group, advanced 8.5p to 46.5p, after it said it was considering its strategic options.

After touching 191p early in the session, Scoot.com , closed 26.25p higher at 152p, as the online directory service group moved to dampen takeover speculation. While Vivendi, the French media group and 22.4% shareholder, may increase its stake, Scoot said it had received no indication that it wanted to make an offer for the group.

On a more speculative tack, catalogue retailer N Brown jumped 32p to 322p amid talk of a possible big contract with Marks & Spencer , up 3.25p to 214p.

On AIM it was much the same story with retail investors chasing selected stocks higher. Internet language specialist Stilo International rose 43p to 134.5p in response to a tip in the specialist press, while internet recruitment firm RexOnline surged 56p to 181.5p as it confirmed reports of rapid revenue growth.

Leading shares, meanwhile, ended a quiet session modestly higher. Robbed of momentum by the Labour Day holiday in the US and undermined by a 5% fall by Vodafone - equivalent to 40 FTSE 100 index points - the blue chip gauge ended a mere 3.1 points higher at 6,798.1.

Nevertheless, this was still the FTSE 100's highest close of the year and, once Wall Street reopens today, dealers are predicting further gains. Accord ing to City professionals, institutional coffers are by historical standards stuffed with cash that is looking to find a home.

Among the leaders, internet service provider Freeserve , which could be relegated from the FTSE 100 later this week, rose 31p to 315p. Dealers said the move was a reflection of consolidation moves elsewhere in the sector. German group T-Online, which held talks with Freeserve earlier this year, yesterday acquired a Spanish portal. Dixons , which retains an 80.1% stake in the company, moved up 10p to 252p in sympathy.

Over in the banking sector, analysts continued to warm to Standard Chartered's acquisition of Chase Manhattan's Hong Kong consumer banking and credit card operations. Deutsche Bank was a fan, repeating its buy recommendation, while HSBC Securities, a noted bear of the stock, lifted its rating to reduce from sell. The stock ended 37p higher at £10.

Elsewhere in the sector, Royal Bank of Scotland advanced 48p to £12.83 and Lloyds TSB put on 19p to 647p, helped by Schroder Salomon Smith Barney advising clients to switch holdings in the insurance sector into banking stocks.

webTitle: Counter-bid hopes boost stock exchange shares

fields.headline: Counter-bid hopes boost stock exchange shares
fields.trailText: Shares in the London Stock Exchange hit new highs yesterday amid increasing expectation that a rival bidder will emerge to top the £800m-plus hostile bid already tabled by the Swedish group OM.
fields.body:
Shares in the London Stock Exchange hit new highs yesterday amid increasing expectation that a rival bidder will emerge to top the £800m-plus hostile bid already tabled by the Swedish group OM.

At one point shares in the exchange reached £31.50 yesterday before easing back to close at £29.75, valuing the company at close to £900m. Ahead of the OM bid they were changing hands at around £23.

Euronext, which represents the merged Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels exchanges, is now seen as the most likely bidder to challenge OM although it refused to be drawn on the speculation.

"We are looking at the situation very closely, that is all I can say," said a spokesman for the Paris bourse last night.

One complication for Euronext is that it does not come into existence officially until September 22. That would make it difficult for Euronext to table an offer - particularly if it wanted to make its own shares part of the bid - until after that date.

"Normally it would be logical to wait for their own listing on the stock exchange before making a bid for another exchange but it's always possible they could find some interim financing," said one industry source.

Although most of the expectation is currently focused on Euronext, it is not the only group seen as a potential bidder.

Frankfurt-based Deutsche Börse, whose plans to merge with the LSE have been upset by the OM bid, could make a "white knight" counter-bid but it would want to bring in other exchanges - Milan and Madrid are the most likely allies - rather than making a solo effort to counter OM.

Reuters' agency broker, Instinet, has also been mentioned as a possible bidder. Reuters declined to comment.

The OM bid has already forced the London exchange to abandon a planned vote by its shareholders on the merger with the German exchange.

That has given shareholders in the London exchange who opposed the merger with the Deutsche Börse a platform to argue against the Anglo-German merger.

The merger plan was drawn up on a 50-50 basis, which critics said undervalued the London end of the operation.

Under the terms of the UK takeover code, OM has 28 days from Monday of last week to send out its formal offer to London exchange shareholders, but it is expected to do so well within the timetable.

However, if a rival bidder were to emerge a new timetable would have to be brought in.

webTitle: Proms review

fields.headline: Proms review
fields.standfirst:
Henze premiere
Royal Albert Hall/Radio 3
****
fields.trailText:
Henze premiere
Royal Albert Hall/Radio 3 ****
fields.body:
Ever since Beethoven, the completion of a ninth symphony has been regarded as a watershed in a composer's development. Hans Werner Henze, who wrote his Ninth Symphony between 1995 and 1997, used the opportunity to write a 55-minute-long choral work, without soloists, in which he came to terms musically and emotionally with a traumatic period of his own early years. He designed the symphony as a summation of his life's work and calls it "an apotheosis of terror and grief" - an outpouring of the experience of living in Germany through the 30s and 40s.

The novel The Seventh Cross by Anna Seghers was his starting point. Henze asked the writer Hans-Ulrich Treichel, who has been his opera librettist for the last 15 years, to provide him with seven poems based upon the seven characters in the novel, who escape from a concentration camp only to be remorselessly hunted down and crucified. Just one of them survives, so that the seventh cross remains unoccupied. Treichel's texts don't replicate the narrative but impressionistically deal with the horror and fear of being a fugitive, of hiding from the hunters and of being captured. It's a dance of death on a massive scale which allows just a glimmer of hope in the final poem as the last fugitive escapes his persecutors.

Every movement in Henze's scheme is dominated by the chorus and their sombre words, yet it is not a quasi-opera nor an oratorio; it is a symphony in its arch-like form and manner. The tumultuous orchestral opening sets the mood in The Escape, as the chorus deliver halting impressions of the fugitive's terror. The second movement is a glacial little slow movement, the third a ferocious scherzo, drastically compressed. The long sixth movement, Night in the Cathedral, is the musical and emotional heart of the work as the escapee hides among the dead; it ends with a string threnody of Mahlerian intensity, and the last movement, with its shreds of optimism, has a provisional, barely affirmative feel.

Ingo Metzmacher, who conducted the premiere in Berlin three years ago, took charge of this searing first British performance. The choir, intense and dramatic when required, was again the Berlin Radio Choir, and the orchestra was the BBC Symphony. Henze's Ninth Symphony is an extraordinary piece, a one-off that is never easy listening, but impregnated with a sincerity and power that are deeply moving.

webTitle: Review: Trio Europa

fields.headline: In pursuit of lost youth
fields.standfirst:
Trio Europa and the GS Wellard Septet
Purcell Room, London
****
fields.trailText: British jazz relies these days on stalwarts like Gordon Wellard to convert the streetwise young to its charms.
fields.body:
British jazz relies these days on stalwarts like Gordon Wellard to convert the streetwise young to its charms.

This concert was a fundraiser for Wellard's Jazz in Schools cause, intended to give kids a taste of big band music. His septet, which during term-time runs the gauntlet of school assemblies, had a more relaxed outing here as the hard bop appetiser to the Trio Europa, fronted by the benevolent bassist Pierre Boussaguet whom Wellard encountered at the Marciac Jazz Festival. It was an evening of joy only marginally marred by exhortations at every opportunity to buy A Tribute to Keezer, Wellard's new album. All in a good cause, of course.

The four horn line-up included Steve Fishwick on trumpet and Ed Jones on tenor saxophone, who, lifting his knee to give leverage to his playing, built up several muscular passages with Bob Martin's warm, persuasive alto horn adding contrast.

Ping Pong, written by Wayne Shorter, gave the band a chance to let loose some energy, but The Good Life, arranged by Fishwick, was the highlight. The brass slowed to a saunter and Adrian Fry on trombone got a chance to shine.The biggest disappointment was that Wellard kept pounding away like a packhorse but never really took his own turn in the spotlight.

Trio Europa took the evening up another notch, despite the fact that drummer Alvin Queen was replaced last minute by Clark Tracey. In fact, Boussaguet, a favourite with players such as Wynton Marsalis and Cedar Walton, has known the British drummer for 20 years.

Pianist Hervé Sellin threatened to outshine them in dexterity and stamina as the trio launched the set with a tribute to the Catalonian pianist Tete Montoliu. Sellin's fingers danced, his right foot pedalled, his left foot skittered, at a loss to keep up. Next came Three Witches, which Boussaguet in troduced on bass with an edgy precedent and some great note-bending. The set got better and better, finishing with a grown-up version of Milt Jackson's Bags Groove, which had Tracey grounding a flighty piano with his drum flurries as, sneakily, the theme crept out.

The four horn line-up included Steve Fishwick on trumpet and Ed Jones on tenor saxophone, who, lifting his knee to give leverage to his playing, built up several muscular passages with Bob Martin's warm, persuasive alto horn adding contrast. Ping Pong, written by Wayne Shorter, gave the band a chance to let loose some energy, but The Good Life, arranged by Fishwick, was the highlight. The brass slowed to a saunter and Adrian Fry on trombone got a chance to shine.The biggest disappointment was that Wellard kept pounding away like a packhorse but never really took his own turn in the spotlight. Trio Europa took the evening up another notch, despite the fact that drummer Alvin Queen was replaced last minute by Clark Tracey. In fact, Boussaguet, a favourite with players such as Wynton Marsalis and Cedar Walton, has known the British drummer for 20 years. Pianist Hervé Sellin threatened to outshine them in dexterity and stamina as the trio launched the set with a tribute to the Catalonian pianist Tete Montoliu. Sellin's fingers danced, his right foot pedalled, his left foot skittered, at a loss to keep up. Next came Three Witches, which Boussaguet in troduced on bass with an edgy precedent and some great note-bending. The set got better and better, finishing with a grown-up version of Milt Jackson's Bags Groove, which had Tracey grounding a flighty piano with his drum flurries as, sneakily, the theme crept out.

webTitle: Anthony Bourdain's top 10 books about food

fields.headline: Anthony Bourdain's top 10 books about food
fields.trailText: Anthony Bourdain was born in New York in 1956 and has worked as dishwasher, prep-drone, fry-cook, grillardin, saucier, sous-chef and chef on both sides of the Atlantic for 25 years. He is now executive chef at Brasserie Les Halles, NYC
fields.body:
Anthony Bourdain was born in New York in 1956 and has worked as dishwasher, prep-drone, fry-cook, grillardin, saucier, sous-chef and chef on both sides of the Atlantic for 25 years. He is now executive chef at Brasserie Les Halles, NYC.

He is the author of two novels, Gone Bamboo and Bone in the Throat; his first non-fiction work, Kitchen Confidential, takes the reader into the kitchens to reveal the seamy side of the smartest restaurants.

Sex, drugs and haute cuisine... Read an extract from Kitchen Confidential

Buy Kitchen Confidential at Amazon.co.uk

1. The French Laundry Cookbook by Thomas Keller
The mad monk of Napa Valley's unsurpassed cookery book - the ultimate in porno for chefs.

2. White Heat by Marco Pierre White
A chef who looks like a chef! A revelationto professional culinarians when it came out. Great food, recognisable worldview of the culinary perfectionist - and a ground-breaking shot of a chefsmoking.

3. Down and Out in Paris and London by George Orwell
The first account of whatit's REALLY like in a professional kitchen, and as true today as it was when it waswritten.

4. The Kitchen by Nicolas Freeling
Another seminal work on the business, fromthe point of view of the professional.

5. The Belly of Paris by Emile Zola
The Citizen Kane of foodie books: escapedconvict becomes food inspector in 19th-century Paris marketplace Les Halles.

6. La Cuisine du Marche by Paul Bocuse
The Big Daddy of Nouvelle Cuisine's widely imitated cookbook. Still useful, decades later.

7. The Epicurean by Charles Ranhofer
The turn-of-the-century Delmonico's chefspills everything he knows about cooking. Ranhofer's work wasunprecedented - and was considered high treason by his peers at the time. Afascinating and imposing tome and an important piece of culinary history.

8. The Ivy by AA Gill
As fascinating for its account of a day in the life of a swanky restaurant as for its recipes.

9. Le Bernardin Cookbook by Eric Ripert
Modern, clean, impeccable and austererecipes from New York's brilliant seafood Dauphin.

10. Nose To Tail Eating by Fergus Henderson
Absolutely uncompromising ode toBritish cooking by the awesome chef of St John's. A rare and unpretentiouscollection of recipes for the neglected (but often tastiest) parts of ediblecreatures. Who says British cooking isn't great? This book ROCKS!

webTitle: Review: Parsifal at the Albert Hall

fields.headline: Rattle takes on riddle
fields.standfirst:
Parsifal
Royal Albert Hall, London
****
fields.trailText: More than a hundred years after its premiere, the world still hasn't made up its mind about Wagner's Parsifal. Is it an outpouring of Christian mysticism, or deeply blasphemous?
fields.body:
More than a hundred years after its premiere, the world still hasn't made up its mind about Wagner's Parsifal. Is it an outpouring of Christian mysticism, or deeply blasphemous?

How much of it is a projection of Wagner's fascination with eastern philosophy on to a legendary western subject? Is the work primarily erotic? Does its portrayal of a uniformed elite harping on about "purity" and "blood" prefigure Nazism? Most would agree though that the score's noxious beauty still exerts a spellbinding fascination. It certainly did on this occasion.

This is the first time Simon Rattle has tackled the complete work in the UK, though he conducted the Netherlands Opera production in 1997. For his Prom performance he used a Dutch orchestra - the Rotterdam Philharmonic, on astonishing form - and some of his original cast.

Rattle takes a while to get the balance right. The Prelude has a blinding, crystalline clarity that just falls short of the genuinely mystic. The first appearance of Klingsor's theme is sinister rather than seditious. He doesn't strike form until the first Grail scene, in which the sense of numinous mystery finally becomes apparent. Thereafter he is superlative, swivelling between the sexy and the demonic in act two, and reaching remarkable heights of serenity and anguish in the final act.

You're in no doubt, either, that Rattle sees the work as prefiguring much of the repertoire that we most closely associate with him: the flashes forward to Schoenberg in the scene between Parsifal and Kundry; the hints of Debussy in the translucent textures of the Flower Maidens' sequence; above all, the prototype of Mahler's symphonic funeral marches in the tremendous act three interlude.

Poul Elming's dark-hued Parsifal brilliantly captures the weariness of the absolute moral responsibility that follows spiritual enlightenment, though he doesn't quite convey boyish innocence in the earlier scenes. Petra Lang's Kundry is better at sexiness than neurosis, though there's no mistaking the quality of her superb voice. As Amfortas, Wolfgang Schoene powerfully projects excruciating physical pain, though the pitch occasionally sags. Robert Lloyd's Gurnemanz remains a superlative achievement, while Sergei Leiferkus, one fluffed entry apart, is the best, most serpentine Klingsor of all.

webTitle: Creating a strong impression

fields.headline: Creating a strong impression
fields.standfirst: Young, talented creative pairings are the life-blood of the advertising industry. We reveal the cream of today's rising stars and agency heads of the tomorrrow.
fields.trailText: Young, talented creative pairings are the life-blood of the advertising industry. Emma Hall reveals the cream of today's rising stars and agency heads of the tomorrrow.
fields.body:
Creative directors are always looking for something they have not got. And that usually means youth, freshness and an original approach.

Advertising agencies need constant injections of energy from young creatives who are still excited by the possibilities the profession offers. They need people who are in touch with life outside the confines of the client/agency relationship.

"I'd rather have to rein them in than kick them into action," says Soul creative director Bruce Crouch. Crouch, who was Bartle Bogle Hegarty's creative director for three years, wants raw thinking from his young teams, even if their ideas are too edgy to be translated directly into commercials.

"Be rebellious, challenge me," Crouch demands. "We'll mould you."

Tim Hearn, the creative director of St Luke's, agrees: "Why should I hire someone if I already have a whole department full of people who can do the same thing? I want people with ideas so odd that no one here would have thought of them. And we have some pretty odd people here."

Ironically, one enemy of raw creative talent is the advertising colleges. Many creative directors criticise them for churning out teams that have been taught to think only in formulaic terms. "I don't believe in studying old ads. It's creative BSE. Where's the new air?" asks Trevor Beattie, creative director of TBWA.

"You should be studying life, relationships and television programmes," he says.

Creative types can study the past masters all they like, but the lessons they learn are limited by the fact that the advertising and marketing worlds are a lot more complex than they were just two years ago. Simple ideas are common currency and new media requires new thinking. This situation can make life more complicated for creative directors seeking new talent.

Robert Campbell, joint creative director of Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R, says: "As the criteria by which we judge ads broadens, it's harder to guess who's going to be good at them. You have to look for freer thinking individuals with strong ideas."

Some creative directors inevitably complain that, because of the new profusion of creative industries, the most talented youngsters are no longer seeking a career in advertising. "It is rare to see someone who is 100 per cent-committed to advertising," Hearn says. "You usually get the feeling that they'd rather be doing something else but think they can get into it through ads."

So the smart agencies put a lot of energy into finding new blood and send out scouts to snap up student talent before it is siphoned off by new media moguls.

Real talent has always been rare, but all top creative directors can come up with a select list of hot young things whose work they admire.

Beattie believes the current crop of new talent is better than it has been for many years. "There's a new energy about advertising," he insists. "The new media revolution has made everyone think more creatively."

webTitle: New Media Diary

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: • Hyperlinks, they're a funny old thing. First BT claims that it invented them and decides the world should pay it huge sums of cash for the privilege of hyperlinking. Now, it seems that hyperlinking is being taken from one extreme to the next, with corporates laying down strict guidelines for the erstwhile courteous act of providing links to another company's site. A curious two-page document arrived in the Diary's inbox this week from Lloyds TSB, setting out the bank's rigorous demands for any site that wishes to provide a common-or-garden free link to www.lloydstsb.com. The days of informal referring of traffic appear to be well and truly over, that is unless you consent to sign a restrictive contract which binds you to check the link is working on a daily basis, and if your site changes in any way you are obliged to notify Lloyds TSB. But that's barely scratching the surface: the relationship, although in no way does the link imply any form of relationship, expires after a year unless it is renewed in writing, and... well, I could go on, but there's not enough space. However, the Diary has henceforth decided to start a ridiculous practice monitor, and will endeavour to bring to light any absurd policies. So send them in.

 Hyperlinks, they're a funny old thing. First BT claims that it invented them and decides the world should pay it huge sums of cash for the privilege of hyperlinking. Now, it seems that hyperlinking is being taken from one extreme to the next, with corporates laying down strict guidelines for the erstwhile courteous act of providing links to another company's site. A curious two-page document arrived in the Diary's inbox this week from Lloyds TSB, setting out the bank's rigorous demands for any site that wishes to provide a common-or-garden free link to www.lloydstsb.com. The days of informal referring of traffic appear to be well and truly over, that is unless you consent to sign a restrictive contract which binds you to check the link is working on a daily basis, and if your site changes in any way you are obliged to notify Lloyds TSB. But that's barely scratching the surface: the relationship, although in no way does the link imply any form of relationship, expires after a year unless it is renewed in writing, and... well, I could go on, but there's not enough space. However, the Diary has henceforth decided to start a ridiculous practice monitor, and will endeavour to bring to light any absurd policies. So send them in.

 Never let it be said that journalists don't have any influence over people's decisions. While attending the e-women summer party last Thursday, the Diary was flabbergasted to learn that yours truly was the inspiration behind it all. Apparently, and this is straight from the mouth of founder Kathryn Bullock, a rant - arguing that women's websites were patronising and that women needed better representation - was the spark that lead to the formation of e-women. Such power. The Diary is now thinking of patenting future ideas and cashing in on companies that evolve from them - a slice of equity and non-exec board position should keep the ideas flowing nicely.

 Fans and followers of Richard Lord, effervescent editor of trade rag Revolution, will be saddened by the news that dear old Dickie has been struck down by a mysterious Asian lurgy while out schmoozing in Hong Kong - under the pretence of setting up Revolution Asia. Mmm. Over at Revolution Towers, panic set in when news of Dickie's illness broke and it was deemed that he was far too ill to write his weekly tirade, sorry column. The simple explanation in the rag "Richard Lord is unwell" left so many questions unanswered - like where to send the flowers... does "Screaming ad-dabs" Dickie have enough Imodium... is someone looking after him? Thankfully Mr Reliable Phil Smith, deputy editor of Revolution, was at hand to step in and fill the blank space at the last minute, saving the day and the magazine from more nasty, unfounded rumours about its closure.

webTitle: Audio visions

fields.headline: Audio visions
fields.standfirst: Six young people will soon get their big breaks at Radio 1.  Andy Parfitt explains how they will be chosen
fields.trailText: Six young people will soon get their big breaks at Radio 1. Andy Parfitt explains how they will be chosen
fields.body:
As part of the BBC Talent campaign, Radio 1 invited young people with a passion for music and creative ideas to match to apply for six year-long traineeships. Submissions have now been whittled down to the final 50.

As well as their creativity and love of music, I want the station's six trainees to bring their enthusiasm, energy and an outside perspective on Radio 1. What we are all about here is having the best understanding of our target audience of anybody in the UK and I think we do pretty well. But we need to work all the time at bringing in a fresh perspective from people who will have a view about everything we do, so, whether it's the website, the playlist or the way the presenters approach their shows, I'm looking for that external view from six young people who have proved they have the ability and staying power to get through this process.

From their programme proposals I was mainly looking for originality. There were plenty that expanded 'on existing Radio 1 themes - live music, for example. I saw dozens that suggested we do this live act from that location but what I wanted was "and we will then do such and such". In other words, I was looking for the extra creative thinking on top of a pretty standard theme. Alternatively, I was looking for something completely left-field. There were some strange and lovely ideas that I read, and my question was: could we actually achieve this in practice? I would rather have a really inventive and original idea which, after some discussion, we may not be able to do in practice - I'd like to have the discussion about the idea.

I was looking for applications that showed the author had real imagination - the ability to idealise, to look for and imagine situations for presenters and so on. I was also looking for candidates to talk about the audience and to really understand how Radio 1 has to suit the mood of the time of day. For example, if you were doing a specialist show with some very new, experimental music, you wouldn't put it out at drivetime. So, just those little clues gave me an insight into how thoroughly they'd been thought through.

Another important factor is the ability to communicate on a piece of paper with real impact. There were some well written but very lengthy proposals where I felt one had to work quite hard to understand what the programme was about. If you are an executive producer or an editor at Radio 1, these proposals have to leap off the page and give you a clear picture of the show pretty quickly. The two examples we've selected below are pretty pithy and to the point, giving you an instant flavour of what you will hear.

What also stood out in the two proposals we're using as examples was that some really thorough, creative thinking had gone into the ideas and that the authors had thought a lot about the audience, which is very important. In the first of the proposals, there are a dozen fairly well thought-through hooks that would engage listeners. In the second example, the author clearly understands Ant and Dec, their characters, and the way that they relate to audiences.

There are a couple of ways the submissions below could be improved. "Tranceformations" submitted a list of 15 themed ideas for a specialist show catering for the trance fraternity. However, if you were presenting this to an editor or executive producer you would start with a little summary paragraph to communicate the trance scene. Also, I don't need 15 feature ideas: I would get the impression that this is a quality, thought-through proposal from someone who knows the scene after about eight. You just need to select the ideas that give the indication that you, the producer, really know your stuff as far as trance is concerned.

I think "Ant 'n' Dec's Morning Assembly" offers a full, creative and striking idea. The candidate probably took too long to explain the quiz mechanics, however: all that needs to be said is that the quiz would involve the teachers and the kids and the specific details would be worked out at a later stage. What I did like about this one is that the candidate clearly understood how Ant and Dec would match in with the 16-year-olds at the school. I like the line: "School's out - not when it's this much of a laugh!" It gave me a sense of fun, slapstick and irony, and I like that.

Contenders . . . two of the best proposals

Tranceformations

"A change or alteration, especially a radical one." A future-based show showcasing new talent, spotting future hits in clubland and the charts.

Presented by
DJ MTK and guests.

Time
4-6am, Sunday and Monday.

Musical style
Catering to the trance fraternity, eg Time to Burn by Storm; Beautiful by Matt Darey; Fly Away by Unknown; 4 Seasons EP by Sander Kleinberg; Superstring by Cygnus X; Feeling this Way by Conductor and the Cowboy; More and More by Spoiled and Zigo.

Features include
Distinctive Demo : Send in your tunes, win a chance to get signed.
Tranceportation : A monthly slot where a listener's track is reproduced in studio by a top producer.
Tranceaction : Top DJs give demonstrations on how to get those mixes right.
Spot the Cyber Kid : Find the cyber kid hidden on the Radio 1 website.
Spot that Sample : Where did that tune originate?
Trancemission : Letters, email and phone-in slot.
Sonic Heaven : New equipment tested and demos of results broadcast.
What's Hot, What's Not : MTK runs down his trance top-10 chart of what is set to become massive in clubland.
Clubbers' Corner : Interactive web chat, with listeners phoning in their reviews of clubs, clubwear and club politics.
Industry Insight : Advice on education, books, magazines, shops, studios and labels looking for new talent.
Studio Solutions : Your opinion on good home studio set-ups - your problems and our solutions.
Gurners' Gallery : Email your photos to the gallery top 10 - can your photo make it to the top spot?
Twister Trancer : Strangest tune of the week.

Ant 'n' Dec's morning assembly

A classic Radio 1 roadshow with a twist - a week-long live and lively broadcast from five different schools and colleges across the UK, featuring live performances, comedy sketches (like the tactless nit nurse), quizzes and celebrity sports days. The overall feel is fun and funny - heavy on the double entendres but making the most of the double act's personalities and comic acting abilities, and tying in with the school theme as much as possible.

Presented by
Anthony McPartlin and Declan Donnelly.

Time
9am-11am weekdays, for one week only in August.

Musical style
Mainstream playlist tracks, charts, new releases and live performances, eg Steps, Craig David, Travis, Alice Deejay.

Features include
The Tuckshop : A quiz, introduced as the "non-stop, news and pop, question swap". Three students versus three teachers in three rounds spread over the show's two hours. In the first round, the kids (preferably 16-year-olds, to reflect the core Radio 1 audience of young - or young-minded - adults) choose five pop culture questions to ask the teachers. In the second, the teachers choose five current affairs questions to ask in return. Teams must always give a response or a point is taken off, so daft guesses should be encouraged. In the final round, Behind the Bike Shed, Ant and Dec pretend to be a celebrity couple (past or present), and it's open to either team to guess their identities. After the broadcast, a picture of Ant, Dec and all participating pupils and teachers will be posted on the Radio 1 website. The unmistakable vocal talents of Mr Bronson from Grange Hill will be used for pre-recorded links and samples played over tracks. School's out? Not when it's this much of a laugh!

 Andy Parfitt is controller of Radio 1

In other words, I was looking for the extra creative thinking on top of a pretty standard theme. Alternatively, I was looking for something completely left-field. There were some strange and lovely ideas that I read, and my question was: could we actually achieve this in practice? I would rather have a really inventive and original idea which, after some discussion, we may not be able to do in practice - I'd like to have the discussion about the idea. I was looking for applications that showed the author had real imagination - the ability to idealise, to look for and imagine situations for presenters and so on. I was also looking for candidates to talk about the audience and to really understand how Radio 1 has to suit the mood of the time of day. For example, if you were doing a specialist show with some very new, experimental music, you wouldn't put it out at drivetime. So, just those little clues gave me an insight into how thoroughly they'd been thought through. Another important factor is the ability to communicate on a piece of paper with real impact. There were some well written but very lengthy proposals where I felt one had to work quite hard to understand what the programme was about. If you are an executive producer or an editor at Radio 1, these proposals have to leap off the page and give you a clear picture of the show pretty quickly. The two examples we've selected below are pretty pithy and to the point, giving you an instant flavour of what you will hear. What also stood out in the two proposals we're using as examples was that some really thorough, creative thinking had gone into the ideas and that the authors had thought a lot about the audience, which is very important. In the first of the proposals, there are a dozen fairly well thought-through hooks that would engage listeners. In the second example, the author clearly understands Ant and Dec, their characters, and the way that they relate to audiences. There are a couple of ways the submissions below could be improved. "Tranceformations" submitted a list of 15 themed ideas for a specialist show catering for the trance fraternity. However, if you were presenting this to an editor or executive producer you would start with a little summary paragraph to communicate the trance scene. Also, I don't need 15 feature ideas: I would get the impression that this is a quality, thought-through proposal from someone who knows the scene after about eight. You just need to select the ideas that give the indication that you, the producer, really know your stuff as far as trance is concerned. I think "Ant 'n' Dec's Morning Assembly" offers a full, creative and striking idea. The candidate probably took too long to explain the quiz mechanics, however: all that needs to be said is that the quiz would involve the teachers and the kids and the specific details would be worked out at a later stage. What I did like about this one is that the candidate clearly understood how Ant and Dec would match in with the 16-year-olds at the school. I like the line: "School's out - not when it's this much of a laugh!" It gave me a sense of fun, slapstick and irony, and I like that. Contenders . . . two of the best proposals Tranceformations "A change or alteration, especially a radical one." A future-based show showcasing new talent, spotting future hits in clubland and the charts. Presented by DJ MTK and guests. Time 4-6am, Sunday and Monday. Musical style Catering to the trance fraternity, eg Time to Burn by Storm; Beautiful by Matt Darey; Fly Away by Unknown; 4 Seasons EP by Sander Kleinberg; Superstring by Cygnus X; Feeling this Way by Conductor and the Cowboy; More and More by Spoiled and Zigo. Features include Distinctive Demo : Send in your tunes, win a chance to get signed. Tranceportation : A monthly slot where a listener's track is reproduced in studio by a top producer. Tranceaction : Top DJs give demonstrations on how to get those mixes right. Spot the Cyber Kid : Find the cyber kid hidden on the Radio 1 website. Spot that Sample : Where did that tune originate? Trancemission : Letters, email and phone-in slot. Sonic Heaven : New equipment tested and demos of results broadcast. What's Hot, What's Not : MTK runs down his trance top-10 chart of what is set to become massive in clubland. Clubbers' Corner : Interactive web chat, with listeners phoning in their reviews of clubs, clubwear and club politics. Industry Insight : Advice on education, books, magazines, shops, studios and labels looking for new talent. Studio Solutions : Your opinion on good home studio set-ups - your problems and our solutions. Gurners' Gallery : Email your photos to the gallery top 10 - can your photo make it to the top spot? Twister Trancer : Strangest tune of the week. Ant 'n' Dec's morning assembly A classic Radio 1 roadshow with a twist - a week-long live and lively broadcast from five different schools and colleges across the UK, featuring live performances, comedy sketches (like the tactless nit nurse), quizzes and celebrity sports days. The overall feel is fun and funny - heavy on the double entendres but making the most of the double act's personalities and comic acting abilities, and tying in with the school theme as much as possible. Presented by Anthony McPartlin and Declan Donnelly. Time 9am-11am weekdays, for one week only in August. Musical style Mainstream playlist tracks, charts, new releases and live performances, eg Steps, Craig David, Travis, Alice Deejay. Features include The Tuckshop : A quiz, introduced as the "non-stop, news and pop, question swap". Three students versus three teachers in three rounds spread over the show's two hours. In the first round, the kids (preferably 16-year-olds, to reflect the core Radio 1 audience of young - or young-minded - adults) choose five pop culture questions to ask the teachers. In the second, the teachers choose five current affairs questions to ask in return. Teams must always give a response or a point is taken off, so daft guesses should be encouraged. In the final round, Behind the Bike Shed, Ant and Dec pretend to be a celebrity couple (past or present), and it's open to either team to guess their identities. After the broadcast, a picture of Ant, Dec and all participating pupils and teachers will be posted on the Radio 1 website. The unmistakable vocal talents of Mr Bronson from Grange Hill will be used for pre-recorded links and samples played over tracks. School's out? Not when it's this much of a laugh!  Andy Parfitt is controller of Radio 1

webTitle: Marks breaks free

fields.headline: Marks breaks free
fields.standfirst: The company that didn't need to advertise has had a radical U-turn in a bid to transform a fading image, with a stripping model pioneering the new M&S. Smart or foolish? Claire Cozens takes the industry pulse.
fields.trailText: The company that didn't need to advertise has had a radical U-turn in a bid to transform a fading image, with a stripping model pioneering the new M&S. Smart or foolish? Claire Cozens takes the industry pulse.
fields.body:
Bare-bottomed girls running joyfully up hills and groups of women orgasmically screaming, "Yes, Yes, Yes" do not fit with most people's mental image of Marks & Spencer. But then, the mental image of M&S is exactly what the retailer is trying to escape. And its first major advertising campaign, which breaks on Friday, is a brave bid to shake off its old-fashioned image without alienating its core market of middle Englanders.

For years, Marks & Spencer claimed it did not need to advertise, making it the company the ad industry loved to hate, because prospective clients could always argue that if a successful brand like M&S didn't advertise, why should they?

Now, in a major policy turnaround, M&S is to plough £20m into a major television, poster & press campaign to reverse the decline in fortunes of the brand that once seemed unassailable. The campaign, created by Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R, introduces the new strapline, "Exclusively for Everyone".

The first ad shows a size 16 model, Amy Davis, stripping off as she runs up a hill. At the top, she raises her arms and shouts: "I'm normal" in celebration of the fact that she can now buy stylish clothes that fit. It ends with a variety of women wearing a fashionable selection of clothes. The second, designed to promote Marks & Spencer's autumn collection, features three women secretly looking forward to autumn to give them an excuse to buy new clothes. The strapline is, "Yes! Yes! Yes! You can't say no to the new autumn collection".

Tim Mellors, executive creative director of Grey Advertising, believes that the campaign will have to be dramatic if it is to persuade people to change their views of Marks & Spencer. "The reality is that they've changed radically. If you look at some of the Italian designer wear they've got, it's nothing like what you would expect of M&S. So whatever they do, they need to radically alter that fuddy-duddy image. The ad with the size 16 model sounds like it's moving in the right direction. People have always thought of M&S as being quite rational and this combines that with the unexpected.

"Relatively speaking, it is quite daring to be putting across a view about anorexia. But the ad for the autumn collection sounds a bit too predictable."

Mark Wnek, executive creative director of Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper, believes the ad will have a strong impact: "Even the most downmarket clothes stores have traditionally used pouting models in their ads. Marks & Spencer is saying, 'let's dare to talk to real women in a real way'. By using a nude model they will ensure it has impact and gets noticed. I'm sure there will be a certain amount of pursed lips in Milton Keynes, but you have to accept that."

But one senior agency source worries that the campaign is too obviously based on the focus group results: "Everyone wants it to be good because at heart we all love Marks & Spencer. But this seems like one of those dangerous strategies that can sometimes come out of focus groups - people might say things like 'I want to be free, I want to be me and I don't want to feel pressurised into being skinny.' But what people say they want from their advertising is not always the same as what will make them buy the product."

And Dave Droga, executive creative director of Saatchi & Saatchi, says: "Using shock tactics is a really obvious thing to do when you're trying to make an impact, but there is no point in being controversial for the sake of it," he says. "It might get you noticed in the short term, but the public has a very short memory."

webTitle: I'll be watching

fields.headline: I'll be watching
fields.standfirst: She's not scared of a showdown and is used to being loathed, so what will Patricia Hodgson do with the independent television commission now that she's in charge? She tells  Maggie Brown  that it's all about being assertive
fields.trailText: She's not scared of a showdown and is used to being loathed, so what will Patricia Hodgson do with the independent television commission now that she's in charge? She tells Maggie Brown that it's all about being assertive
fields.body:
Often described as the most formidable woman in British television, Patricia Hodgson is at the door of her new habitat, the chief executive's office of the independent television commission (ITC). She is beaming with pleasure; or it may be power.

Minutes into the interview she has dispensed with the habitual caution of a BBC lifer and is speaking recklessly. Formerly John Birt's right-hand woman, she played the villain's part to perfection as his much-loathed director of policy and planning. Now she has left the BBC, she's "going for it", prepared to risk a showdown.

Her agenda is to salvage the ITC from extinction: to fix the row with ITV over News at Ten by the end of this month; save the thing she cares about most - public service broadcasting - and ensure the forthcoming white paper on media, communications and "convergence" remembers that broadcasting has cultural obligations. No mean feat.

As she sees it, the ITC, as the licensing body until new legislation comes in, has the power to make public service broadcasting worthwhile in business terms. It can cut the annual "levy" payments by ITV, and negotiate altered terms ("don't call it relaxation"), but in return for more programme investment. Seven licence-holders, including Central, LWT and Granada, are about to apply to renew their franchises and, consequently, renegotiate their annual licence payments. The ITC still controls some important levers and Hodgson has the nerve to use them.

Her determination was apparent when she spoke at last week's Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival about the forthcoming white paper. Her appointment - she starts officially today - changes the balance of the regulatory environment. Her predecessor, Peter Rogers, was shy and decent but lacked the confidence of the industry; with his retirement, the ITC could become far more assertive.

In her Edinburgh speech, she also gave her views on the BBC governors. "They are needed," she said, "to keep the BBC management honest. They should be strong enough to keep politicians at bay. But they, too, must be accountable. They can't convincingly embody the BBC and then also judge it." BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland accepts this, she says.

Back to the ITC. "I took the job because it is an opportunity to make a difference. The challenge is to achieve a new settlement for public service broadcasting, to take the free-to-air networks [ITV, Channel 4, Channel 5] into the new digital age over the next 10 years." It is very late in the day, she concedes, but possible. ITV is being offered a deal. She will move "further and faster on [simplifying] regulation", with the prospect of more "flexible" schedules and advertising controls. But it must keep faith with its most important public service duties, providing "range and quality" - above all, serious news and modernised current affairs.

The clue to Hodgson is that she is a politician manqué. At Cambridge she was a committee member of the university Conservative association, then worked for the Conservative Research Department, even contesting a London seat. She plays the political chess game like a grandmaster - unlike the ITC before her arrival, with its abandonment of News at Ten two years ago. The ITC has "not been sufficiently confident of its skills and professionalism in a changing world," she says. "It needs confidence."

Her answer is strengthened leadership - ie, herself - and new recruits with economic and strategic expertise - presumably ex-colleagues from BBC policy and planning looking for a new world to conquer. The watchdog could then regain the ear of government.

But the first aim, clear in Edinburgh, is a face-saving deal with ITV before it goes to court at the end of this month for a judicial review of the commission's edict effectively ordering the broadcaster to restore News at Ten. The two sides can "talk up to the courtroom door," Hodgson says.

She pounced instantly on an olive branch offered by Charles Allen, chief executive of Granada Media Group. Hodgson scents a deal. "It's the first time anyone of great seniority and influence has wanted to talk."

It is her good fortune to take over as ITV consolidates into two big power blocs, far easier to deal with, and when one awkward baron, Lord Hollick, is exiting. Salvaging the ITC's reputation rests on keeping this dispute out of court. "We shouldn't be where we are," says Hodgson, insisting that "it's not about the 10pm slot" - though she repeats that "11pm is too late". She says there are plenty of other options now that the BBC is switching its news to 10pm; the important thing is to ensure optimum accessibility to improve audiences.

Taking a line calculated to please politicians, Hodgson argues that "however excellent the BBC news is, dominance by any news service is not good for democracy." Some news, she says, inevitably then "gets left out".

If the dispute proceeds to judicial review, she says, "it will tie my hands in modernising regulation [as ITV wants] ... I might have the best scheme in the world to simplify regulation, but how can we talk about it if we're having a great big barney?"

Her other priority is to mould the white paper on media convergence, and, one suspects, temper the drive, led by the Department of Trade and Industry, towards a telecoms-driven regime where social obligations scarcely feature. She is seeking recognition that terrestrial networks need "transitional arrangements" in which consumer protection and duties, such as investment in high-quality regional programmes, can be traded for privileges, such as guarantees of being given prominence on all platforms and electronic programme guides.

But this is not what ITV executives seem to worry about in public. Rather, they cry out for a level playing field with freedom to dump genres such as religion and compete head-on with the likes of Sky.

"When their minds are focused, ITV executives recognise the validity of the requirements of diversity," Hodgson says. "I have a good deal of sympathy with their frustrations. Now ITV is settling its ownership issues we'll start talking about the right mix of self-set aspirational and mandatory targets."

She wants to open discussions with licensees and the government, and also see a proper digital strategy in place for ITV, akin to the BBC's which she helped to devise, and Channel 4's. "My hope is to make content regulation simpler, clearer, less complex, to reflect all the things ITV complains of, but holding onto the essentials." She points to the success of the tougher yet aspirational Channel 4 licence agreement introduced two years ago as a model: multi-cultural programmes, for example, have been moved out of ghetto slots to prime time.

In her Edinburgh speech, Hodgson asked: "Will the multi-channel interactive world provide all the content audiences need?" She, naturally, answered her own question: "Given the power and pervasive nature of the electronic media, I think we'll continue to do so in a big way. How it's done, through the BBC, through privileges for some players on the commercial side, needs to be worked out. Someone has to do that, with, but independent of, government." It's a vision that handily keeps the ITC, or something like it, in business.

Once described by Guardian writer Dave Hill as "a woman apparently sculpted from deep-frozen Oil of Ulay", Hodgson has never been short of detractors. Behind her back some of the important executives she has to rub along with range from sceptical to antagonistic (told this, she just says "what fun!"). Asked about hostile predictions that she will bring a bossy BBC perspective to a commercial sector where she has never worked, she counters that she "learned a fair bit about the commercial world when I served on the monopolies and mergers commission [forerunner to the competition commission] for six years." Instead of "nannying" the network, her aim is "a new deal - to achieve simpler regulations, and only when they're needed". Far from imposing a BBC perspective, she backs further consolidation: "One ITV is the target. It is not only inevitable, it is desirable."

Another charge is that she has a personal agenda, to emerge from the expected cull of watchdogs as top dog, regulating the content of electronic media (and those BBC governors), within or outside of a new economic regulator, called perhaps Ofcom. She simply wants to ensure the ITC is respected, and works with other regulators to "design together a new framework", she answers.

Those who admire Hodgson - citing such BBC coups as the renewal of its charter in 1996, and this year's licence fee settlement, which makes possible Greg Dyke's new programme spending - say she will be a very good thing for the ITC, and its currently anxious staff. And for viewers.

At Edinburgh, Dyke used his MacTaggart lecture to opine that advertising-funded channels such as ITV will find it hard as television fragments. Hodgson responds with vigour. "Greg is wrong. All free-to-air channels will be showcases for much bigger media companies. The money will be there. I love this sector, and I have an opportunity to get it right."

Not to be under-estimated.

webTitle: New media: The women's portal market

fields.headline: Women on the verge of a nervous breakdown
fields.standfirst:
The lucrative women's portal market already boasts six generic sites. But with US invaders poised to show us how it's done and analysts warning that there's only room for two, something has got to give, says Imogen O'Rorke

Net news
fields.trailText: The lucrative women's portal market already boasts six generic sites. But with US invaders poised to show us how it's done and analysts warning that there's only room for two, something has got to give, says Imogen O'Rorke
fields.body:
Next month, the UK's first women's portal will celebrate its first birthday. For the publishers of Handbag and its peers-in-combat iCircle, Charlotte Street and Beme, the past 12 months have amounted to a costly and nerve-wracking experiment. Valuable lessons about this fledgling market have been learned, but huge cash piles have been used up, and there has already been one loser.

On top of the growing pains, the imminent arrival of two powerful US players into the UK later this year - iVillage, backed by Tesco, and Hearst-owned uk.women.com under the aegis of NatMags - has forced British publishers to reassess who their audience is and where their real revenue is coming from. E-commerce has not experienced the growth that was projected in the last year, and start-ups like the Ready2 network, founded by journalists Susannah Constantine and Trinny Woodall, have been forced to cut their operations back. The Americans, boasting five years of experience over their competitors, regard the British market as underdeveloped - in other words, it had better grow up fast.

The replacement of Charlotte Street's launch editor Nicola Davenport by Maria Trkulja, head of marketing at e-retailer Zoom, was the first sign that Associated News and Media's site was having an identity crisis. Burden commented at the time: "We have all our advertising booked up and we are the envy of our competitors, but the lack of e-commerce will be the death of the women's portal." "Publishing companies are used to thinking of advertising as their main revenue, but e-commerce is the only way forward."

The invaders have timed their entry into the marketplace well, striking when the herd is turning and the weaklings are starting to reveal themselves. "They're getting to know the beast before attacking," says Burden.

It already has 160,000 registered users in this country, a base it hopes to build on with $18m (£12m) put aside by Tesco into the launch, with a further $25m for marketing. The attitude of the newcomers seems sublimely confident but rather vague. uk.women.com, which calls itself a "destination site" not a portal, plans to become "a market leader". "We have an open-minded attitude: any way it's appropriate, any way it works. We have a good set of skills and have been around the block," says MD Lisa Riley. "We have a portfolio of magazine brands [at NatMags] to choose from and we will cherry pick the best." In terms of personality, there will be an "even tone" and "focused attitude", but she is not giving anything away.

In response to the stock criticism that cultural differences will present a serious barrier to entry, Riley says: "We are not going to foist the American content on this market, but we're using it to inform what works for audiences. With ready-made commerce partnerships, however, it won't have to try as hard.

Distancing itself from other portals, Handbag has started calling itself a "mass-market site" (the difference being that it commissions its own articles and produces content in-house) but it's a frivolous distinction. Market ing directorAlicen Stenner claims the Handbag formula is working. More tools are promised, more experts, more interaction and community, and no change to editorial policy.

iCircle likewise is sticking to its 25-35 target age range and "all inclusive voice" covering issues under subject headings, similar to the American prototype. MD Deborah Sherry believes the site's distribution via Freeserve, which enables the highest reach (1.9m compared to Handbag's 1.5m) and low marketing spend gives it the edge over Handbag, and confirms it will be "redoubling efforts" to improve e-commerce.

Beneath the veneer of corporate civility - "Handbag welcomes newcomers for the PR it brings us"; iCircle thinks "it makes the marketplace more exciting" - the Brits are battening down the hatches and preparing for battle.

The glittering prize is a sizeable chunk of the fastest-growing market on the internet. There are now around 5m women regularly using the internet and around 28% use it to shop (an increase of almost a third in a year). With women affecting most of the buying decisions in the household, the predictions for commerce in the future look very tempting indeed. "There is still an enormous opportunity because no one has got the magic formula right yet," says Ulph. "If the UK publishers don't get it right in the next few months they will be too late."

webTitle: New media: The beginnning of broadband Britain

fields.headline: Will you let the fat pipe into your home?
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Today marks the beginning of broadband Britain. After much waiting, BT has announced that service providers such as Freeserve, Demon and BT Openworld can provide high-speed internet services over existing BT phonelines using a technology called ADSL (asymmetric digital subscriber line).
fields.body:
Today marks the beginning of broadband Britain. After much waiting, BT has announced that service providers such as Freeserve, Demon and BT Openworld can provide high-speed internet services over existing BT phonelines using a technology called ADSL (asymmetric digital subscriber line).

Although the service will not at first be available to every part of the country, more than 7m homes and businesses will have access from this week. BT promises that the majority of Britain will be broadband capable by the end of 2001.

We have all experienced difficulties in connecting to the internet and the world wide wait as pages take an age to download. ADSL technology promises faster internet access, "always-on" connectivity (much like your PC connection at work) and access to richer content and upgraded services such as short films, music videos and faster software downloads. It sounds like a revolution for the internet.

Perhaps it is a revolution, but it won't happen overnight. At £40 per month, the initial price of ADSL at home will still be beyond regular internet users. Pricing will come down as, from mid-2001, other telephone companies are allowed to compete with BT in supplying wholesale ADSL services to companies like Freeserve. Today BT is the sole provider. We need to see the price fall to between £20 and £30 a month before it finds a mass market.

Freeserve's own high-speed internet service, FreeservePlus, has been in development for over a year. We launched a business service in early July, delivering low-cost access to small businesses that can't afford the cost of leased lines. The package includes access to Clearlybusiness.com, a small business portal provided by Freeserve and Barclays Bank. With domestic users, our aim is to build a large audience using this "fat pipe" into the home to experience the internet as it should be: a convenient and fast tool for communication, information and entertainment.

The power of high-speed internet will be realised as content providers old and new start to enhance their sites and content. Since February, Freeserve has been building a showcase portal to demonstrate the capability of ADSL. The portal aggregates some of the best broad band content around from both old and new media. Among others, the portal offers news from ITN, music from Virgin Records, Music Choice, Peoplesound and Darkerthanblue, entertainment from Mentorn Barraclough Carey and Streets Online, and games from Gameplay. This portal will truly come of age when the broadband audience can produce healthy advertising and commerce revenues to support the cost of producing rich content.

This new breed of content provider brings together the strengths of traditional and new media: strong, rich and creative production values combined with a more forward-thinking approach to business models. This will offer CD-quality music playlists with the ability to buy the CD being played. TV programmes will be remixed in to a format that is compatible with the "lean forward" PC experience. Adding advertising within content such as a preroll ad before a music video - the advertising banner may finally be put to rest.

But this evolution doesn't come about without its problems. Copyright issues abound. Cutting up existing TV programmes, digging out short films from the archive or broadcasting music affects the copyright owners. I have been urging producers to hold on to their rights. To reuse or rebroadcast material that has been played out before on the main terrestrial channels usually means that at least some of the rights lie with the broadcaster. A good broadcaster would then want to use this content for its own gain. Even the largest production companies fall foul of the traditional commissioning practices of the broadcasters.

Freeserve has embraced this problem area by working with companies who own their own rights and by trying to educate the new producers about the importance of ownership. However, rights ownership comes with a price. Traditional TV commissioning takes the risk out of content creation: upfront funding of the production by the broadcaster means a small company gets a guaranteed return on its investment. In the new media world, payment from an internet portal is usually a share of revenue earned from advertising and commerce. A shared risk model, then, but the rights stay with the creator.

Our vision would see production companies seeking partnerships and distribution for their properties with new media companies before seeking distribution from broadcasters. This will enable productions to be created and optimised for both the new media and traditional media spaces from the very beginning. The development costs can be spread across multiple distribution platforms enabling the production company to be in a better position to keep its rights.

 Peter Cowley is director of broadband and television at Freeserve. Peter.cowley@freeserve.com
