webTitle: Wild about satire

fields.headline: Wild about satire
fields.standfirst:
It caused AltaVista's managing director in Europe to resign, yet you've probably never heard of it. Richard Adams on the web's answer to Private Eye
Net news
fields.trailText: It caused AltaVista's managing director in Europe to resign, yet you've probably never heard of it. Richard Adams on the web's answer to Private Eye.
fields.body:
It was the hottest new media story of the summer: how AltaVista, one of the biggest names on the internet, was forced into a humiliating retreat and the resignation of its managing director in Europe. The story made headlines in all national newspapers and the BBC's news bulletins. But it was broken in a pokey office above a Turkish restaurant off Regent Street, home to the Register, one of the most significant British internet success stories you've probably never heard of.

The AltaVista saga, which saw the US-based company confess that its much-hyped unlimited internet access offer in the UK was an empty promise, was just the latest and most high-profile example of how web-based news services are setting the mainstream news agenda.

"We have broken a lot of good stories, but most of them have been quite technical, which means a lot to a small set of people," says Linus Birtles, a former computer magazine publisher who was one of the Register's founders and is now its managing director. "But AltaVista, that was the big one."

One thing that sets the Register (www.theregister.co.uk) apart is that it has succeeded in an arena dominated by technology news sites from the US. The other - and the most surprising to those readers who know next to nothing about computers - is that it is wildly satirical, perhaps the closest thing to Private Eye on the internet.

Even its motto, "Biting the hand that feeds IT" puns on the website's no-holds-barred approach to its main subject matter, the information technology sector. Wedged between serious stories about computing giants such as Intel and Microsoft are "exclusive extracts" from Andrew Morton's book about Posh Spice and David Beckham. The site also carries the Register's "tariff" - a guide to how much and in what circumstances its journalists can be bribed. Prices range from £500 to attend a press conference, £15,000 to remove any story, and up to £50,000 to expose the mole within a company who leaked a news story.

"I was a keen Private Eye reader, and that's exactly why I got involved with this," says Birtles, as staff behind him take pictures of each other eating bananas for a parody of Anthea Turner's chocolate bar-sponsored wedding photo. Within minutes the parody was published on the website: "We did manage to get the Costa Rican Banana Marketing Board to rush two of their finest bananas right round and took this exclusive shot for an undisclosed two-figure sum," it crowed. "Proof that, once again, we are unafraid of bad publicity and are, in fact, media whores."

Its mix of hard news and gags enables the Register to take risks on news stories that other organisations wouldn't be able to pull off. The AltaVista story, for example, broke after the site's internet editor, Tim Richardson, ran a mock "lonely hearts" ad looking for users of AltaVista's unmetered internet provider, which the company assured him was up and running.

"It was a hunch, things just didn't add up," says Richardson. "I expected to look stupid, but when I got in the next day there wasn't one reply. And I thought, 'here we go'." Richardson and the Register then hounded AltaVista for two weeks, before the company finally broke down and admitted that the service, which had been heralded by Tony Blair in March when it was first announced, didn't exist. A few days later Andy Mitchell, head of the company's European operation, resigned.

What started as a typical tale of an internet start-up (a meeting in a pub) by Birtles and three computer industry journalists led by 1998 to a specialist news service covering the IT sector. Two years later and the staff has grown to 14 full-time journalists.

The site's scope has also expanded to include all aspects of the new economy. Each month, 10m pages are being read by 750,000 individuals ("unique users", in the trade jargon) according to independent audits, although Birtles says the site has spent "zero pounds" on marketing. That has pushed the Register into the top 20 most popular UK internet sites, and its readership has widened outside the IT sector.

Half of its readers come from the US where the site has a solid following. Not surprisingly, the US is where Birtles is looking for the news service to expand. At the moment the company makes a loss, which is covered by Birtles (who sold cod in Liverpool before launching a computer trade magazine) and another private investor.

"We have revenue from two areas: advertising, and we make money selling our editorial as news feeds to people like Microsoft, Dun & Bradstreet and Trinity Mirror," says Birtles. Content is also being carried on websites such as Yahoo! and the advertisers are a blue-chip bunch: Microsoft, IBM and Intel, a slight surprise given the heavy criticism those companies regularly receive at the hands of the Register.

"Our only downside is that we don't get ads from outside the UK," says Birtles, who has been frustrated in his attempts to tap into the lucrative market in the US.

While the Register looks across the Atlantic, some major competition is coming in the other direction. IT and new economy sites such as ZDnet are already well established in the UK, and there is competition within Europe from VNUnet and the venture capital-backed start-up Silicon.com. But the latest arrival is the business-orientated Industry Standard, the San Francisco-based publishers of thestandard.com website and the highly successful Industry Standard weekly magazine, an unusual example of a print publication based on a website, rather than the other way around.

The Standard has recruited more than 30 journalists for its London office, and this week moves into offices in now-fashionable Southwark in preparation for the European website ( www.thestandardeurope.com) going fully live in early October, and the debut issue of its weekly European edition on October 16. According to Neil Thackary, its chief executive in Europe, the competition on this side of the Atlantic is more likely to be magazines like the Economist than existing new media offerings.

The Standard's target audience includes the dot.com and IT sectors that the Register follows, but it is looking for readers in what Thackary calls the "brick and click" area, established businesses expanding on to the web, as well as the investment, venture capital and consultancy industries that have sprung up to service the online sector. He estimates a potential market of half a million readers in the UK, but optimistically expects the magazine to sell "in the tens of thousands" once established, with a £1.95 news-stand price and around 100 pages an issue.

Mike Parsons, who has returned home to be the Standard's editorial director in London, says there is a difference in tone between the print side and the web side of the publications. "It's more an 'in' audience. It likes gossip," he says. "It's more playful in tone."

Parsons admits to missing the wit of British tabloids while working in the US, but thinks the UK business market is ill-served by mainstream newspapers: "People are used to a very caustic and hostile business press. I think they are not used to a well-informed one."

Meanwhile, above the Turkish restaurant near Regent Street, the Register is busy savaging Abbey National's online banking service for withdrawing its customers' cash cards when they failed to work: "Another internet bank, another bleedin' cock-up." Caustic and hostile it may be, but it did for AltaVista.

"I was a keen Private Eye reader, and that's exactly why I got involved with this," says Birtles, as staff behind him take pictures of each other eating bananas for a parody of Anthea Turner's chocolate bar-sponsored wedding photo. Within minutes the parody was published on the website: "We did manage to get the Costa Rican Banana Marketing Board to rush two of their finest bananas right round and took this exclusive shot for an undisclosed two-figure sum," it crowed. "Proof that, once again, we are unafraid of bad publicity and are, in fact, media whores." Its mix of hard news and gags enables the Register to take risks on news stories that other organisations wouldn't be able to pull off. The AltaVista story, for example, broke after the site's internet editor, Tim Richardson, ran a mock "lonely hearts" ad looking for users of AltaVista's unmetered internet provider, which the company assured him was up and running. "It was a hunch, things just didn't add up," says Richardson. "I expected to look stupid, but when I got in the next day there wasn't one reply. And I thought, 'here we go'." Richardson and the Register then hounded AltaVista for two weeks, before the company finally broke down and admitted that the service, which had been heralded by Tony Blair in March when it was first announced, didn't exist. A few days later Andy Mitchell, head of the company's European operation, resigned. What started as a typical tale of an internet start-up (a meeting in a pub) by Birtles and three computer industry journalists led by 1998 to a specialist news service covering the IT sector. Two years later and the staff has grown to 14 full-time journalists. The site's scope has also expanded to include all aspects of the new economy. Each month, 10m pages are being read by 750,000 individuals ("unique users", in the trade jargon) according to independent audits, although Birtles says the site has spent "zero pounds" on marketing. That has pushed the Register into the top 20 most popular UK internet sites, and its readership has widened outside the IT sector. Half of its readers come from the US where the site has a solid following. Not surprisingly, the US is where Birtles is looking for the news service to expand. At the moment the company makes a loss, which is covered by Birtles (who sold cod in Liverpool before launching a computer trade magazine) and another private investor. "We have revenue from two areas: advertising, and we make money selling our editorial as news feeds to people like Microsoft, Dun & Bradstreet and Trinity Mirror," says Birtles. Content is also being carried on websites such as Yahoo! and the advertisers are a blue-chip bunch: Microsoft, IBM and Intel, a slight surprise given the heavy criticism those companies regularly receive at the hands of the Register. "Our only downside is that we don't get ads from outside the UK," says Birtles, who has been frustrated in his attempts to tap into the lucrative market in the US. While the Register looks across the Atlantic, some major competition is coming in the other direction. IT and new economy sites such as ZDnet are already well established in the UK, and there is competition within Europe from VNUnet and the venture capital-backed start-up Silicon.com. But the latest arrival is the business-orientated Industry Standard, the San Francisco-based publishers of thestandard.com website and the highly successful Industry Standard weekly magazine, an unusual example of a print publication based on a website, rather than the other way around. The Standard has recruited more than 30 journalists for its London office, and this week moves into offices in now-fashionable Southwark in preparation for the European website ( www.thestandardeurope.com) going fully live in early October, and the debut issue of its weekly European edition on October 16. According to Neil Thackary, its chief executive in Europe, the competition on this side of the Atlantic is more likely to be magazines like the Economist than existing new media offerings. The Standard's target audience includes the dot.com and IT sectors that the Register follows, but it is looking for readers in what Thackary calls the "brick and click" area, established businesses expanding on to the web, as well as the investment, venture capital and consultancy industries that have sprung up to service the online sector. He estimates a potential market of half a million readers in the UK, but optimistically expects the magazine to sell "in the tens of thousands" once established, with a £1.95 news-stand price and around 100 pages an issue. Mike Parsons, who has returned home to be the Standard's editorial director in London, says there is a difference in tone between the print side and the web side of the publications. "It's more an 'in' audience. It likes gossip," he says. "It's more playful in tone." Parsons admits to missing the wit of British tabloids while working in the US, but thinks the UK business market is ill-served by mainstream newspapers: "People are used to a very caustic and hostile business press. I think they are not used to a well-informed one." Meanwhile, above the Turkish restaurant near Regent Street, the Register is busy savaging Abbey National's online banking service for withdrawing its customers' cash cards when they failed to work: "Another internet bank, another bleedin' cock-up." Caustic and hostile it may be, but it did for AltaVista.

webTitle: Need to know

fields.headline: Need to know
fields.standfirst: Paul Edney
fields.trailText: Paul Edney
fields.body:
Age:
29.

Who is he?
MD of Keekaboo Cards Ltd, launching September 7. Previously worked as account director in advertising, sales promotion and live events.

What's the clever idea?
"A completely new way of advertising on the web and bringing the virtual to the real. Keekaboo enables people to send real postcards via the internet for free. It should result in thousands of cards being sent each day, thousands of senders and recipients potentially exposed to each card design - an attractive proposition for any advertiser wishing to sponsor cards with their choice of image on the front and message on the back. Advertisers have been hankering after a more accountable, versatile way to reach their target audience on the internet, and the benefits are threefold - accountability, control and versatility. All card senders are encouraged to visit the advertiser's site through online links, all recipients receive a piece of branded direct mail which has been personally endorsed by a friend, and all advertisers only pay for cards that are sent. Keekaboo is an online traffic driver combined with an offline brand builder all in one postcard. In a pilot, Keekaboo cards got a 9% response. Direct marketing response rates are usually between 2 and 5%."

What's the thinking behind it?
"The idea behind Keekaboo came up when Patrick van Zandvoort, the Dutch founder of the company, wanted to send a birthday card to his mother. He searched the web for a service which would allow him to write and send a real card online but only found virtual card sites. He saw the opportunity to launch a web service specialising in personalised cards chosen and sent online, but which arrive through the post."

How does it work?
"Users come to the site www.keekaboo.com. There they can choose a postcard, write a message, and address the card to the home/business address of the recipient (not the email address). The information is sent digitally to a printer who prints the card and posts it. The postman then delivers the card to the recipient. So the beauty is that it turns a virtual message into a real card, for free."

Possible shortcomings?
"Free postcards and postage may not appeal to some consumers. Advertisers may not see the benefit of a medium which can reach both an off and online audience with one hit."

What's next?
"Expansion outside of the UK, Spain and Netherlands into other international markets. Development for other platforms, including Wap."

webTitle: Off the Record

fields.headline: Off the Record
fields.standfirst: Newspapers are fighting tooth and nail to boost circulation in Scotland so, as Martin Clarke departs from the editor's chair at the Daily Record,  Roy Greenslade says he is best seen as a casualty of war
fields.trailText: Newspapers are fighting tooth and nail to boost circulation in Scotland so, as Martin Clarke departs from the editor's chair at the Daily Record, Roy Greenslade says he is best seen as a casualty of war
fields.body:
Scotland today is the Fleet Street of the 30s. Newspapers are engaged in a vicious circulation war, with groups using every possible device to win readers. The weapons are commercial - price-cutting gimmicks, massive "sampling" giveaways and promotional lures - but the pressure on editors to produce saleable papers, to ensure that the casual buyers stay, is immense.

It is possible, therefore, to put Martin Clarke's departure as editor of the Daily Record in this context. That would suggest that he is just another casualty in the debilitating round of journalistic blood-letting.

Then again, Clarke stands out from the crowd. There can be little doubt that he was monstrously behaved, exhibiting the man-management skills of a galley-master on a Greek trireme.

There are legions of stories about his ranting and raving in the office, his rudeness to subordinates and his lack of respect for his superiors. It is also obvious that he alienated his paper's traditional political allies in the Labour party. In his enthusiasm to end the so-called cosy relationship with the party hierarchy, he went too far.

Not only did he upset the party, it is highly likely that he annoyed habitual Labour voters among his readership, too. Similarly, his controversial campaign against the repeal of Clause 28 may well have played well with older buyers but is thought to have bemused, and even incensed, younger people.

Then there is the not unimportant matter of circulation. The Daily Record has sold fewer and fewer copies since Clarke arrived in April 1998 when it was selling 671,000. By April this year (the fairest of comparisons) it had fallen to 618,000, a drop of almost 8%.

But that does not give anything like the whole picture. The Record has enjoyed - how shall I put this tactfully? - an oddly high level of sales in Spain. It has also been reliant on increasing numbers of bulk giveaways.

As if that wasn't bad enough, rival circulation managers claim the paper's Scots-only sale dipped as low as 516,000 last week. Even if that's an exaggeration, and Trinity-Mirror argue that its monthly year-on-year sale will show a slight rise when the next officially audited figures are published, the sales situation is dire.

Not that Clarke can be held entirely responsible for that. The Record held sway in Scotland for a couple of generations as its main competitors retreated south of the border. For years, the Daily Express and Daily Mail virtually abandoned Scotland. Even the Sun was slow to make its mark there.

But once the whole newspaper market began to slide in the early 90s, managements desperate to boost circulation showed a renewed interest in Scotland, turning it into the most competitive newspaper environment of modern times. In most of the larger cities, there are at least 15 daily morning titles on the news-stands, with a 16th, the Swedish-owned Business am, about to be launched in three weeks' time. The populous Glasgow-Edinburgh central region is also served by a free Metro, which has a distribution of 120,000 copies.

To be frank, in a country of 5.1m, the market is overheated. Even some Scottish editors agree with me that there are too many titles chasing too few readers, not to mention the problems of too few good journalists to staff the papers, and too few good stories to publish.

The Scots don't seem to mind. With almost every title slashing its cover price, they can cherry-pick the cheapest available paper. The latest Daily Express voucher mail shot is offering one issue a week for just 1p.

In such a climate, with buyers able to judge value for money every day, it isn't hard to see why a 20p Scotsman and a 20p Times might be preferred over a 48p Herald. It is surely creditable that the Herald has managed to keep a 95,000 sale so far, but price-cutting isn't any longer a short-term weapon. It is a war of attrition and it is difficult to forecast the outcome.

Among the red-tops, the Daily Record has found it harder to retain reader loyalty for a paper selling at 32p against a cheaper Mirror and a Sun which slips in 15p issues on a weekly basis. Price-cutting also helped the Daily Mail to build a healthy sale before it reverted to its proper cover price.

The result has seen the Sun climb to an astonishing 400,000, double its sale three years ago, and the Mirror to 60,000 from almost zero. With the Mail at 120,000 and rising, and the Express at almost 90,000, the Daily Record has borne the brunt of the onslaught.

Not surprisingly, Clarke's friends contend that his owners have failed to provide him with the resources to fight back, implying that Trinity-Mirror's treatment of the Record as a regional rather than national title inhibits proper investment. They claim the lack of management understanding explains why he was prone to lose his temper so often.

A Trinity-Mirror source scoffed at any such suggestion. "It sounds," he said witheringly, "like the squeal of the last little piggy down the ramp into the abattoir."

But one of Clarke's friends countered: "In a war like the one we have here it makes no sense to remove the man recognised as the toughest, meanest general from the battlefield."

That's probably the reason Clarke was shocked when Trinity-Mirror's chief executive Philip Graf fired him at a tense meeting in Canary Wharf. The arrogant and abrasive Clarke simply had no inkling he was for the chop.

So can the new editor, Peter Cox, who is moving from the Record's stable-mate, the Sunday Mail, expect to do better? He is a more amenable, amiable character. Even when I criticised him harshly for one of his stories, he didn't lose his sense of humour and was prepared to fight his corner without rancour.

His paper has been unimpressive, and has also shed some readers, but it has remained coherent - the Record, meanwhile, has been erratic: sensational one minute and overly serious and dull the next.

Cox did pursue a much more sympathetic line over Clause 28 and, after an initial hiccup, has offered tacit support to the Labour administration of Scottish first minister Donald Dewar. It was surely significant that his first Daily Record front page, on Friday, contained the pro-Dewar headline, "Well Don!"

webTitle: Let's lose the tea leaves

fields.headline: Let's lose the tea leaves
fields.standfirst: Audience figures for radio stations are calculated using people who crouch before their sets and fill in a diary of what they are listening to. In a digital age, says  Kelvin MacKenzie, it doesn't add up
fields.trailText: Audience figures for radio stations are calculated using people who crouch before their sets and fill in a diary of what they are listening to. In a digital age, says Kelvin MacKenzie, it doesn't add up
fields.body:
Imagine the scene. An old dear sits in her favourite armchair putting down the time - by the half hour - that she listened to various radio stations over the day. Did I listen to Radio 2 between 10.30 and 11.00? Or was it Capital? Or was it Virgin? No, that was 11.30-12.00. This absurd charade is carried out by 100,000 people every year in order to put together the ratings for all Britain's 350 radio stations.

It's called Rajar, but I believe that its days are numbered. In the newspaper business you can be sure the sales figures are right because they are based on the amount of money taken against the number sent out to newsagents minus the returns. Television is done technologically with a box over the set which records all given viewing. But radio is based on the widely discredited diary system where somebody has to try and record exactly what they listened to that hour, that day or that week. What astounds me the most is that the radio business is not up in arms seeking a change.

It's not as if there are no alternatives. Since the early 80s, a number of companies have been developing systems that measure radio audiences using electronic meters worn by survey participants. These meters pick up radio signals and accurately record who listened to what and when. Accurate, reliable, no guesswork and no reliance on memory.

Not only are meters accurate, but they can deliver up-to-date information that should be the norm for the radio industry. With the current diary system, national stations receive their results on a quarterly basis. Because of this time lag, some figures for the quarter are almost five months old. With meters, we could receive results at worst after a week and at best overnight.

Surprisingly, the companies developing meters have received little or no support from the radio industry in the UK.

Perhaps if we were to examine the effect that moving from a diary system to electronic meters has on listening figures, then we might get an insight into the reticence of the industry to force what seems an irresistible change.

A clue to this effect can be found in the US television industry in the 80s, where the federal communications commission insisted on a certain number of markets converting from diaries to meters every year. The major networks fought tooth and nail to slow down the changeover.

The reason was simple: every time the switchover was made, the networks lost millions of dollars in advertising revenue. This was because the diary system worked for the networks. Diaries rely on people's recall, so the networks scored inaccurately high ratings while the smaller cable stations suffered. Once meters accurately recorded what people were actually watching, the result was always the same: networks lost viewers and cable gained.

Already, one company actively involved in introducing a radio metering system in the UK acknowledges that the effect would be the same with the radio audience figures. Diaries favour established radio stations or stations with large marketing budgets as they are more easily recalled; meters reflect the true picture... so that smaller, lower-profile stations get a fairer share.

Let me declare an interest. (Am I not allowed an interest?) Private research that we did at TalkSport shows that when we broadcast live and exclusive coverage of the Test series in South Africa, for every listener who said correctly that they heard the cricket on TalkSport, two other listeners were convinced they heard our coverage on either Radio 4 or 5 Live. A diary would have reflected the listener's error while a meter would have given us the correct result.

So we begin to understand why the enthusiasm for radio metering is lukewarm among those radio stations enjoying great ratings with diaries... best typified by the old joke about John Major activists chanting: "What do we want? Gradual change! When do we want it? In due course!"

One victim of this attitude is the American audience research company Arbitron, which has spent millions in a test operation for its portable people meter (PPM) system in Manchester. From 1998 until early this year, 300 meters had been distributed to Mancunians for testing.

The meters - worn like a bleeper - detect inaudible codes that broadcasters embed in the audio using encoders provided by Arbitron. At the end of the day, the meter-wearer places the meter onto a base station that recharges and sends the collected codes to Arbitron for tabulation.

The problem Arbitron faced was that its system required the cooperation of all broadcasters in order to work. Talk Radio, as it was then - in common with all other commercial broadcasters, as well as the BBC local station GMR - agreed to encode its broadcasts.

After a week, however, all the BBC's national stations pulled out. The reason they cited was that they received complaints of a buzz from Radio 3 listeners. No other stations taking part in the test experienced the same problem. Nevertheless, Arbitron spent more than two years trying to persuade the BBC to rejoin the test - but without success.

Consequently, the Arbitron test was flawed as it did not measure all radio listening. The company has now abandoned Manchester and decided to complete its testing in Philadelphia, where one has to assume the atmosphere is more favourable to an accurate system of measuring ratings.

There is, however, another metering system that is being developed that does not require the cooperation of all broadcasters. A Swiss company, SRG SSR, has developed a digital wristwatch, Radiocontrol, with a built-in microphone which picks up all audio that the wearer is listening to.

SRG SSR matches the wristwatch audio with the radio stations' audio to find out what the survey participant was listening to. The company began distributing the watches in July and expects testing to be complete by the end of this year. The system, which will be used by the Swiss Broadcasting Corporation, should be fully operational from January 2001, with published results in the spring.

Interestingly, when we spoke to Manuel Dahler, head of radio research at SRG SSR, he told us that TalkSport's inquiry was the first sign of interest from the radio industry in the UK.

Yet this resistance to change is impossible to sustain. Not only is it wrong-headed to cling to a system that's akin to reading tea leaves, but the diary system is incapable of coping with the changes in the radio industry, not least the explosion in Manchester.

The perceived radio industry wisdom that people listen to only two radio stations is nonsense. It is born out of the frailties of the diary system. The increase in the number of stations people can tune into has made the diary system notoriously simplistic - and that is before the changeover to digital adds more stations into the market.

Common sense tells us that people in Britain listen to more radio stations than ever. It's just that no one is measuring their listening accurately. That is bad news for advertisers, who are paying top dollar for inflated ratings created by an out-of-date, flawed system. So it is in the advertisers' interests - if not some of my commercial rivals' and certainly not the BBC's - to join me in my efforts to place the implementation of a metering system in the UK on the front burner.

Only when meters measure radio ratings will everyone in this multi-million pound industry get their money's worth. That could be good news for many, bad news for some - but whatever the impact, at least it would be accurate.

 Kelvin MacKenzie is chairman and chief executive of the Wireless Group

The problem Arbitron faced was that its system required the cooperation of all broadcasters in order to work. Talk Radio, as it was then - in common with all other commercial broadcasters, as well as the BBC local station GMR - agreed to encode its broadcasts. After a week, however, all the BBC's national stations pulled out. The reason they cited was that they received complaints of a buzz from Radio 3 listeners. No other stations taking part in the test experienced the same problem. Nevertheless, Arbitron spent more than two years trying to persuade the BBC to rejoin the test - but without success. Consequently, the Arbitron test was flawed as it did not measure all radio listening. The company has now abandoned Manchester and decided to complete its testing in Philadelphia, where one has to assume the atmosphere is more favourable to an accurate system of measuring ratings. There is, however, another metering system that is being developed that does not require the cooperation of all broadcasters. A Swiss company, SRG SSR, has developed a digital wristwatch, Radiocontrol, with a built-in microphone which picks up all audio that the wearer is listening to. SRG SSR matches the wristwatch audio with the radio stations' audio to find out what the survey participant was listening to. The company began distributing the watches in July and expects testing to be complete by the end of this year. The system, which will be used by the Swiss Broadcasting Corporation, should be fully operational from January 2001, with published results in the spring. Interestingly, when we spoke to Manuel Dahler, head of radio research at SRG SSR, he told us that TalkSport's inquiry was the first sign of interest from the radio industry in the UK. Yet this resistance to change is impossible to sustain. Not only is it wrong-headed to cling to a system that's akin to reading tea leaves, but the diary system is incapable of coping with the changes in the radio industry, not least the explosion in Manchester. The perceived radio industry wisdom that people listen to only two radio stations is nonsense. It is born out of the frailties of the diary system. The increase in the number of stations people can tune into has made the diary system notoriously simplistic - and that is before the changeover to digital adds more stations into the market. Common sense tells us that people in Britain listen to more radio stations than ever. It's just that no one is measuring their listening accurately. That is bad news for advertisers, who are paying top dollar for inflated ratings created by an out-of-date, flawed system. So it is in the advertisers' interests - if not some of my commercial rivals' and certainly not the BBC's - to join me in my efforts to place the implementation of a metering system in the UK on the front burner. Only when meters measure radio ratings will everyone in this multi-million pound industry get their money's worth. That could be good news for many, bad news for some - but whatever the impact, at least it would be accurate.  Kelvin MacKenzie is chairman and chief executive of the Wireless Group

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: * A tricky dilemma for Scotsman staff on Friday night. Andrew Neil organised a lavish launch party to celebrate the commencement of Scotsman.com at the Corinthian - a suitably flash venue off St George's Square in Glasgow. If only the paper's revolving doors policy wasn't continuing at such a pace that the function room next door was hired out by five (count 'em) ex-Scotsman hacks for their joint leaving do. Our man in a kilt was all of a flutter trying to decide which party to go to (and of course watching out for those flitting between the two).
fields.body:
* A tricky dilemma for Scotsman staff on Friday night. Andrew Neil organised a lavish launch party to celebrate the commencement of Scotsman.com at the Corinthian - a suitably flash venue off St George's Square in Glasgow. If only the paper's revolving doors policy wasn't continuing at such a pace that the function room next door was hired out by five (count 'em) ex-Scotsman hacks for their joint leaving do. Our man in a kilt was all of a flutter trying to decide which party to go to (and of course watching out for those flitting between the two).

*The Emapification of Wagadon continues, with the appointment of veteran Mark Ellen to replace Greg Williams as editor of Arena. No word yet on Williams' next move, though one Emap source said he was being promoted - expect an announcement in a couple of weeks. Seems like Emap is following the IPC model of pulling in new blood to refresh ailing men's titles. Whether Ellen - who has edited or overseen everything from Q to heat - or IPC's similarly experienced Mike Soutar count as fresh young blood is another matter.

*The BBC needs to get its skates on with its new children's services: Disney's Paul Robinson was noted at Edinburgh crowing that the Beeb's offerings will end up behind three Nickelodeons, three Cartoon Networks, two Fox Kids, one Trouble, and four Disney services - at numbers 620 and 621 on the EPG. Worse, ITV has still not released Nigel Pickard, the CITV controller behind the fantastic SMTV:Live who has been poached to head up the BBC's children's output. So the relaunch of flagship kids' show Live & Kicking will take place in Pickard's absence. We hear the new presenter line-up relies heavily on former Blue Peter presenters . . . so not much new there then.

*Of all the reasons the diary can think of for Piers Morgan to have had his collar felt this year, interfering with the post is not the one we'd have put our cash on. After assisting the serious crime squad with inquiries into the theft of letters sent by Diana, Princess of Wales to James Hewitt - as exclusively revealed by the Mirror on Friday - Morgan is now proudly declaring himself the Norman Stanley Fletcher of British journalism.

In a gesture of support for the habitual alleged criminal, the diary is opening a book on which charge Morgan will end up in the slammer over by Christmas. Profits to the bail fund. Spread betting available, printable suggestions welcome but for starters we offer: crimes against bespoke tailoring (evens); exposing himself in a public place (2-1); copping a feel from Cherie Booth at the Labour party conference (5-1); inciting defenceless Women in Journalism to have sex with David Yelland with the lights on (40-1).

webTitle: Media: Was Clarke a pugnacious and unremitting editor?

fields.headline: 'I have watched him roar'
fields.standfirst: Was Clarke a pugnacious and unremitting editor?  Tim Luckhurst  offers a first-hand appreciation
fields.trailText: Was Clarke a pugnacious and unremitting editor? Tim Luckhurst offers a first-hand appreciation
fields.body:
All copy was "mince" until Martin had improved it. All photographs were "shit" until Martin had cropped them. All page designs were a "fucking disgrace" until Martin had drawn them himself. Reporters were a waste of space, photographers were "monkeys" and sub-editors were so inconsequential that Martin deliberately forgot their names. There was no job at the Scotsman that Martin could not do better than the person he employed to do it.

Clarke believed this. He arrived at the Scotsman accustomed to the driven world of London tabloids and brought his assumptions with him. Clarke thinks that being a journalist is fun. He thinks it is a privilege. So he assumes that every reporter pulls out all the stops every day simply in order to stay ahead of the pack barking at his heels. That's what he did to get the jobs he got when he was young. He worked like a Stakhanovite (though in the absurd way that he always seeks to hide his own intellect, Clarke would deny knowing who Stakhanov was).

And, like many ostensibly ruthless bosses, Clarke was loyal to those who lived up to his expectations. That didn't mean being perfect. It meant trying. The image Clarke deliberately cultivated at every newspaper he ran - evil, certain, harder than a rivet - was all performance. Clarke would spend hours nurturing a young reporter who had done his best. He is a good teacher. He writes fast and incisively. He sees the point while others are still struggling to grasp the context.

When colleagues were exhausted, Clarke could be compassionate. "Take a week off," he told me. "Relax. Don't think about this place. You've earned it." When I protested that I hadn't finished the leader, he just shrugged and said: "I'll handle it." He never told colleagues that he had done so. Clarke had to behave like a tabloid brute. He hid his subtlety like an embarrassing illness.

The stories of Clarke screaming at staff are true. I have watched him roar crude expletives into the face of a terrified reporter. I have seen adults cry after one of his cruel humiliations. His finger would jab inches from the victim's face. He stood close enough to overpower with the stench of stale cigarettes and fried breakfast (Clarke runs on heavy fuel - most days began with curt instructions to his secretary to get a fry-up and 60 Silk Cut).

Female colleagues found him particularly hard to take. I remember a priceless moment at the Scotsman's news conference. Clarke: "This schedule is pure shit. You're supposed to be working, not gossiping. Where's the splash? What the fuck am I going to put on the front page? You've got 10 minutes. Go and find some fucking stories."

Female assistant news editor: "That's yesterday's schedule, Martin. You liked it at the time."

Clarke is a flawed character. He never needs alcohol or anything stronger to get his adrenaline flowing. He could work for 18 hours after just four hours sleep because he loves the whole game. Clarke without a newspaper to edit is a lost soul. He will find it hard to grasp that an ex-editor has no influence.

So how did these ingredients fail at the Scotsman and the Record? For all the true stories about tantrums, Clarke is not reviled by good journalists. His problem is a siege mentality which increasingly prevented him distinguishing between good and bad advice.

Scottish journalism is not cutting-edge. For years the big Scottish newspapers have been content with soft, consensual words and a thin parochial agenda. Clarke came with the conviction that if Scotland wanted national status it should have national journalism too. And that meant no more cosy deals whereby political correspondents were close friends of the politicians he wanted them to crucify.

To Clarke politicians are "cunts". It's a word he uses with passionate abandon. He has a primitive democratic instinct which assumes that politicians are all liars and that newspapers exist to expose their mendacity.

Clarke's demonic moral-majoritarianism was his biggest mistake. He did it to annoy. The Record's obscene campaign against repeal of Clause 28 was not about morality. Clarke is not prejudiced. He just found the performance of the Scottish executive so pathetic that he would do anything to infuriate the first minister.

Clarke thought he could change a culture of complacency by force of character alone. Instead of compromising when he must have known the effort was crippling him, he just became more driven, more deliberately vile and more obsessive. That's how most will remember him. I prefer to recall the razor-sharp mind and deep background knowledge. He will succeed when he allows the sophistication he has buried beneath his armour to return to the surface.

Clarke was curiously good for Scottish journalism. He set standards. They were too often nasty and harsh - Clarke's mistakes became more spectacular as his career failed - but things will never be as complacent as they were before his arrival. Martin should team up with that other great iconoclast, Andrew Neil. Between them they could run a very good title - but probably not in Scotland.

 Tim Luckhurst is a former editor of the Scotsman. In 1997, he was assistant editor under Martin Clarke.

webTitle: A-levels too easy, says Woodhead

fields.headline: A-levels too easy, says Woodhead
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A-levels should be made more difficult and preserved for the minority of students, according to the chief inspector of schools in England, Chris Woodhead.
fields.body:
A-levels should be made more difficult and preserved for the minority of students, according to the chief inspector of schools in England, Chris Woodhead.

In an interview with the Guardian, Mr Woodhead stokes the simmering row over examination standards by calling for a new investigation into "grade inflation".

The head of Ofsted, the schools inspectorate, said "nobody seems to know" whether exam standards have fallen since GCSEs were introduced.

"We musn't ignore this, we musn't sweep it under the carpet. There is a danger that we get ourselves to a point where it's impossible to speak out because everybody wants to believe that things are getting better," said Mr Woodhead.

"The teachers obviously do, the government obviously does, and the exam boards have got a vested interest. You can see how the consensus emerges and anybody who dares to ask any questions is seen as a dissident, a 'traditionalist' used in a very pejorative way. But that is unhealthy because the currency has to be maintained if we are to have the education system we must have for the new century and new millennium."

He said the Department for Education and Employment, and the exams watchdog, the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority (QCA), "really ought to focus on this energetically and see if we cannot come to clearer judgments as to what is happening".

He had recorded improvements in teaching in schools over the last six years in his annual report. "Having said that I think we do need to be eternally vigilant... If we have a situation, and apparently we do, where 40% of 11-year-olds make either losses or no gains in their first three years at secondary school, it obviously raises a question about the 16-plus examinations and how do you tally those two truths."

His intervention will irritate ministers, the teaching unions and the examination boards who argue that exam standards are being maintained. But Ruth Lea, policy director at the Institute of Directors, last month condemned record A-level passes as "farcical".

Mr Woodhead said an inquiry, Standards Over Time, held four years ago, by Ofsted and the Schools Curriculum and Assessment Authority, QCA's predecessor, had been wrongly interpreted to have "whitewashed" exam standards. The inquiry had been hampered because there were no exam scripts available from a decade or two decades before which could be compared, he said.

The QCA does now keep examination scripts. A spokesman said: "There's no evidence that standards have fallen in the exams that we've looked at." Mr Woodhead said the new emphasis on coursework and modular exams posed difficult questions. "For better or worse these changes in the identity of the exam are having an impact," Mr Woodhead said.

"We cannot have a situation where young people are kept for longer and longer at school, and at greater and greater public expense, but who end up in fact knowing no more than people in the past did who left school younger. It is very important that we look very hard at what is happening, and QCA in the lead really take that as a major responsibility."

He added: "We need A-levels that are as academically rigorous as they have ever been. Indeed I would like them to be more academically rigorous. As standards rise in schools then we ought, in our public examinations, to be looking to raise the level of demand at all levels as well.

"Let's preserve A-levels that really do stretch the intellectually most able but let's recognise that such qualifications are only for a minority. And let's have a range of other qualifications post-16 that will interest, motivate, benefit the other students who are not equipped to study A-levels."

More than 270,000 people received A-level results last month, a rise on the year before, even though the number of 18-year-olds fell.

Mr Woodhead said: "We should raise our aspirations as to what an A involves, a B involves, a C involves. If kids are leaving primary school better equipped to deal with secondary school, brighter, more able to deal with the national curriculum, then for me it follows if you are interested in raising standards we've got to raise our expectations.

"It's very difficult for a government to do because the government wants to demonstrate improved examination results... The currency of the examination grade is vitally important in terms of raising standards."

Mr Woodhead said less academically able students should be advised to take vocational qualifications. Nearly 90% of candidates achieved A-E grades at A-level this year. He said: "An examination which doesn't involve failure is a very peculiar examination... for me failure isn't a dirty word at all. An education system must involve failure. Life involves failure."

webTitle: Laura Spence lays no blame on Oxford

fields.headline: Laura Spence lays no blame on Oxford
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Laura Spence, the Tyneside comprehensive student whose rejection by Oxford University became a national cause célèbre, yesterday said she could "see the logic" in the university's argument.
fields.body:
Laura Spence, the Tyneside comprehensive student whose rejection by Oxford University became a national cause célèbre, yesterday said she could "see the logic" in the university's argument.

In her first public comment on the affair, Miss Spence is more conciliatory towards Magdalen College, Oxford, which turned her down for a place to read medicine, than were her headteacher, Paul Kelley, and the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

Miss Spence is going instead to Harvard University in Massachusetts to read biochemistry. Yesterday the first of a series of self-penned "letters" about her student life appeared in the Mail on Sunday.

Mr Kelley, head at Monkseaton school, Whitley Bay, and Mr Brown lambasted the Oxford admissions procedure as elitist when she was rejected before she got her A-level results, which turned out to be five As.

"To be honest, I never disputed my Oxford rejection," Miss Spence wrote. "I simply got on with life. My position in the centre of the row was difficult. I could see the logic in both sides of the argument. Optimising the egalitarianism of admissions procedures is a complex problem and not one that is experienced only by universities. I thought that commenting would have protracted the debate, so I tried to channel my energies into revision." But "in retrospect I think it may have been worthwhile to discuss openly a topic which was so close to the hearts of many".

Choosing Harvard was one of "the hardest decisions I have ever had to take". She had been accepted by Newcastle, Nottingham and Edinburgh. Ultimately the choice was between Harvard and Newcastle. "At Newcastle I could read medicine. At Harvard I would be required to pursue a broader course of study. This would allow many possible career options but would mean an extra two years if I wanted to become a doctor."

She spoke of her joy on getting her results: "When I rang home and told my mum that I had not only got five As, but received a letter from the examinations board saying I had achieved one of the five best geography results in the country, I could tell she was pleased."

 Officials embroiled in the fiasco in which thousands of Scottish pupils received incorrect or inaccurate exam results last night defended a visit by Omani education ministry officials intended to show off Scottish exam expertise.

A spokesman for the Scottish qualifications authority said the Omanis would be focusing on exam setting rather than results processing.

In her first public comment on the affair, Miss Spence is more conciliatory towards Magdalen College, Oxford, which turned her down for a place to read medicine, than were her headteacher, Paul Kelley, and the chancellor, Gordon Brown. Miss Spence is going instead to Harvard University in Massachusetts to read biochemistry. Yesterday the first of a series of self-penned "letters" about her student life appeared in the Mail on Sunday. Mr Kelley, head at Monkseaton school, Whitley Bay, and Mr Brown lambasted the Oxford admissions procedure as elitist when she was rejected before she got her A-level results, which turned out to be five As. "To be honest, I never disputed my Oxford rejection," Miss Spence wrote. "I simply got on with life. My position in the centre of the row was difficult. I could see the logic in both sides of the argument. Optimising the egalitarianism of admissions procedures is a complex problem and not one that is experienced only by universities. I thought that commenting would have protracted the debate, so I tried to channel my energies into revision." But "in retrospect I think it may have been worthwhile to discuss openly a topic which was so close to the hearts of many". Choosing Harvard was one of "the hardest decisions I have ever had to take". She had been accepted by Newcastle, Nottingham and Edinburgh. Ultimately the choice was between Harvard and Newcastle. "At Newcastle I could read medicine. At Harvard I would be required to pursue a broader course of study. This would allow many possible career options but would mean an extra two years if I wanted to become a doctor." She spoke of her joy on getting her results: "When I rang home and told my mum that I had not only got five As, but received a letter from the examinations board saying I had achieved one of the five best geography results in the country, I could tell she was pleased."  Officials embroiled in the fiasco in which thousands of Scottish pupils received incorrect or inaccurate exam results last night defended a visit by Omani education ministry officials intended to show off Scottish exam expertise. A spokesman for the Scottish qualifications authority said the Omanis would be focusing on exam setting rather than results processing.

webTitle: Brunswick buys SRU

fields.headline: York sells SRU to Brunswick
fields.trailText: Peter York, the social commentator who in the 1980s famously coined the term "Sloane Ranger", has sold research consultancy SRU to City PR firm Brunswick.
fields.body:
Peter York, the social commentator who in the 1980s famously coined the term "Sloane Ranger", has sold research consultancy SRU to City PR firm Brunswick.

York, who for business purposes prefers to be called Peter Wallis, founded SRU in 1973 together with Lord Stevenson, now chairman of Halifax and Pearson. It provides heavyweight research to a number of corporate clients, including EMI, Marks & Spencer and WHSmith.

Brunswick, which is privately owned and run by founder and senior partner Alan Parker, has for some time been seeking to add research to its marketing advice services. It is thought to have attempted to build the business organically before opting to buy an established research firm.

Brunswick is one of the biggest financial PR agencies in London and claims to advise more FTSE 100 companies than any of its rivals.

York's writing credits include 1980s classic The Sloane Ranger's Handbook and Style Wars, a how-to guide to style writing.

SRU, which has just 14 staff, will retain its offices in Clerkenwell.

The financial terms of the deal are being kept under wraps.

webTitle: Fiji court upholds coup charges

fields.headline: Fiji court upholds coup charges
fields.trailText: The Fijian high court today prevented a magistrate from dropping treason charges levelled against a coup leader and 20 of his supporters.
fields.body:
The Fijian high court today prevented a magistrate from dropping treason charges levelled against a coup leader and 20 of his supporters.

In a letter read aloud at a hearing to chief magistrate Sailesi Temo, the high court said magistrates had no power to rule on the validity of the amnesty granted to George Speight as part of a July deal that ended his 56-day hostage stand-off at Fiji's parliament.

Defense lawyers had last week asked Temo to throw out the charges against Speight based on the terms of the amnesty. He faces a life sentence if convicted.

But prosecutors claim Speight breached the terms of the deal by not handing over all the weapons stolen from the army for the coup. They also claim the military agreed to it under duress, while Speight was holding hostages.

The High Court will discuss the amnesty on September 15. Speight and followers are to remain in custody.

Speight was arrested on July 26, just days after releasing the last of the hostages seized after storming Parliament on May 19.

A failed businessman, Speight launched the coup in the name of indigenous Fijians, who he claimed have been marginalized by Fijians of Indian descent.

Ethnic Indians make up 44% of the country's 814,000 population. The democratically elected government toppled in the coup was Fiji's first led by an ethnic Indian.

Fiji is currently ruled by an interim government established by the military. Prime minister Laisenia Qarase has said his administration will work to redraw Fiji's constitution to guarantee that indigenous Fijians, who make up 51% of the population, hold top political posts.

Qarase says he hopes to hold fresh elections in two years.

webTitle: Stepanovs, Stepping up, Stepping down

fields.headline: Stepanovs, Stepping up, Stepping down
fields.trailText: BODY BEAUTIFUL
fields.body:
BODY BEAUTIFUL

Imagine, Arsenal fans, that you were Dr Frankenstein. Imagine you had enough demonic power - and, of course, electricity - to create your perfect central defender. Obviously he would be big, strong and able to shoot his hand up for offside even in his sleep. That much goes without saying. And a penchant for near-post flick-ons and the West End play 'Art' would be nice too. Hang on a minute though, that's a perfect synthesis of Tony Adams and Steve Bould - and surely that's impossible!

Well think again, because that defender already exists. His name is Igors Stepanovs, he's a Latvian international and - control yourself you Gooners - he's signed for Arsenal. "Igors can definitely do a job in the Premiership. He is in the same mould as Tony Adams, which is why he will fit in so well at the Arsenal," said Graham Johnson, Latvia's English coach (who, in case you're wondering, used to manage Cambridge). "The lad was magnificent against Scotland [at the weekend]," Johnson went on. "Steve Rowley [the Arsenal scout] was full of praise for the lad and thought there was a bit of Steve Bould in his game as well."

That's some billing, and the 6ft 3ins centre-back could prove his worth as soon as this Wednesday. Because with Tony Adams out - reportedly for a month - and with a fresh-smelling work permit arriving at Highbury this very morning, Stepanovs looks likely to be hurled into the lions' den (well, Stamford Bridge). Not that Johnson, Stepanov's one-man fan club, is worried. "I have told him if he plays like he did against Scotland in the Premiership he will soon be a millionaire in England," he twittered. But what will Stepanovs do with the money? Buy Lee Dixon's thigh muscles, we would wager.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NOT-SO CLEVER TREVOR

The Fiver loves the Sunday papers. They're as important a part of the weekend as the Saturday fry-up and the Friday night vomit. The Sunday papers are what make this country great. After all, where else could you read about the latest in light fittings, catch up with the movements of your local paedophile, get the recipe for a meal comprised entirely of artichokes, or read Birmingham City chairman David Sullivan having a pop at his manager, Trevor Francis, over two pages?

Sky pundit Francis declared over the weekend that there is a conspiracy aimed at forcing him out of St Andrews. Sullivan told the Birmingham Sunday Mercury that Francis should stop talking like that, if he doesn't want to be forced out of the club. "I would describe Trevor's reaction as paranoia," Sullivan said. "His nature is one of pessimism. He paints a gloomy picture and has a policy of talking the team down. That way if we do badly he can say 'I told you so'. But if we do well he can tell us all what a wonderful manager he is."

Francis, when not making Richard Keys look like an erudite afficionado of the game, has over the course of the past four seasons used porn magnate Sullivan's millions to steer the Blues away from promotion and acquire a complete collection of Mediocre Players . Not that Sullivan believes Francis would cut it even if he did make it to the Premiership. "The task of staying there would be phenomenal and he might say 'I don't need this in my life'," Sullivan said. So, all in all, a ringing endorsement. That Trev should just chill out - he'll do himself a misfortune.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"It's a lie. I am not a crook, I do not have to hide in my house. These accusations make me upset and I cannot allow them."

Brazil manager Wanderley Luxemburgo responds to allegations that he accepted bribes and forged documents about his age. He certainly sounds innocent to us.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NWANK-WOE

Arsenal's Nwankwo Kanu has written to the Nigerian FA asking to be left out of their squad for the Olympic games. The Nigerian FA were not best pleased by the request. A spokesman said: "We are very unhappy about this development - more so when the player had given us his word that he would play in Sydney. Kanu should not work against his country." It is now expected that Kanu will not travel to Sydney. In a (parallel) world exclusive The Fiver reprints the letter in full below.

Dear Mr Nigerian FA

Hallo, my name is Nwankwo. I have been picked in your 22 man squad to play in the Olympics in Sydney. I have always liked Australia. It looks pretty in Neighbours, the television programme that I watch by myself after training. I am so lonely.

Anyway, Mr Nigerian FA, I am writing to say that I will not be coming to Sydney because Mr Wenger doesn't want me to. Oh, what have I said? I mean to say that I will not be coming to Sydney because my dog ate it. Oh, how silly! Of course I meant that I will not be coming to Sydney because of pressing concerns at home (it is very big, I have no cleaner, the smaller dining room is getting dusty etc).

I wish you all the best in your Olympic endeavours.

Yours truly,

Nwankwo Kanu

PS If you are ever in London, please do not hesitate to contact me. I am free every afternoon. And evening. And most mornings too. Don't be a stranger! * * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Shay Given has expressed an interest in re-joining Celtic. "I've been in negotiations with Newcastle about a new contract but nothing has been sorted out," he told the Daily Record. "If Celtic came in for me I would definitely consider moving back."

Southampton have denied they will sell Marian Pahars, despite rumoured interest from Celtic.

Dutch side Roda are lining up a bid for Sheffield Wednesday striker Gerald Sibon, after missing out on Erik Meijer.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Jesper Blomqvist faces another lengthy spell on the sidelines after suffering another knee injury. The Swedish international will have an exploratory operation on his other knee and will be out for at least a month.

Huddersfield striker Clyde Wijnhard has undergone an operation to pin a compound fracture of his arm after he was involved in a serious car accident. The 26-year-old was involved in the accident when his Mercedes jeep left the road on the A1 in the early hours of yesterday.

Uefa have fined Aston Villa £5,200 for "the improper conduct of the team" during the two legs of their Intertoto Cup match with Celta Vigo. Meanwhile Aberdeen have been fined £4,000 for the same offence after their second leg against Bohemians.

Moldovan side Constructorul-93 Chisinau have been banned from European club competitions for a year after a member of the club threatened the assistant referee with a gun, following their tie against CSKA Sofia last month.

Celtic's chief executive Allan MacDonald has announced he will quit the club after only 18 months in the post. An announcement to the Stock Market read: "Mr Allan MacDonald has informed the board of his intention to resign from his position as chief executive of Celtic plc and return to a career outside the football sector."

The draw for the third round of the Bell's Challenge Cup is: Airdrie v Clydebank, East Stirling v Stenhousemuir, Stranraer v Arbroath, Livingston v Brechin.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 3: Football League Review (5pm)
"Never mind this rubbish about McCaff," says Gareth Devine. "Kamara is the future of sports broadcasting. Even as a red-blooded male, I must admit to a certain frisson of sexual excitement every time the old smoothie utters one of his catchphrases, such as 'Tremendous, smashing or brilliant.'"

British Eurosport: World Cup Football (6pm)
"His footballing talent is remembered by young and old throughout the country, his smog-monster Middlesbrough accent is ready-made for TV, his smooth debonair charm is a hit with the ladies," he continues

Sky Sports 1: World Football Show (7.30pm)
And there's more: "Put the powerful voice of the Fiver behind what this nation truly wants. Together, we can make Kamara great!" Gareth insists.

Sky Sports 1: You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 2.30am)
But surely the nation loves McCaff, not Kamara. Don't you?!

webTitle: Focussed England brush away history

fields.headline: Focussed England brush away history
fields.trailText: It was 31 years of more tangible hurt than England's soccer team has suffered since the '66 World Cup. There have been frequent fractures, more bruises than at a Saturday-night casualty department, and numerous careers blighted as England went down to defeat after defeat against West Indies. No-one playing now - no, not even Alec Stewart - was around when England last beat the Windies in a series, in 1969. Half the team wasn't even born in those black-and-white days of Illy and Dolly and Sobers. At times during the '80s it was often a matter of celebration if England scraped a draw, never mind won.
fields.body:
It was 31 years of more tangible hurt than England's soccer team has suffered since the '66 World Cup. There have been frequent fractures, more bruises than at a Saturday-night casualty department, and numerous careers blighted as England went down to defeat after defeat against West Indies. No-one playing now - no, not even Alec Stewart - was around when England last beat the Windies in a series, in 1969. Half the team wasn't even born in those black-and-white days of Illy and Dolly and Sobers. At times during the '80s it was often a matter of celebration if England scraped a draw, never mind won.

And now this fit and focussed England team has changed all that. England had the fastest three bowlers on view and, for the first time since that 1969 series, the better pace attack. Even allowing for the excellence of Curtly and Courtney, once they were kicking their heels it was no contest: Cork and surprise packet White bowled the socks and shoes off West Indies' struggling support men. England's batting, too, was more solid, none more so in this Oval Test than Mike Atherton, whose heroic hundred deserves to be bracketed alongside that match-saving 185 at Johannesburg four years ago. West Indies' batsmen, in contrast, exhibited a tendency to self-destruct that will have had Glenn McGrath and Brett Lee licking their lips in anticipation of this winter's series in Australia.

Possibly the most amazing aspect of a memorable match was the final-day crowd at The Oval. On a working day, with no tickets sold in advance (who'd have bought one, anyway, after those three- and even two-day finishes?), they shut the Hobbs Gates behind a capacity crowd. No-one could remember anything remotely comparable: 1953 was mentioned, but Compton and Edrich's Ashes-winning triumph actually came on the fourth of a scheduled six days.

Quite a way for sponsors Cornhill to bow out after 131 Tests. Well done them, well done the Oval crowd - but above all well done England. Shades of David Gower's Ashes triumph in 1985: wonder if Australia (not to mention Pakistan and Sri Lanka) are quaking in their boots now?

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: Bomb kills three in Russian market

fields.headline: Bomb kills three in Russian market
fields.trailText: Three people were killed when a bomb exploded in an early-morning outdoor market in central Russia today.
fields.body:
Three people were killed when a bomb exploded in an early-morning outdoor market in central Russia today.

The blast in Ryazan, a small industrial city about 120 miles south of Moscow, shattered a meat stall. Shards of torn metal and food were strewn for yards around.

Two people were killed immediately and a third died in a hospital, medical officials said. At least three others were wounded.

The bomb was in a plastic bag placed on the corrugated metal roof of the stall, according to a witness quoted on NTV television news. The device exploded when a saleswoman tried to move it, the witness said.

Officials said the bombing was part of a criminal turf war between a gang of Afghan war veterans and a rival group from Russia's Caucasus region, over protection money from the market.

Dismissing the possibility that the blast was a terrorist attack carried out by Chechen rebels, interior minister Vladimir Rushailo told journalists: "This situation doesn't have any relation to terror in the widely understood sense. This was a local conflict."

Police detained five people for questioning shortly after the incident.

Another small explosion destroyed the windows of a boutique today in St. Petersburg, but nobody was hurt. A police spokesman also blamed the incident on organized crime.

The blasts came on the first anniversary of a series of apartment bombings that were blamed on Chechen rebels. Some 300 people were killed in the blasts, and Russia responded by moving its forces into the separatist province.

webTitle: Gore on tax and economy

fields.headline: Turning from the big battalions
fields.standfirst:
Gore on tax and economy

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: If, as Bill Clinton once said, "It's the economy stupid", the next couple of months should be a triumphal procession towards the White House for Al Gore. The US has never seen an economic expansion as long as this one, which began after the Gulf war in 1991, and the combination of low unemployment and rising real wages are the classic ingredients of a feelgood factor.
fields.body:
If, as Bill Clinton once said, "It's the economy stupid", the next couple of months should be a triumphal procession towards the White House for Al Gore. The US has never seen an economic expansion as long as this one, which began after the Gulf war in 1991, and the combination of low unemployment and rising real wages are the classic ingredients of a feelgood factor.

Mr Gore's direct responsibility for the rejuvenation of the economy was limited. In his days as a Tennessee senator he helped to launch the Democratic Leadership Council, a home for the "new" Democrats who believed that the party should loosen its ties with the unions and adopt a friendlier approach to business.

As such, it was no surprise that after Mr Clinton's victory in 1992 he was a strong supporter of the plan to take the axe to the hefty budget deficit built up by Ronald Reagan's mix of tax cuts and military spending in the 80s, and one of the most vociferous cheerleaders for free trade, both through the North American Free Trade Act (Nafta) and the World Trade Organisation.

But, like most vice-presidents, he has played a back-seat role in economic policy. Americans know whom to thank for rising prosperity, and it is not Mr Gore (or Bill Clinton) but Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, the US central bank.

Until last month's Democratic convention his failure to claim credit for nine years' economic growth looked like an insurmountable barrier to his presidential hopes.

Business liked his commitment to free trade; the trade unions did not. He has tried to remedy that by tacking to the left, saying he will defend ordinary Americans against "Big tobacco, big oil, the big polluters, the pharmaceutical companies, the HMOs [health maintenance organisations]".

webTitle: Northern Ireland: Still seeking the murderous truth

fields.headline: Still seeking the murderous truth
fields.standfirst: John O'Farrell explains the background to today's meeting between Tony Blair and Geraldine Finucane
fields.trailText: John O'Farrell explains the background to today's meeting between Tony Blair and Geraldine Finucane.
fields.body:
Today, in Downing Street, Prime Minister Tony Blair will meet the widow of a 1989 murder victim.

Geraldine Finucane will have finally made it to the heart of the government she believes played a part in her husband's assassination.

Mr Blair will require more than his famous charm and caring ear to assuage the widow of Pat Finucane.

The story begins three weeks before the Belfast solicitor was shot 14 times by members of the Ulster Freedom Fighters. The murder gang knocked down Finucane's front door in his north Belfast home as the family sat down for Sunday dinner.

Geraldine Finucane was shot in the foot as she tried to protect their three children.

An RUC detective investigating the killing described it at the time as "the most ferocious murder I have come across. Every shot seemed to strike home and I believe the gunmen involved had murdered before."

An immediate question that arose from the killing came from a statement made in the House of Commons three weeks before the killing.

A Junior Home Office Minister, Douglas Hogg, told the House of Commons "that there are in Northern Ireland a number of solicitors who are unduly sympathetic to the cause of the IRA."

Hogg's comments were immediately condemned by the SDLP MP Seamus Mallon, who said that "it would be on the Minister's head, and on the heads of the government, if an assasin's bullet did what his words had done."

The NI Law Society accused Hogg of creating "an excuse for terrorist organisations to carry out murders - something which was not available to them before."

Then other strange things began to emerge. In 1992, the BBC Panorama programme broadcast allegations that the UDA were plotting to kill Finucane and that British Army Intelligence were warned in advance.

The allegations came from Brian Nelson, who was, as well as a spook for the FRU (Forces Reconnaisance Unit), the Intelligence Officer for the UDA in West Belfast.

Further allegations were made claiming that loyalist suspects under interrogation in Castlereagh Holding Centre were told by RUC Special Branch Officers that Finucane and two other nationalist solicitors were senior figures in the IRA.

The UDA statement that claimed responsibility for the killing alleged that Finucane was "killed as an IRA officer and not as a solicitor."

In recent months, it has become clear that the RUC may well have more to reveal about the killing. William Stobie was arrested last year and charged with the killing, although, last week, the charges against him were reduced to "aiding and abetting" the shooting.

In 1989, Stobie was quartermaster of the West Belfast UDA. We now know that he was also an RUC Special Branch informant.

In the Sunday Tribune newspaper, he claimed that his RUC handlers had been tipped-off that Finucane was the target.

Then, on the day of the killing itself, Stobie contacted his handlers and informed them that he had supplied weapons for a killing that would take place later that day.

Over the years a momentum has built up, backing the calls of Geraldine Finucane for an independent judicial inquiry into the killing of her husband.

The call has been supported by human rights organisations such as Amnesty International and the New York-based Lawyers Committee for Human Rights.

The UN Human Rights Commission joined the chorus after a scathing report on the killing was compiled by leading Malaysian jurist Param Cumaraswamy, who concluded his report by writing "so long as this murder is unresolved, many in the community will continue to lack confidence in the ability of the government to dispense justice in a fair and equitable manner."

Last year, again on Panorama, Cumaraswamy claimed that the present RUC Chief Constable Sir Ronnie Flanagan told him that there were lawyers who were involved with paramilitary organisations.

At first, Flanagan denied the allegation, but was publicly embarrassed when the BBC programme showed him minutes of his meeting with Cumaraswamy that Flanagan's office had subsequently approved and that showed such a conversation had taken place.

Within months of the conversation between Cumaraswamy and Flanagan, an event occurred which made the Finucane allegations suddenly very relevant.

Another leading nationalist solicitor was assassinated, again after receiving alleged threats from the security forces.

Indeed, in an added, the week before Rosemary Nelson was blown up outside her home in Lurgan, a newspaper advertisement appeared calling for an independent inquiry into the Finucane shooting, signed by over 400 Irish and international legal figures.

Soon after the then Secretary of State Mo Mowlam met with Geraldine Finucane, and received "new evidence," which Finucane's widow believes are grounds for a new inquiry.

Since then, she has met and received the backing of the Irish Prime Minister Bertie Ahern.

If today she convinces Tony Blair that there are grounds for a full inquiry, on top of the re-opened criminal investigation which saw Stobie's arrest last year and was headed by the recently appointed head of the Metropolitan Police John Stevens, it could open an almighty can of worms.

The following questions are some that require convincing answers. How did Douglas Hogg feel secure in making his comments to the House of Commons three weeks before Finucane's assassination?

Is it true, as claimed, that Hogg was briefed by RUC Special Branch officers days before his Commons statement?

Why did army intelligence not act on the warnings by Brian Nelson that Finucane's life was in danger? Why did RUC Special Branch not act on similar warnings from William Stobie?

Were UFF/UDA suspects told that people like Finucane should be targeted rather than the random Catholics who made up the bulk of loyalist victims during the murder campaign of the time?

What did MI5 know? If the intelligence services were informed, how high did this information go? The go-ahead for the killing of three IRA members in Gibraltar the previous year went as far as the prime minister's office.

Is it possible that intelligence reports from different agencies of the security forces stopped at a very low level in Northern Ireland?

Finally, if another solicitor could die in similarly suspicious circumstances almost exactly 10 years later, what does that say about how certain figures at the heart of the security establishment regard defence solicitors who happen to be good at their jobs?

webTitle: Graceful US debut for British film

fields.headline: Graceful US debut for British film
fields.trailText: British comedy Saving Grace poised for international success and Oscar recognition as it opens Stateside to higher average earnings than X-men
fields.body:
The UK comedy Saving Grace, released in Britain earlier in the year to minimal fuss, is on the verge of international blockbuster success and Oscar recognition. The film, starring Brenda Blethyn as a widow who turns around her ailing fortunes by growing marijuana in her greenhouse, has higher per-screen takings in the US than box-office mammoth X-Men.

The film, which won an audience award at the Sundance Film Festival in January, opened on only 30 screens in the US three weeks ago, but such was its success that distributor Fine Line expanded coverage to 250 screens the subsequent weekend. Now, Philip Reid of UK film and TV rights company PrimeEnt tells Reuters, "Saving Grace is demonstrating all the characteristics of becoming a major international hit."

Nigel Cole's film, which includes scenes featuring pensioners unwittingly spaced out on cannabis, grossed £3m on its British release, making it little more than a modest success. Unimpressed Guardian critic Xan Brooks called it "faintly unrealised, dramatically stodgy and rather too in love with its own naughtiness".
