As Cotton says when asked how he ensured the return of dozens of popular series: "You had a good head of drama and that was his job." At the moment, the BBC doesn't really have a head of drama. There's Jane Tranter, head of drama serials, and Mal Young, head of drama series. They are the Upstairs, Downstairs of BBC drama - she muses over Wives and Daughters and Other People's Children, while he gets his hands dirty with Casualty and Holby City. Soon there will be Simon Lewis and Sue Hogg from Granada, installed as executive producers in a new unit reporting to drama and entertainment supremo Alan Yentob. But are these really the right people? Lewis and Hogg were unpopular figures at Granada. It is understood that Granada's programming director Grant Mansfield got so fed up with their prevarication that he told them both to "shove off" to the BBC if they really wanted to. Granada is now looking forward to restructuring its drama department without them. Crucially, ITV's revered drama controller Nick Elliott doesn't seem to be in too much of a hurry to give up his network centre kingdom, despite desperate attempts by the BBC to get him. Meanwhile, it is clear that the lion's share of the £95m of new money earmarked by Dyke for BBC1 is going on popular drama. At BBC Elstree this week, 30 new episodes of Holby City, the Casualty spin-off, are in production. That's twice last year's run, and takes it to Peak Practice proportions, becoming almost a year-round feature of our screens. The show will gain a new children's ward, allowing writers to diversify from heart surgery to saving babies (remember the audience demographics: at 8pm, it's mums, teens and kids after EastEnders). Talking of which, the soap has just introduced a new family to the Square, whose five mouthy daughters will provide a raft of new storylines. That long-promised fourth episode is now certain, and if the BBC has any sense it will play it on Sunday nights, its weak point, giving Heartbeat a serious run for its money and teeing up the audience for the later-night offerings. And in Birmingham, producers are labouring on an order for 100 new half-hours of Doctors, the successful daytime soap set in a Midlands surgery. Series such as Holby are what the BBC really needs, the fresh but reliable mid-week regular drama that ITV is best at. As Dyke said in his MacTaggart: "It's the programmes, stupid". Young, perched in a hospital chair on the Holby set, underscores its significance. This is the first successful new BBC1 one-hour drama format and it has risen above the very public failures of Harbour Lights and Sunburn - slapped down by Dyke in Edinburgh for relying on ex-soap stars. The man who once vowed he would use former soap stars above all others is repentant. "We're all guilty of grabbing a face, but it's a short-term gimmick. Viewers see right through it. It's the scripts that count. On the other hand, the soaps are so prevalent it's hard to find someone who hasn't been in one," says Young equably. Salmon remarked at Edinburgh, perhaps prophetically, that BBC1 can be a very cold place. He meant that there would have to be more collaboration, between the network of five new channels sketched out by Dyke, so promising ideas can migrate across. However, in the short term, the stockpiling for next year's schedule blitz started under him six months ago, as the shift in 9pm news was anticipated. The build up in production has been aided, confirms Dyke, by a cache of £200m, amassed by prudent BBC accountants, before the improved licence fee settlement was struck last January. So, there are three more Scarlet Pimpernels, starring Richard E Grant. Martin Shaw, a hit in ITV's rival hospital drama, Always and Everyone, has been wooed to star in Judge John Dee, a series about an unconventional judge, written by GF Newman (Law and Order). And Stephen Tompkinson is being paired with Nick Berry for In Deep, an undercover cop show, for post watershed. It could become the regular police drama that the BBC so badly needs. BBC1 is investing in Steven Spielberg's 10-part Band of Brothers, about a group of American soldiers in the second world war, a spin-off from Saving Private Ryan, currently in production in Hertfordshire. It's clear, then, that Dyke has signed up BBC1 to the Bill Cotton rule of "being the best of everyone for everybody". The question is, whether he's got the right idea. Is there enough talent simply to make all these programmes? Jackson thinks not. "That's a huge undertaking and it's a waste of time. You just need to make sure that BBC1 is out there, making a few big hits that make people say 'thank God for the BBC'. Anything else is just too difficult." ITV is in trouble too by David Elstein Why does it matter where the BBC places its main evening news bulletin? Before Greg Dyke labels me as one of the "retired old men of the BBC" defending yesterday (yes, I did work there until 35 years ago), I do not believe 9pm is sacrosanct or 10pm impermissible. But I do believe in being honest with the public. The argument based on Commons votes or US markets closing is simply laughable. Dyke himself scoffed at it while making the case for moving News at Ten to Gerald Kaufman's Commons committee when he was ITV's council chairman. Very few Commons votes feature in the news, let alone those at 10pm. The US markets have all but closed when the present 9pm bulletin ends, and virtually never merit more than a glancing mention. But "the main reason" for the move, according to Dyke, is that more people will watch news in the later slot. That is barely credible. There are far fewer people available to view television at 10pm than 9pm. A later bulletin might - "might!" - just win a larger share of available viewers, but that "more people will watch it" is a pledge almost impossible to fulfil. Will the governors require a return to 9pm if the ploy fails? Don't hold your breath. Dyke made much of the claim that "currently in digital homes, audience share for the Nine O'Clock News often falls below 10%". In fact, after under-performing against the rest of the schedule for the first six months of the year in digital satellite homes, the Nine O'Clock News has since equalled or out-performed BBC1 as a whole in these homes, based on the relative share of viewing compared with total viewing. In any case, there is absolutely no evidence that news will perform any better relatively in digital homes at 10pm than at 9pm. And we have heard before all these improbable protestations about enlarging the news audience by moving the bulletin later - from the ITV companies. Nobody (except, perhaps, an over-credulous ITC) believed them: but then the transparent motive for the move was to increase audience share in the vacated slot. Increasing BBC1's audience share at 9pm is evidently the true motive for moving the news, and Greg should have been much more straightforward about it. After all, it is all part of the pressure that licence-fee funding places on the BBC. You cannot afford to let the audience share for your main channel drop to the point where licence-fee payers feel short-changed, and evasion starts to rise again. Of course, what takes the 9pm slot remains a crucial issue. First, will it drive up audience share? The evidence from the run of failed dramas at 9.30pm recently would suggest that the BBC simply lacks the fire power to compete at 9pm, unless there is to be a shift to much more populist programming. That in turn raises the issue of why a publicly-funded broadcaster should deliberately reduce the news audience in peak-time (as seems inevitable) in favour of increasing consumption of soft factual material or entertainment. A major dent in the BBC's reputation for public service broadcasting seems a high price to pay for putting a minor blip in the ratings decline of BBC1. Whether Lorraine Heggessey (if it is to be her) can achieve what eluded Peter Salmon must be doubtful. Three years of navigating the BBC's frustrating system seems to have crushed some of Salmon's natural flair: at Edinburgh, he made a woeful hash of the ITV line-up in the scheduling game, putting both a 90-minute Bill and Burnside into peak-time, while BBC exile Michael Attwell showed how a competitive BBC1 schedule could be assembled. Heggessey - whom I have known since she was a student - is an energetic go-getter, but she (like Salmon) will lack the full control of the channel budget and commissioning process that is so essential in a competitive environment. In any event, the downward trend for the two main channels seems inexorable. In 1989, ITV and BBC1 captured 80% of all viewers. In 1995, 70%. In 1999, just under 60%. So far this year, 56.5%. For the last month, less than 53%. In multi-channel homes in July, they shared barely 40% of the audience, for the first time less than all satellite channels combined. If anything, BBC1's plight has only served to conceal ITV's dismal performance, not just across the day, but even within its own carefully defined version of peak-time, where it will fail by a wide margin even to meet the target it so recently revised sharply downward. Of course, ITV's concentration of ownership allows it to secure a disproportionate amount of the advertising market, despite audience erosion. The licence fee is not like that. Dyke (and Heggessey) may find that the news manoeuvre backfires. A further audience decline, embracing an even sharper news audience decline, would leave a lot of questions to be answered at Edinburgh next year.

webTitle: Judge suggests second opinion on Siamese twins

fields.headline: Judge suggests second opinion on Siamese twins
fields.standfirst: Graphic: the case explained
fields.trailText: A senior judge today suggested that a second medical opinion might be necessary in the case of the Siamese twins Jodie and Mary.
fields.body:
A senior judge today suggested that a second medical opinion might be necessary in the case of the Siamese twins Jodie and Mary.

Three appeal judges are being asked to rule whether the twins should be separated against the wishes of their parents, which the court has heard would mean death for baby Mary.

Lord Justice Ward, sitting with Lord Justice Brooke and Lord Justice Robert Walker, referred to the wide public interest in the case and added: "I cannot but wonder (whether) a second opinion might be of value if only to confirm the views expressed ... and to allay any public concern."

Jodie and Mary - false names used to preserve their anonymity - were born on August 8 and are joined by their lower abdomens. A legal battle began after it was realised that one would have to be sacrificed if the other was to survive.

At the High Court in London on 25 August Mr Justice Johnson gave surgeons the go-ahead to separate the girls, meaning death for baby Mary. Five days later an appeal was lodged by solicitors acting on behalf of the parents.

Lord Justice Ward said today the court had "deep sympathy" for the parents, who were not in court, although it might seem during the course of legal argument that they had forgotten their human predicament.

Among the major issues the court would have to decide was "whether it would be an unlawful killing of Mary to sanction this treatment".

The hospital's application to separate the twins was also opposed by the Official Solicitor, acting on behalf of Mary. Jodie is a bright and alert child but her twin relies on her for heart and lung function and lives only because she is attached to her sister.

The parents came to Britain from abroad to have their children after it was realised they were conjoined and there was a lack of medical facilities in their own country.

In earlier written evidence, they said: "We cannot begin to accept or contemplate that one of our children should die to enable the other one to survive. That is not God's will. Everyone has the right to life, so why should we kill one of our daughters to enable the other one to survive?"

webTitle: Rob Burleigh and Dave Beverley of Leagas Delaney

fields.headline: Rob Burleigh and Dave Beverley of Leagas Delaney
fields.standfirst: Under the harsh gaze of Tim Delaney, their famously hard-to-please creative director, this duo has flourished for seven years.
fields.trailText: Under the harsh gaze of Tim Delaney, their famously hard-to-please creative director, this duo has flourished for seven years.
fields.body:
Rob Burleigh and Dave Beverley created two of this year's best-known ads: the Adidas Euro 2000 spot featuring David Beckham in Amsterdam with a van full of balls, and the controversial Barclays Bank "big" commercial starring Anthony Hopkins.

They work 12 hours a day at the agency; 18 hours a day when on shoots. "You have to do long days to do good work," Beverley says. "This is the best job there is. We get a real buzz out of problem-solving."

After obtaining degrees in communications and media, they both headed straight down to London and soon made their mark with a poster advertising the British Television Advertising Awards. It featured a picture of OJ Simpson and suggested the awards were worth entering because "you'll never know what decision a jury will reach".

They found their niche in this, their second, job and have recently been rewarded with a promotion to creative director.

webTitle: Labour drops 'ethical' tag

fields.headline: Labour drops 'ethical' tag
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: Labour's ethical foreign policy, launched to a fanfare by Robin Cook, is to be dropped for the next general election, according to senior sources and internal party documents seen by the Guardian.
fields.body:
Labour's ethical foreign policy, launched to a fanfare by Robin Cook, is to be dropped for the next general election, according to senior sources and internal party documents seen by the Guardian.

The policy is said to have become "a millstone" around the neck of the foreign secretary, who announced it within days of Labour taking power in May 1997, saying it would "make Britain once again a force for good in the world".

The 32-page final document from the party's national policy forum, which will form the basis of Labour's next election manifesto, fails to mention the ethical foreign policy or ethical dimension in its main report and recommendations.

Called Britain in the World, it talks of promoting "a more responsible arms trade". It was finalised last month before news that a key part of the ethical foreign policy, a bill to regulate the arms trade, had failed to find time in the government's legislative programme.

The document will be unveiled at the party's conference next month. It was drawn up by key Labour figures including Mr Cook, the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, and the international development secretary, Clare Short.

This lays to rest a policy that delighted the party's left wing when it was announced but has troubled ministers and led to inter-departmental rows ever since. Labour's claims to the label of an ethical foreign policy were holed after they refused to block a string of arms sales to regimes with poor human rights records.

Sources with knowledge of the discussions confirm that what one described as the "cornerstone" of Labour's foreign policy was dead before the document was even drawn up.

On May 12 1997, Mr Cook said in a "mission statement" that it "supplies an ethical content to foreign policy and recognises that the national interest cannot be defined only by narrow realpolitik".

A senior source with knowledge of the debate within the government said: "It was an embarrassment as we couldn't live up to it. We were always being panned."

The source added: "The document is an accurate reflection of government thinking.

"I'm sure they'll [number 10] be pleased it's gone, otherwise it becomes a big benchmark everyone needs to follow."

A source involved in the round table discussions that led to Britain in the World said that even before the final draft was written in July, ethical foreign policy had been killed off as a label the government would use: "It did not form any part of our discussions. It was not surprising. It was understood that Robin Cook's view was that the whole thing has become a millstone."

The document pledges tighter controls on small arms exports and to "work to strengthen significantly the EU code of conduct on arms exports."

The Foreign Office minister, Peter Hain, said: "We want to be judged by our record not by obsessive interpretation of a misrepresented label. Our record is a proud one on human rights, on refusing to export arms which could be used for either internal repression or external aggression, and it is a record which is as night and day compared with the thoroughly unprincipled policy of the Tories.

"Our foreign policy stands up against any realistic yardstick on its commitment to human rights and international justice."

Rachel Harford, of the pressure group Campaign Against the Arms Trade, said: "To have made such gain in opposition from this issue, with the Scott inquiry [into arms to Iraq], and to come in with expectations raised with commitments to an ethical dimension when they first came in, it's absolutely scandalous."

The national policy forum document will go to next month's Labour party conference, where the leadership hope it will be rubber stamped. It is expected to form the basis of the section in the party's election manifesto on foreign policy.

webTitle: Arsenal sign Stepanovs to ease injury problems

fields.headline: Arsenal sign Stepanovs to ease injury problems
fields.trailText: Arsenal have completed the signing of Latvian international defender Igor Stepanovs, according to their official website.
fields.body:
Arsenal have completed the signing of Latvian international defender Igor Stepanovs, according to their official website.

The 24-year-old centre-back, who has joined for an undisclosed fee from Latvian Champions FC Skonto Riga, could go straight into the Gunners side to face Chelsea on Wednesday night.

Manager Arsène Wenger confirmed: "We have signed Igors to strengthen our defensive unit. He is an experienced International and a very competent defender who will prove to be a great asset to the club. He will play an important part in this season's campaign."

Stepanovs, who has made a total of 37 appearances for Latvia, said: "I am delighted to be joining one of the top clubs in Europe. Arsenal is a great club and I am looking forward to playing in the same team as so many excellent players and also such a great league as the English Premiership."

The news of Stepanovs' signing comes amid fears that Tony Adams could be out for a month after damaging an ankle during England's friendly against France.

The Arsenal captain has already been ruled out of the game against Chelsea and is also expected to miss the Gunners' opening Champions League fixture against Sparta Prague in the Czech Republic next Tuesday.

At the start of the current campaign Adams insisted he was feeling fitter than "for a long time" and said he was ready to meet the demands of a regular two-games-a-week schedule. But the latest setback will raise questions over the future of the Arsenal captain, who celebrates his 34th birthday next month.

webTitle: Mowlam: why I resigned

fields.headline: Mowlam: why I resigned
fields.trailText: "I have decided to stand down from my Redcar parliamentary seat at the next election.
fields.body:
"I have decided to stand down from my Redcar parliamentary seat at the next election.

"This is a personal decision for me. It is one that I have been considering for some time, and have previously discussed with the Prime Minister.

"I have decided not to stand because I have several years of my working life left and want to do something different before I finally retire. "I have been looking at a number of different options to continue to pursue my many interests, including in international affairs, conflict resolution and poverty.

"My commitment to the Government and the Labour Party is as strong as ever. Between now and the General Election I will continue to fight for the election of a Labour government.

"I have worked for the Labour Party all my life and I'm very proud to be part of all that this Government stands for and has achieved for the people of this country."

webTitle: Mowlam resigns: reaction

fields.headline: Mowlam resigns: reaction
fields.trailText:
"It was a career decision by Mo, pure and simple... No one who speaks in any way, shape or form with any authority on behalf of the prime minister has ever briefed against Mo. On the contrary, the prime minister holds her in extremely high regard."
Alastair Campbell, prime minister's spokesman
fields.body:
"It was a career decision by Mo, pure and simple... No one who speaks in any way, shape or form with any authority on behalf of the prime minister has ever briefed against Mo. On the contrary, the prime minister holds her in extremely high regard."
Alastair Campbell, prime minister's spokesman

"Politics will be the poorer for Mo's departure. We may have disagreed in many things, but I have never doubted her honesty, candour and ability to respond to people."
Shadow Cabinet Office Minister Andrew Lansley

"She has made an enormous contribution towards bringing about peace on our streets."
SDLP leader John Hume

"She will be remembered in Northern Ireland as the person who played a key role in resolving the conflict here - not just in achieving the Good Friday Agreement, but also working hard to see it implemented properly."
Women's Coalition Northern Ireland Assembly member Monica McWilliams

"There will be some who will miss her but there will also be those who detested her because she was a capable and clever woman who was a breath of fresh air for this society."
Progressive Unionist Assemblyman David Ervine

"It's just a pity it didn't happen sooner when she was Secretary of State. It's a case of goodbye and good riddance."
Democratic Unionist Assemblyman Ian Paisley Jr

webTitle: Sound news; Reuters expands into world of pop

fields.headline: Sound news; Reuters expands into world of pop
fields.trailText: Reuters, the venerable information group, is to offer pop music news and pictures to its online clients, alongside its usual blend of financial prices and corporate statements.
fields.body:
Reuters, the venerable information group, is to offer pop music news and pictures to its online clients, alongside its usual blend of financial prices and corporate statements.

City brokers, bored of staring at financial news pages, will soon be able to read exclusive interviews with pop bands like Spiller, led by Sophie Ellis-Baxter, who are helping to promote the new alliance, following the agreement with cross media music company Worldpop.

The service, to be be updated twice a day, will include pop scoops, reviews, gossip and chart news.

Reuters will not restrict access to its City clients. It is trying to expand the demographics of its user base. Worldpop targets 15-24 year-olds who, according to MORI research, make up one quarter of web users.

Geoffrey Wheating, director of strategy, Reuters Media UK & Ireland, said: "Worldpop are undoubtedly a leader in reporting on the pop scene. Their coverage perfectly compliments Reuters' extensive entertainment file and provides an additional news service to our clients."

Reuters was founded in October 1851 by Paul Julius Reuter, a German-born immigrant who, from an office in the City, transmitted stock market quotations between London and Paris, via the new Calais-Dover cable.

Today it is the world's largest international news and television agency, with almost 2,000 journalists, photographers and camera operators in 153 countries.

webTitle: Ignore the scary tales about internet fraud. It's quite safe, honest

fields.headline: Ignore the scary tales about internet fraud. It's quite safe, honest
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Media reports may be overblowing lapses in internet security.
fields.body:
If you are a regular reader of the papers you might think there were only two types of internet businesses.

One forlorn group comprises those companies that are struggling to survive after being battered by the invisible hand of the market. We have seen the debilitating effects of this ourselves. A couple of our own retail partners have already fallen by the wayside or are treading water as they try to secure further funding. The other group are those that find themselves targeted for lapses in internet security.

A recent television news report focused on the security of online banks following recent attempts to defraud Egg. For the average viewer it must have been scary stuff as the report appeared to demonstrate how relatively easy it might be for a hacker to infiltrate a computer and access passwords and other confidential information.

We have an insight into some of the security scares because of our relationships with online retailers. It has provided us with a more in-depth version of events than can be gathered from the morning's headlines. In many cases, the situation is not as serious as the media make out. In one reported case, where limited personal details of two customers were mistakenly made accessible for a short time to visitors to one leading retailer's website, the customers involved were relatively unconcerned.

In fact, they appeared more annoyed at being disturbed in the middle of the night by tabloid journalists investigating the case than the error itself.

It is not that hackers are not an issue. We assume that rools will be targeted by hackers, so we are building our systems to withstand attacks accordingly. Currently we have 237 different security processes and procedures in place to address this. There will be many more by the time we launch.

In several ways the rools service has been designed to offer greater protection to our users than existing means of payment. Online retailers, for example, bear the cost if a credit card payment that they have accepted turns out to have been made fraudulently. With rools, the technology means that all transactions are authorised in real time - so-called "charge-backs" - are no longer an issue for the retailer.

However it will be our ability to build trust in the rools brand among consumers that will be a key to our success. One important element of this is the security of the service itself. Although the consumer rarely suffers directly when online services are exposed, scary media stories do mean that everyone in the dot.com world has to work that bit harder to build the necessary trust.

Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are the co-founders of rools, a service that enables teenagers to buy online without a credit card

webTitle: Mo Mowlam stands down as MP

fields.headline: Mo Mowlam stands down as MP
fields.trailText: Mo Mowlam, the popular minister for the Cabinet Office, ended months of speculation about her political career today when she announced that she intends to step down from parliament at the next general election.
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam, the popular minister for the Cabinet Office, ended months of speculation about her political career today when she announced that she intends to step down from parliament at the next general election.

Tony Blair's spokesman described her move as a "career decision" and said that the prime minister had praised the "massive contribution" that she had made in her former job as secretary of state for Northern Ireland.

"In the working years she's got left she wants to do something else. The prime minister said she will be a great loss to this government and to parliament," the spokesman said.

He said that Dr Mowlam was expected to remain as a cabinet minister until the next election.

Dr Mowlam met Mr Blair at No 10 briefly this morning to plan the announcement of her retirement and to tell him that her mind was made up.

No 10 said that Dr Mowlam would make a statement this afternoon explaining her decision, that was said to be unrelated to the brain tumour she had battled against during her time as Northern Ireland Secretary.

Rumours have been rife that Dr Mowlam has never really been happy since losing her Northern Ireland brief to Peter Mandelson. She has also been subjected to a constant sniping campaign, questioning her mastery of details in her various briefs.

As minister for the Cabinet Office, Dr Mowlam was in the unenviable position of being a roving minister, trying to get her fellow ministers to cooperate on projects, but without wielding real clout.

Earlier in the summer, she publicly anticipated a time when she was no longer part of the government and said she would like to promote integrated schools for Ulster.

Although widely popular, Dr Mowlam regularly made waves for the government.

She was slapped down earlier this year when she called for a wider debate on the future of the Royal Family, and her suggestions for a more liberal approach to drugs have also got her into trouble for deviating from the official party line.

webTitle: Margarita

fields.headline: Margarita
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the new threat to hedonism - the global margarita shortage
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the new threat to hedonism - the global margarita shortage.
fields.body:
1. Mexican tequila producers are calling time on America's favourite summer drink - the margarita.

2. They say their northern neighbour has such a thirst for the cocktail there is now a worldwide shortage of its prime ingredient tequila.

3. The manufacturers simply cannot keep up with demand. Tequila comes from eight to 12-year-old spiky blue agave plants grown in a demarcated area around Jalisco state, Mexico.

4. Ten years ago, when the current crop of blue agave was planted, few outside Mexico drank tequila. Those were the early 90s and the health-conscious new man drank mineral water.

5. In those halcyon days no one could have imagined that premium tequilas made from 100% blue agave would become drinks of desire.

6. Now the criminals have moved in: bandits steal the precious plants and sell them to desperate producers.

7. One New York bar, unable to obtain the good stuff, has taken to making a version with rum, a so-called "rum Rita". True devotees, however, may have no choice but to consider therapy.

8. Tequila and the less expensive mezcal are distilled versions of pulque, a low-alcohol agave wine that Spanish colonists found the native population drinking.

9. You mix tequila, lime juice and orange liquor poured into a glass with salt on the rim to make a classic margarita.

10. Mexicans usually prefer the spirit straight. They drink it as an aperitif to a hearty meal; a fine prelude to a pit barbecue fiesta or goat.

webTitle: Recommended Wapsites

fields.headline: Wapsites worth a visit
fields.standfirst: Check out the pick of the wapsites available direct to your phone
fields.trailText: Check out the pick of the wapsites available direct to your phone.
fields.body:
Sports news

Wap a Result
9/10 www.waparesult.com/index.wml
One of the most comprehensive sports results on the Wap web. The service features all the basics common among Wap results services, but excels by providing in-depth information on European leagues, nationwide leagues, forthcoming draws, live scores, tables, fixtures and rankings.

Football365.com
6/10 http://football365.com
While it has all the basic features - results, news etc * it pales into insignificance when compared to the Waparesult football service. To this end, some of the features seem uninspired and essentially, simple repurposed jobs of bits of the football365 website.

Entertainment

UK Entertainment Centre
4/10 www.ents24.com/index.wml
A useful local service designed to give people more detail about entertainment in their postcode area, split up into straightforward sections such as live music, cinema, clubs, comedy and theatre. However, the service can be a bit hit and miss. Not only does it often provide only one listing (and this for a Saturday night in Brighton) it can sometimes suggest evenings out in places more than 50 miles away.

Dotmusic
7/10 http://wap.dotmusic.com
Simple and well thought through. It offers news, charts and a pop quiz, and is one of the few Wapsites that has managed to incorporate visually strong advertising on the different sections. The only drawback is sometimes the content is too long for Wap devices and therefore won't load. Special features such as Party in the Park and Glastonbury are well out of date, but are redeemed by the superb pop quiz, which is easy to use and updated randomly, so, by and large, a different quiz is presented every time you go to use it.

UnmissableTV
7/10 www.unmissabletv.com/txw/wap.wml
A useful service, particularly if you can't bear to be without the latest showbiz gossip or you fancy planning your evening's TV viewing on the train on the way home. The service makes clever uses of TV databases to allow you to search for programmes and tailor your viewing.

Search engines and directories

AltaVista: Raging Search Unplugged
http://wml.raging.com wml
Google http://wap.google.com wml (Temperamental)

Portals

2thumbsWAP.com: http://2thumbswap.com/wap
Breathe: http://wap.breathe.com/
Excite: http://mobile.excite.co.uk/
Mviva: www.mviva.com/wap/index.wml wap
Virgin Mobile: www.virgin.com/mobile/wap
WapWorld: http://mmm.wapworld.net/
Yahoo: http://wap.yahoo.co.uk wap

About Wap portals

All portals are pretty much the same insofar as they provide basic, run of the mill services (categories tend to be: news, weather, entertainment, sports, lifestyle, shopping, search, money and travel). Given the nascent state of Wap services, it's difficult to find any distinguishing features between the various portals. What will happen, however, is the portals will make more of an effort to sign up exclusive content that make them stand head and shoulders above the competition. Orange has already done this with ITN, but is that really a strong enough reason to buy an Orange phone over and above a Vodafone phone? The now defunct BBC Wap service, which was heads and shoulders above the competition, is about to sign long-term deals with Vodafone and BT Cellnet so that they can offer BBC news on their Wap portals - for a price. However, BBC content is on offer through AvantGo and Yahoo.

News services

AvantGo
6/10 http://wap.avantgo.com
Very useful for tapping into different sources of business news, but can often get lost in a maze of links to Wapsites and then have to go back to the start because there is no direct route to work your way back.

The Guardian
8/10 www.theguardian.com/wml
One of the first news providers to get a fully functional Wap service up and running. Gives a good round-up of the news from the paper as well as the day's G2 sections, and doesn't skimp on the amount of text presented, unlike the FT. The breaking news service is updated throughout the day and is very useful.

The Financial Times
7/10 http://wap.ft.com
Broken up into three sections: top stories, news by subject and a search function. While it enables the user to get a general overview of the day's top business stories, the drawback is that it only gives the first paragraph of every story. This helps in speeding up navigation, but sometimes just a paragraph is not enough and the FT should think about extending this to three paragraphs.

Useful tools

Iobox
6/10 http://wap.iobox.com
Some of the services on offer through Iobox seem a tad pointless and while the site is difficult to navigate, one cannot scoff at the piece de resistance - download mobile rings to your phone. With this service you can change the rings easily and as often as you change your underwear.

Railtrack
8/10 www.railtrack.co.uk/i.wml com
A necessary bookmark for all commuters. You have to pre-register on the Railtrack website and enter your travel preferences (ie. any journey made regularly) and then every time you use the Wap service you can simply ask it to give you the details of the next train you can get, or search for details on a new journey. The logging in process in a bit tedious, surely there's a way of installing a cookie to recognise each user? Also, it would be great if the service was incorporated into SMS so that once you've got all your details pre-programmed, the database could SMS you to let you know if your train is likely to be delayed.

CitiKey
4/10 http://wap.citikey.com
Basic guide to a few European cities. At the moment just covers London, Paris, Stockholm, Berlin and Edinburgh but is being expanded all the time. Provides details of where to go, stay, eat etc. but by no means does it provide an exhaustive guide, merely a few recommendations.

Somewhere Near
6/10 www.somewherenear.com/wap/index.cgi com
Just fill in a postcode or place name and finds pubs, hotels, restaurants, curry houses, mobile phone shops and miscellaneous in the local area. Useful and quick, but needs to add more categories and listings.

Bluffers guide to Wap

Our guide to facilitate quick entry into the world of Wap:

1) Bluff your way into the world of Wap by taking five minutes out of your busy schedule to learn the words Mviva, WapWorld, GPRS and UMTS.
2) Drop these words in conversations at random intervals saying how terrible the portals are and how the reality about new technology is never going to live up to the hype.
3) If in doubt, and you're losing your way, harp on about how UMTS is never going to happen because of the impossible compression job needed - the technology needed to make UMTS mobile just about squeezes into a transit van.

How to sound like a Wap know-it-all

Say things like: "It's shocking that the BBC has shut down its Wap service"; "These walled garden Wap services are so restrictive"; "I'm not impressed by the prototype UMTS phones."

The now defunct BBC Wap service, which was heads and shoulders above the competition, is about to sign long-term deals with Vodafone and BT Cellnet so that they can offer BBC news on their Wap portals - for a price. However, BBC content is on offer through AvantGo and Yahoo. News services AvantGo 6/10 http://wap.avantgo.com Very useful for tapping into different sources of business news, but can often get lost in a maze of links to Wapsites and then have to go back to the start because there is no direct route to work your way back. The Guardian 8/10 www.theguardian.com/wml One of the first news providers to get a fully functional Wap service up and running. Gives a good round-up of the news from the paper as well as the day's G2 sections, and doesn't skimp on the amount of text presented, unlike the FT. The breaking news service is updated throughout the day and is very useful. The Financial Times 7/10 http://wap.ft.com Broken up into three sections: top stories, news by subject and a search function. While it enables the user to get a general overview of the day's top business stories, the drawback is that it only gives the first paragraph of every story. This helps in speeding up navigation, but sometimes just a paragraph is not enough and the FT should think about extending this to three paragraphs. Useful tools Iobox 6/10 http://wap.iobox.com Some of the services on offer through Iobox seem a tad pointless and while the site is difficult to navigate, one cannot scoff at the piece de resistance - download mobile rings to your phone. With this service you can change the rings easily and as often as you change your underwear. Railtrack 8/10 www.railtrack.co.uk/i.wml com A necessary bookmark for all commuters. You have to pre-register on the Railtrack website and enter your travel preferences (ie. any journey made regularly) and then every time you use the Wap service you can simply ask it to give you the details of the next train you can get, or search for details on a new journey. The logging in process in a bit tedious, surely there's a way of installing a cookie to recognise each user? Also, it would be great if the service was incorporated into SMS so that once you've got all your details pre-programmed, the database could SMS you to let you know if your train is likely to be delayed. CitiKey 4/10 http://wap.citikey.com Basic guide to a few European cities. At the moment just covers London, Paris, Stockholm, Berlin and Edinburgh but is being expanded all the time. Provides details of where to go, stay, eat etc. but by no means does it provide an exhaustive guide, merely a few recommendations. Somewhere Near 6/10 www.somewherenear.com/wap/index.cgi com Just fill in a postcode or place name and finds pubs, hotels, restaurants, curry houses, mobile phone shops and miscellaneous in the local area. Useful and quick, but needs to add more categories and listings. Bluffers guide to Wap Our guide to facilitate quick entry into the world of Wap: 1) Bluff your way into the world of Wap by taking five minutes out of your busy schedule to learn the words Mviva, WapWorld, GPRS and UMTS. 2) Drop these words in conversations at random intervals saying how terrible the portals are and how the reality about new technology is never going to live up to the hype. 3) If in doubt, and you're losing your way, harp on about how UMTS is never going to happen because of the impossible compression job needed - the technology needed to make UMTS mobile just about squeezes into a transit van. How to sound like a Wap know-it-all Say things like: "It's shocking that the BBC has shut down its Wap service"; "These walled garden Wap services are so restrictive"; "I'm not impressed by the prototype UMTS phones." webTitle: Cecilia Dufils and Markus Bjurman of Mother

fields.headline: Cecilia Dufils and Markus Bjurman of Mother
fields.standfirst: Dufils and Bjurman have brightened up the UK advertising scene ever since they came to London from Stockholm 18 months ago.
fields.trailText: Dufils and Bjurman have brightened up the UK advertising scene ever since they came to London from Stockholm 18 months ago.
fields.body:
This duo introduced us to Harvey and Hibby - the two knitted grey dolls that front Harvey Nichols' ad campaign - and have recently brought a generous helping of Italian colour to Costa Coffee's dark brown environment.

They met at Beckmans School of Design in Stockholm and ran away to London together after completing two years of a three-year course. "We wanted to do real work," Bjurman says.

They chose advertising "because it 's perfect. You get to do all the fun bits like design, making films and going on photo-shoots. It's never boring."

The duo have also worked on campaigns for Typhoo Tea, Britart.com, D&AD and Ivan Massow financial services.

Their only problem, they say, is that they are picky. "We are both art directors and we always want to do everything all the way through. So we end up working weekends and nights," Bjurman says.

webTitle: Peacekeeping missions

fields.headline: Peacekeeping missions
fields.standfirst: The government and the Liberal Democrats have called for a radical reform of United Nations peacekeeping operations. Mark Tran and Derek Brown explain the issues.
fields.trailText: The government and the Liberal Democrat party have called for a radical reform of United Nations peacekeeping operations. We explain the issues.
fields.body:
What are the latest proposals?
Released to coincide with this week's UN's Millennium Summit, the report from Labour and the Liberal Democrats calls for a total overhaul of UN peacekeeping, including the creation of a staff college - possibly in Britain - to command and train UN peacekeeping operations in the world. The college would modernise and professionalise peacekeeping operations so troops can deploy rapidly and take action in clear cases of aggression. The report also said that the UN should require member states to provide quarterly assessments of the soldiers available for peacekeeping operations.

What are the chances of success for these ideas?
There have been numerous proposals to sharpen up peacekeeping operations over the years. In the early 1990s, Secretary-general Boutros Boutros-Ghali wanted to set up a sort of UN standing army, but the US and other Security Council members disliked the idea as they thought it would give the secretary-general too much power. Sir Brian Urqhart, formerly a top UN official, suggested a UN force composed of volunteers, like a UN foreign legion, but his imaginative idea also gathered dust on the shelves. More recently there have been less ambitious ideas from countries like Britain and Canada, which have suggested that countries set troops on standby for rapid deployment to hot spots. But ideas for reforms have made little headway. So past experience does not augur well for the latest plans. Expect grumbling at the idea of a special college being set up in the UK for a start.

How has the UN performed in recent operations?
The UN has hardly covered itself in glory. In Sierra Leone, some 500 poorly-trained peacekeers were taken hostage by the Revolutionary United Front rebels without firing a shot. In other low points, the UN failed to intervene to stop the genocide in Rwanda in 1994 and, in one of its most shameful episodes, UN peacekeepers were helpless in stopping the slaughter of Bosnian Muslims by Serbs in Srebrenica - a so-called UN safe haven - in 1995. Currently, just 32 officers at UN headquarters oversee some 27,000 UN troops from 20 countries in 14 peacekeeping operations scattered across the globe.

What has been the UN's record overall?
The record is mixed. Since 1947, two years after its formation, the UN has mounted some 50 peacekeeping and monitoring operations. Some 750,000 soldiers have put on its blue helmets and berets, from Central America to East Timor. There are some 14,000 soldiers, police, and other civilian back-up personnel taking part in UN operations around the world. Wars and other conflicts continue to rage.

Surely there have been some successes?
It depends how you measure success. The UN generally intervenes not to end conflict but to restore stability after the fighting has ended. It has helped maintain an uneasy peace in places like Cyprus and the Golan Heights, and it has played a key part in the restoration of order in other places, like East Timor and Cambodia. It has also played an honourable part in initiatives like de-mining, and monitoring potential trouble spots. But for the most part its acronym-laden contingents - like the 22-year-old UNIFIL force in south Lebanon - have proved powerless to prevent new outbreaks of fighting.

How much does all this cost?
The UN is spending about £2.2bn a year on peacekeeping and related projects. There are perennial rows with member states over funding, and the organisation says it is owed some £750m for past and current operations. Typically, the UN secretary-general has to scramble for troops from countries willing to contribute once the Security Council gives its blessing to a mission. Poorer countries such as Pakistan and Bangladesh have been more than willing to put up troops, because UN rates of pay can be quite good. But the system does not mean that the best qualified troops are always available.

Is there competition in the international peacekeeping sector?
The Nato intervention in Kosovo is the alliance's first active operation in its 51-year history. With the Balkans in a continuing state of ethnic and economic turmoil, it may not be the last. Then there is the Western European Union: a perpetual fledgling among the international military alliances, but one which has, at least theoretically, the capacity to assemble a peacekeeping force. The real competition comes from individual countries with the capacity to protect their interests - and impose their will. Classic examples are the no-fly 'secure' zones in north and south Iraq, patrolled by US warplanes with the help of the RAF.

So the US would prefer to go it alone?
Far from it. The State Department argues that the UN can perform valuable service in protecting the interests of America, as the world's dominant military and economic power, without exposing US servicemen and women to peril. And US diplomats are regularly embarrassed by congressional calls for the UN to recompense Washington for what are, in reality, unilateral operations.

webTitle: Divorce magazine puts an upbeat gloss on the downside of marriage

fields.headline: Divorce magazine puts an upbeat gloss on the downside of marriage
fields.trailText: For the woman who wants to leave her good-for-nothing man but does not quite know how, there will soon be a glossy magazine with handy hints.
fields.body:
For the woman who wants to leave her good-for-nothing man but does not quite know how, there will soon be a glossy magazine with handy hints.

New Era is launched next month by publishers who have spotted a gap in the market. While there are plenty of titles to help you get hitched, there is nothing for when things come unstuck.

With a print run of 100,000, a celebrity divorcee on the cover of each issue and a column by one of the lawyers involved in the divorce of Diana, Princess of Wales, the 116-page bi-monthly magazine is aiming for big sales.

Lesley Neil, its editor and a divorcee, said the magazine would begin where other women's titles end: at the altar.

It will provide serious features on the financial implications of splitting up and advice on how to break the news to children.

But there would be a positive side too, said Ms Neil. "New Era is essentially upbeat. We'll be giving people the confidence to handle their first date as a newly single person and showing them the best way to meet a new partner. Divorce is a time for change, and we intend to approach it in a positive way to show there is life after marriage."

David Cordrey, the publishing director, said research had shown that women turned to their usual general interest magazines for help at the time of divorce but found nothing geared to their needs. "They are hungry for information about their legal and financial rights and also for emotional support. There is no one source of information that covers all those issues."

He said the magazine would draw on the advice of a panel of experts, including Peter Watson-Lee, vice chairman of the Law Society's family law committee, a psychologist, a child psychologist and a financial adviser. Sandra Davis of the law firm Mischon de Reya, who worked with Anthony Julius, the lead lawyer in Princess Diana's divorce, will also contribute.

"Divorce is one of the few times in your life when you realise your assets, such as insurance policies, property and so on," said Mr Cordrey.

But New Era would also be entertaining, featuring women who had undergone big image changes after a divorce, such as Margaret Cook, former wife of the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and Julia Carling, the ex of the former England rugby union captain Will Carling.

webTitle: dot.com thrives on boys' toys

fields.headline: dot.com thrives on boys' toys
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: A table ice hockey game is the first thing you see when entering the office of Firebox.com, a company that is flourishing by selling completely frivolous items at a time when many net retailers are floundering.
fields.body:
A table ice hockey game is the first thing you see when entering the office of Firebox.com, a company that is flourishing by selling completely frivolous items at a time when many net retailers are floundering.

The brainchild of two Birmingham university friends, Michael Smith and Tom Boardman, Firebox.com sells toys and gadgets for men aged 18 to 34. Opened for business two years ago, Firebox took off when customers began snapping up a shot glass chess set in droves from its website. Popshots, a variant on the old pistols that shoot a rubber sucker, was another item that found favour with the punters.

Firebox's success has not gone unnoticed. Last week, Dennis Publishing, publishers of Maxim, the glossy men's lifestyle magazine, took a 5% equity stake in Firebox, whose site carries the logo "where men buy stuff". In addition, Firebox announced plans to raise £1m through a private placement of shares with EO, the online equity company for retail investors.

Smith, who started Firebox with a £1,000 loan from his mother, attributes his company's success to several factors. By their nature, Firebox's products appeal to grown-up male journalists who apparently like write about new toys.

So the company spends virtually nothing on marketing while other dot.coms burn up money on massive advertising campaigns to establish themselves as brand names. Boo.com came to grief partly because it wasted so much money this way.

Advertising may generate traffic, but traffic in itself does not necessarily add up to sales, Smith argues. "Above-the-line advertising may attract traffic, but the critical thing is what happens after that. You have to convert visitors to buyers and buyers to advocates," he says, adding that for many e-tailers, conversion of visitors to buyers has been very low.

Another reason for Firebox's success is the high margins of its products, unlike books and CDs. Some products, bought from an array of over 70 suppliers, have average gross profit margins of over 40%.

"We're selling products people haven't seen before and our customers are in their 20s, people with relatively high disposable income," Smith said. "It means we can grow very fast without a big marketing budget."

While Firebox has carved out a nice niche for itself, the faddish nature of the market means the company has to be constantly on the lookout for new products to keep sales going and to keep its site fresh. Smith and his three partners (who share a house - so they live, eat and breathe toys) cull magazines and visit trade fairs for ideas. But as the company's reputation spreads, companies are now sending them products.

Corx, a new, decidedly low-tech game, is Firebox's next big hope. Consisting of two corks coloured red at one end and black at the other, contestants win points depending on what colour comes up when they bounce the corks on a flat surface.

"We're going back to low-tech," says Smith, who believes there will be a resurgence of such products that appeal to kids as well as adults. "Corx is very stylish and has a funky appeal. There hasn't been anything like it before."

While the appeal of bouncing a couple of corks may seem dubious, selling toys for adults on the net has proven to be a winning proposition so far, with Firebox heading towards sales of £2m this year. But like many dot.com companies, there are no hard and fast predictions on when it will actually turn a profit.

webTitle: Inside the Personal Digital Assistants (PDA) market

fields.headline: The companies leading the way in the PDA market
fields.standfirst: In the burgeoning market of personal digital assistants (PDAs), leading computer companies are having to work hard to stay ahead of the competition both in terms of price and technological advances
fields.trailText: In the burgeoning market of personal digital assistants (PDAs), leading computer companies are having to work hard to stay ahead of the competition both in terms of price and technological advances, writes Amy Vickers
fields.body:
What's a PDA?

The term PDA, or personal digital assistant, was coined by John Sculley, former CEO of Apple Computers, back in 1992. Until recently, PDAs were nothing more than electronic versions of filofaxes, comprising calendars and address books with tiny keyboards and murky LCD displays. The arrival of the PalmPilot in 1996, a handheld device with an elegant user interface and a character-recognition system that actually worked, changed all this. Palm computers were a runaway success, catapulting the company into the lead in the handheld PC market with around 70-80% market share, strides ahead of its nearest competitor, Microsoft PocketPC.

Other market competitors include Handspring, set up two years ago by the brains behind the PalmPilot, and a strong component of cheap, basic PDAs for the mass market.

Handspring's entry price - £150-£199 - has sent tremors though Palm Computing, whose lowest entry point before its Handspring clone (the Palm m100) was in excess of £200. Market newcomer Handspring has proved a point or two with its low-priced Visor, which cleverly targeted the youth market and won, and now commands roughly a quarter of the US PDA market. The reason for its popularity is simple: it was built for add-ons, such as an MP3 player, a webcam and a digital camera - all can simply be slotted into its Springboard expansion slot.

Other major manufacturers in the PDA arena include Casio, Compaq, Hewlett Packard and Psion.

Different devices

There are basically three major lines of PDAs: those with a Palm operating system (OS), those with a Windows operating system and Psion devices. Palm Computing, a division of 3Com, is the market leader:

Palm Computing

While the new PocketPCs contain everything but the kitchen sink, the Palm devices have the edge in simplicity. If you don't want to use the devices for listening to music, browsing the internet, or working in documents that can be easily transferred to a computer, then you may be better off with a Palm or Handspring device, particularly if all you want to do is traditional PDA functions (calendar, contact and to-do list).

Palm Computing's long-term strategy is to concentrate its efforts on licensing handheld operating systems, making products and services for wireless internet services, portal sites and Palm-branded devices.

Palm's flagship product is the Palm IIIc, the only colour handheld it produces, which is priced at £349. Even though this offers more functionality than other Palms on the market, such as browsing the internet and a full screen agenda view, it still only has 8MB of memory. The other popular Palm device is the Palm Vx which has an ultra-slim design that really does live up to its pocket size claims.

With all Palm devices, the user has to learn the shorthand-style alphabet, called Graffiti, which is fairly tedious but worth the hassle. PocketPCs on the other hand have a transcriber function that automatically recognises most handwriting and types it into a Word document. Perhaps the biggest benefit Palm has over PocketPCs though, is that it can synch with both Macintosh computers and PCs, whereas PocketPCs only work in tandem with PC devices (ie Microsoft operating systems).

PocketPC

Recognising that computing is not necessarily going to be done at a fixed desk PC in the future, PocketPC is Microsoft's bid not to be excluded from any computing-related developments in the mobile market. Not only does PocketPC allow Microsoft to extend its Windows operating system to handheld and smaller devices, it also allows Microsoft to wrestle a share of the market from Palm Computing, which currently enjoys around 80% market share in the PDA market.

Microsoft designed the Windows CE operating system for small devices and has licensed it to a number of manufacturers, including HP, Compaq, Casio, and Symbol who make the Pocket PC devices.

The latest generation of PocketPCs have been built to impress, and more profoundly, keep Palm on its toes. The devices are essentially mini powerful computers that have many of the applications and multimedia capabilities of the average PC. Best of all, the miniature versions of Microsoft Office applications (word, excel, outlook express) means greater synchronisation between the PDA and the desktop computer. Another advantage PocketPCs have over Palm devices is their expansion capabilities that enable a greater range of accessories to be added onto the devices (digital cameras, GPRS).

In terms of look and feel, the new generation of PocketPCs are smaller and have evolved to look more like Palm devices. Given the memory capabilities (16MB as opposed to Palm's 8MB) and colour screen, PocketPCs are still heavier than Palms and Psions, but then the fact that the PocketPC offers so many more services than other PDAs, this is not necessarily such a cumbersome drawback.

Other services offered by a PocketPC over the other PDAs include digital image viewing, a voice recorder, games, an internet browser, MP3 and Microsoft Player audio capabilities and a book reader for digital books. The most popular lines are the HP Jornada, priced at around £300, and the Compaq Ipaq, priced at around £330.

At present, PocketPCs enjoy approximately 15% of the PDA market, and are expected to grab anything up to 40% of the market within three years.

Psion

Homegrown firm, Psion, has a large percentage of the European market but has yet to make any inroads into the US market. Its Revo device (priced around £260) is its only device that qualifies as a palm-size device, and it is also the only one that contains a real keyboard. It runs on Psion's EPOC operating system, which is extremely fast. However, it is an unlit monochrome screen.

The Psion 5MX, priced at £429, is really just a tiny PC that contains a word processor, spreadsheet, web browsing and emails, scheduling and contact lists. Like the Palm products, it can also be hooked up to a Mac, and is surprisingly easy to use.

Internet browsing on PDA

The closest thing the handheld market has to a standard for communications protocol and mark-up language is WAP (Wireless Access Protocol), and given the amount of momentum behind it, WAP looks as though it could become the mark-up language of the handheld world. However it could be a two horse race with some operators already pre-installing Microsoft HTML browsers alongside Wap browsers, and Wap being likened to Netscape at the start of the browser wars.

Content for PDAs

Talk to a PDA owner about downloading content onto the devices, and it's pretty much guaranteed that they'll tell you they synch their device with AvantGo. What this means is when they store their PDA in a cradle (its holder) that is connected to their PC, it automatically communicates with the computer and downloads certain preferences from the web in a matter of minutes. Two-year-old start-up AvantGo has positioned itself up as the leader in this field by collecting and reformatting content from providers such as the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, CNN, Wired News, The Guardian and The Industry Standard. Palm's parent company, 3Com, has already signed a deal with AOL to offer AOL email to Palm users in exchange for AOL offering a special deal on a Palm III, packaged with modem, to its members, and a Palm version of AOL. Yahoo bought up Online Anywhere, a company that reformats and repackages web-based content for PDAs in June, and Excite has partnered with Starfish for PDA content distribution.

New entrants are currently making their way into the burgeoning PDA market. Sony Electronics, for example, has just launched the Clie, a multimedia PDA based on Palm operating software that looks suspiciously like a Palm V. Priced at around £350, the Clie is expected to be available in the UK towards the end of the year.

Given the fiddly nature of PDA handhelds, it is highly unlikely that they will ever truly replace desktop computers, rather they will continue to act as a complement and become more closely integrated with the PC. What seems to be the case is that they will be the medium of choice for business people on the move that need to reschedule appointments, get directions and access inventory and sales data. Once better services come to market and GPRS attachments are mainstream, PDAs are set to become the preferred means of buying tickets, books, software and CDs, checking bank accounts, travel details, weather reports and retrieving the latest news.

Case study: Jim Kennedy, BBC Worldwide

"The best thing about a PDA is the ability to download mail at work and go off to sit on a bench in the sun and pop off a few replies. The ability to suddenly sit bolt upright in my loft bed when I get a killer idea and write the e-mail immediately rather than climb down the cold steel ladder, and blunder half naked downstairs to sit in the freezing cold typing on my Home PC really appeals. It's the instant accessibility and portability that I hope will be liberating.

"I single-handedly plan, compile, edit and output three half-hour news programmes each week for BBC World. I write a lot of emails and tend to fire them off from the BBC desktop Ü because time is always a scarce commodity.

"So pressing gets dealt with after the programmes are put together on a Saturday. I know I could relay any mails using outlook to my home email address, but I'm attracted by the idea that I can download these mails from work onto the Pocket PC and deal with them at home seated in an armchair or perhaps on a bus. Then next morning just pop the HP Jornada into its holder socket and the mails would get sent. Hey presto.

"The MP3 facility is also fascinating, as are the cut down web pages. I've not got a WAP or a mobile phone so I've been checking out the Ericsson mobile that has a modem facility and also looking in the Loot classified ads for a suitable Gold Card - I'm due to seek advice as to what is the best alternative.

"Basically the idea is to be able to sit in a doctor's waiting room or outside department store changing rooms (where one seems to spend the most wasted time) and get online and perhaps use that time more efficiently/profitably. I start my week on a Wednesday but the rest of BBC World starts on a Monday and I'm forever getting two/three-day-old emails from correspondents in far-flung places offering longer versions of features or news stories for my Reporters programme. webTitle: History comes second to a hot bath

fields.headline: History comes second to a hot bath
fields.standfirst: Celebration is the last thing on Atherton's mind after crucial century
fields.trailText: For Michael Atherton, there was no outward sense of excitement, no obvious thrill that thanks to his herculean resistance, an impressive England summer should be duly confirmed today by a Test series victory. There was just an exhausted satisfaction, and probably an unrevealed longing for a hot bath and a lie-down, which after more than 12 hours batting at the Oval was perfectly understandable.
fields.body:
For Michael Atherton, there was no outward sense of excitement, no obvious thrill that thanks to his herculean resistance, an impressive England summer should be duly confirmed today by a Test series victory. There was just an exhausted satisfaction, and probably an unrevealed longing for a hot bath and a lie-down, which after more than 12 hours batting at the Oval was perfectly understandable.

Long after he has retired, perhaps Atherton will care to consider where his 15th Test hundred ranks in the canon.

If not, pity the doting kid who one day pipes up: "How well did you bat that time, Grandad?" only to receive the invariable response of "All right, I suppose" and the offer of a brawn sandwich.

Distance lends the chance to assess, to order hundreds in terms of importance; an hour or so after he had stripped off his pads was not distance enough. Atherton press conferences also have the texture of a brawn sandwich: unappealing and hard to digest. This hundred, in Atherton's judgment, ranked in the canon as "satisfying", which places it somewhere between one and 15.

It is probably in the top six, just out of the medals. The pitch was wearing, the bowling - from Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh - insistent, and England's need to avoid defeat had provided a match situation Atherton could relish.

There had been loose talk, too, that he might be dropped. Had that driven him? "I don't think anyone has a divine right to a place in the side, but conditions have been difficult for openers this summer," he said. "You have to keep faith in yourself."

The same truth applies to Nasser Hussain, whose Test summer amounts to 148 runs at 12.33 with a highest score of 25.

On the verge of his greatest success as England captain, he had made his first pair in Test cricket and described it as "a crushing personal disappointment".

Atherton provided solace. "He is a proven Test player," he said. "There is no doubt he will score runs in Test cricket. He is doing a good job leading the side and all the team are behind him."

Hussain wrote in his newspaper diary of having "to sit down at the end of the match and get my mind sorted out".

"Is it the captaincy that is doing this to me? Am I putting too much into all the things that go with the captaincy and not leaving enough in the tank for batting? I don't know but I am aware that something needs to be done for my peace of mind.

"I do think I am captaining the side well but I am not fulfilling my role in the team. It is a hugely disappointing time for me individually but the most important thing is English cricket."

England captains have been pilloried in the past for similar failures, but happily his failures remain in context, with a recognition of his central contribution to England's well-being. The mood remains one of sympathy and regret.

England have shone with collective purpose under Hussain's leadership and, however disturbed he has been by his personal failures, he has done everything to ensure that this does not intrude to the detriment of the team.

Those who wondered aloud whether Hussain's individual ambitions would occasionally swamp his team ethic have had their answer.

He needs to make runs soon, naturally. But, for the moment, a time of prolonged failure has, in its way, proved to be his greatest triumph.

webTitle: Curtly is curt to the end

fields.headline: Curtly is curt to the end
fields.trailText: And today, we all presume, will be the day. Nasser Hussain will lift the long-forgotten Wisden Trophy; the crowd will run on the field, chant happily and maybe even sing; Jimmy Adams, the vanquished captain, will be gracious; and Lord MacLaurin, a member of the Raymond Illingworth School of letting-everyone-know-who-fathered -victory-and-ensuring-defeat-is-an-orphan, will probably be more visible than usual.
fields.body:
And today, we all presume, will be the day. Nasser Hussain will lift the long-forgotten Wisden Trophy; the crowd will run on the field, chant happily and maybe even sing; Jimmy Adams, the vanquished captain, will be gracious; and Lord MacLaurin, a member of the Raymond Illingworth School of letting-everyone-know-who-fathered -victory-and-ensuring-defeat-is-an-orphan, will probably be more visible than usual.

It was Saturday morning when expectation hardened to near certainty. The moment can even be timed exactly: 11.43am. That was when Brian Lara was yet again bewildered by Craig White (a sentence one could not have anticipated writing only a few weeks ago). The Sun has been running a Wisdenometer, similar to the swingometer used on pre-computer election nights. At that point, it crashed towards England with the crunching certainty of the moment Portillo lost or Labour gained Hove.

The fourth day of the Test (and that's an unexpected form of words too these days) was a linking passage between the catharsis of Saturday and the expected triumph today. It was a day of ovations, after a summer of them. The biggest came in Curtly Ambrose's last over in Test match cricket. But it was nothing to do with Ambrose: he was just the feed as Mike Atherton reached his century.

As the crowd erupted, Ambrose stood impassively. He produced two more unmemorable deliveries then moved, on tender legs, towards the outfield and then cricketing history. You could almost SEE him creak. What a way to go.

Six and a half years ago in Port of Spain, Ambrose blew away the aspirations of Athers, the tyro England captain, with one of the most devastating bowling bursts of all time. England were out for 46 - and defeat was such an orphan that even the team manager, MJK Smith, failed to support Atherton at his mournful press conference.

Now Ambrose, and Courtney Walsh with him, has had to learn the truth that eagles can't soar when they are surrounded by turkeys. When Atherton was last man out (a few minutes after we had looked up all the carried-bat stats) the West Indians let him have his moment. The fast bowlers held back. Then it was their turn.

Ambrose says he will never play Test cricket again. There is limited pleasure in a forthcoming tour of Australia in which West Indies will regard avoiding a 5-0 whitewash as their prime objective. Walsh is carrying on, because he is that sort, and because the virgin, mist-shrouded peak of 500 Test wickets is only 17 away.

But even he cannot expect to bowl in a major match here again. So they both had their moment in the September sunshine. Walsh grinned and waved; Ambrose was more sombre. But they punched each other's fists, embraced and squabbled for a second about who would go first: "After you, Courtney." "No, after you, Curtly." Walsh won that round, and sent Ambrose in.

And that was that. If we are ever going to see a great West Indian fast bowler tormenting our brave boys again, it is not obvious who, when or how. The mysterious factory that produced them all is shuttered and silent. There was a time when the line seemed endless, and it infiltrated batsmen's nightmares like the row of Banquo's crowned descendants haunting Macbeth. In the 1980s, supply so far exceeded demand that such players as Sylvester Clarke, Wayne Daniel, Ezra Moseley and Winston Davis, who would all have passed 100 Tests for England, hardly got a game.

For the last time, we saw Ambrose stamp the ground, then lope in threateningly like a mutant killer giraffe. To the end, he provided living proof that precision bombing from a great height is possible. Perhaps the RAF should engage him as a consultant.

Andy Roberts was perhaps the most ferocious of all the West Indians; Malcolm Marshall the most technically perfect; Michael Holding the most artistic; Walsh the most durable. But to the very end Ambrose was the most infallibly unhittable of them all. He got no wicket yesterday and so the wicket of Marcus Trescothick on Saturday was when his mum's famous bell rang for the 405th and final time.

He will be remembered with affection by his team-mates, a shudder by opponents and awe by all who saw him. But for a man with such expressive features, he was remarkably inscrutable. Courtney was courtly; to strangers - especially scribblers - Curtly preferred to be curt. Even last night he chose to keep his thoughts to himself, living up to the anecdote about the time he overheard a journalist ask Viv Richards whether Curtly was feeling fit or not. "You want to know about Curtly, you talk to Curtly," he growled.

"OK, Curtly. How are you feeling?"

"Curtly talks to no one," he replied.

Now Ambrose, and Courtney Walsh with him, has had to learn the truth that eagles can't soar when they are surrounded by turkeys. When Atherton was last man out (a few minutes after we had looked up all the carried-bat stats) the West Indians let him have his moment. The fast bowlers held back. Then it was their turn. Ambrose says he will never play Test cricket again. There is limited pleasure in a forthcoming tour of Australia in which West Indies will regard avoiding a 5-0 whitewash as their prime objective. Walsh is carrying on, because he is that sort, and because the virgin, mist-shrouded peak of 500 Test wickets is only 17 away. But even he cannot expect to bowl in a major match here again. So they both had their moment in the September sunshine. Walsh grinned and waved; Ambrose was more sombre. But they punched each other's fists, embraced and squabbled for a second about who would go first: "After you, Courtney." "No, after you, Curtly." Walsh won that round, and sent Ambrose in. And that was that. If we are ever going to see a great West Indian fast bowler tormenting our brave boys again, it is not obvious who, when or how. The mysterious factory that produced them all is shuttered and silent. There was a time when the line seemed endless, and it infiltrated batsmen's nightmares like the row of Banquo's crowned descendants haunting Macbeth. In the 1980s, supply so far exceeded demand that such players as Sylvester Clarke, Wayne Daniel, Ezra Moseley and Winston Davis, who would all have passed 100 Tests for England, hardly got a game. For the last time, we saw Ambrose stamp the ground, then lope in threateningly like a mutant killer giraffe. To the end, he provided living proof that precision bombing from a great height is possible. Perhaps the RAF should engage him as a consultant. Andy Roberts was perhaps the most ferocious of all the West Indians; Malcolm Marshall the most technically perfect; Michael Holding the most artistic; Walsh the most durable. But to the very end Ambrose was the most infallibly unhittable of them all. He got no wicket yesterday and so the wicket of Marcus Trescothick on Saturday was when his mum's famous bell rang for the 405th and final time. He will be remembered with affection by his team-mates, a shudder by opponents and awe by all who saw him. But for a man with such expressive features, he was remarkably inscrutable. Courtney was courtly; to strangers - especially scribblers - Curtly preferred to be curt. Even last night he chose to keep his thoughts to himself, living up to the anecdote about the time he overheard a journalist ask Viv Richards whether Curtly was feeling fit or not. "You want to know about Curtly, you talk to Curtly," he growled. "OK, Curtly. How are you feeling?" "Curtly talks to no one," he replied.

webTitle: Micky Tudor and Brian Turner of Lowe Lintas

fields.headline: Micky Tudor and Brian Turner of Lowe Lintas
fields.standfirst: Their best work, they say, has yet to be seen.
fields.trailText: Their best work, they say, has yet to be seen.
fields.body:
"It was the most exciting thing in the world," is how Micky Tudor describes landing his first job in advertising. It was at GGT and the two of them were made redundant six months later, yet their enthusiasm for the business remains undiminished.

The pair claim that an upcoming spot they have produced for Reebok will bring the brand back onto a par with Nike and Adidas. In the meantime, the two economics graduates have revitalised Heineken's ads with the "How refreshing, how Heineken" campaign. They also made a memorable ad for Labatt Ice in which a man wears a T-shirt bearing the slogan "My puppy just died" so that people will hug him and keep him warm while he drinks the cold beer.

"We are influenced by anything that isn't advertising," Tudor says. "You've always got to be different."
