webTitle: Scots in 'off to a World Cup flyer' shock

fields.headline: Scots in 'off to a World Cup flyer' shock
fields.standfirst: Latvia 0 - 1 Scotland McCann 89
fields.trailText: In their gloomier moments many Scots share a conviction that the gods have it in for them. On the football field, a tear-stained tapestry of past cock-ups and calamities has done nothing to diminish this sense of divine wrath.
fields.body:
In their gloomier moments many Scots share a conviction that the gods have it in for them. On the football field, a tear-stained tapestry of past cock-ups and calamities has done nothing to diminish this sense of divine wrath.

This result in the Latvian capital, though, will surely nail some of that cosmic paranoia. There was nothing about this opening World Cup group six qualifier that was either wicked or cruel for Scotland.

On the contrary, events amid the wheezing massed bagpipes and the equally raucous home fans' cheers in the new Skonto stadium on Saturday only served to show that the Scots are occasionally granted great mercies.

Indeed, Latvia played so much delightfully taut football that it was impossible not to feel sympathy for them at the finish. After driving at the Scots for 88 minutes, the hosts had to endure the sight of Neil McCann popping up five yards from goal to prod the ball past a disbelieving Aleks Kolinko.

That cast Scotland into the unfamiliar and perhaps uncomfortable role of getting off to a World Cup flyer.

At the very moment of McCann's goal, all 1,000-odd of the kilted horde looked on through eyes glazed with drink wondering if what they had seen had actually happened. As the Tartan Army swaggered off for one last night of Riga refuelling, their banter was not the usual paean about glorious misfortune. Scotland, for once, got lucky.

Craig Brown can rarely have felt such gratitude in his seven years in charge of Scotland. After 62 internationals he clearly feels little inclination to alter old tricks and his team for this match took the field with precisely half their outfield consisting of strapping defenders - Tommy Boyd, Colin Hendry, Matt Elliott, Christian Dailly, David Weir, the list seemed endless.

Against the gloom of Scotland's past, Brown protects himself with brawn. There were enough big limbs and stretched torsos in this side to have satisfied a crowd at Murrayfield.

It was not up there alongside the Sistine Chapel as an aesthetic experience. Elliott, for one, was asked to turn out in his old Leicester pantomime act as a striker, offering glimpses of lumbering menace in an otherwise hopeless first half for the Scots.

With Elliott at centre-forward, Don Hutchison withdrawn to midfield and Neil Sullivan kept busy in goal, Englishmen were at the centre of everything the Scots toiled with. A harassed Brown changed his tactics at half-time to stanch a flow of Latvian attacks.

This former enclave of the old Soviet Union is clearly bounding forward in football development. No one who has seen Marian Pahars at Southampton needs reminding of his stealth when the mood takes him. But in Andrejs Stolcers of Spartak Moscow and the excellent Igor Stepanovs of Skonto Riga - said to be the purpose of the watching Arsène Wenger's visit - the Latvians have players to cherish.

Latvia are managed by an English coach, Gary Johnson, a Cockney sparrow who came in afterwards looking hangdog with despair. Pahars and Stolcers having run Scotland ragged for 88 minutes, Johnson was full of cor-blimey bafflement at how his team managed to lose.

"Football is cruel," he said. "But I've told my players that if they can play like that we can certainly beat Belgium in our next qualifier next month."

Scotland's manager came out with the time-honoured portrait of his team, lauding Scotland's "determination and fighting spirit" that finally clinched these points.

Given the general reaction to the pinching of these points, poor Brown must think his fellow countrymen are a twisted lot. For 11 months of the year the Scots bemoan their wretched luck. Then, when they steal a win, it is accepted almost grudgingly.

Brown was having none of that. "We can't afford to be too hard on ourselves. I've got limited resources in terms of players. An international manager just can't go into the transfer market and buy players."

webTitle: McInnes on the mark for Megson

fields.headline: McInnes on the mark for Megson
fields.trailText: West Bromwich Albion celebrated a century of football yesterday in somewhat subdued fashion, resisting the temptation to remind their fans of former glories. Which, with the team languishing near the foot of the First Division before kick-off, was probably just as well.
fields.body:
West Bromwich Albion celebrated a century of football yesterday in somewhat subdued fashion, resisting the temptation to remind their fans of former glories. Which, with the team languishing near the foot of the First Division before kick-off, was probably just as well.

Instead a firework display staged in bright sunshine and the current crop of players hacking a hundred footballs into the crowd were far more in keeping with recent boardroom shenanigans and on-field underachievement.

And as if to endorse the decision, Albion provided yet another false dawn by following a sparkling display in the first half with an indifferent one in the second, during which crossbar-rattling headers from Leon McKenzie and Neil Ruddock almost salvaged a point for the visitors.

Ruddock began with his head bandaged to protect an injury. By half-time the padding must have been serving as a useful stopcock to prevent steam escaping from the burly defender's ears after he and his colleagues had been given a thorough chasing by Lee Hughes.

Quick of feet and turn, Hughes pulled the Palace defence every which way but failed to capitalise with a goal. Three times he found himself one on one with Stuart Taylor but each time the Palace goalkeeper saved.

Hughes did atone for his profligacy, however, by playing a key part in Albion's winning goal. Collecting a pass from Ruel Fox, he once again scampered past Ruddock before delivering a neat chip for Derek McInnes to fire home.

McInnes went on to give another man-of-the-match display but the Albion manager Gary Megson does not expect him to score many goals.

"We were practising finishing on the day he signed for us so I told him to take the day off and return for our tackling sessions," Megson joked about the player he spent the best part of the summer trying to buy from the French club Toulouse.

Megson's interest in the 29-year-old midfielder goes back further than last summer, however.

"I had him on loan from Rangers when I was at Stockport County but we couldn't afford to take him permanently," Megson said. "And we couldn't have afforded to have him here had he not agreed to a 60% pay cut.

"That's the type of player he is. He wants to play football and that is why I made him skipper before he'd met the players."

McInnes's powers of leadership were tested to the full as Palace swapped their first-half lethargy for second-half ambition and made life extremely uncomfortable for Albion with long stretches of domination.

They did the same in their previous match, when they beat Nottingham Forest 3-2, but their manager Alan Smith is not impressed.

"My players have got to learn they are paid for working seven days a week rather than just 45 minutes," he said. "This is the second game on the bounce we've done that and you've got to ask yourself why."

Smith revealed that his 78-year-old mother did not bother to ask any questions after watching the first half on television. She just switched off.

A bit like Albion, in fact.

webTitle: Laurie Smith & Matthew Pam of Alphabet

fields.headline: Laurie Smith & Matthew Pam of Alphabet
fields.standfirst: Advertising's most high-profile face, Trevor Beattie, recommended this young pair.
fields.trailText: Advertising's most high-profile face, Trevor Beattie, recommended this young pair.
fields.body:
Laurie Smith and Matthew Pam impressed Trevor Beattie when they arrived at TBWA on a placement, but he wanted them to go out into the world for a year before he would think about offering them a full-time job.

They helped TBWA to win a pitch for a campaign to promote a new series of Crossroads, and also got the chance to create an ad for FCUK watches and see their FCUK T-shirts designs on sale in stores.

At Alphabet, they have created ads for more prosaic clients, including a financial services brand, a community television channel, a car wax and a Jill Dando fund. But they are enjoying the chance to be involved in ads from start to finish.

It is the sort of opportunity you rarely get at bigger agencies. Smith and Pam both studied graphic design but went into advertising because they enjoy real-life problem-solving rather than just making things look nice.

"It's important to do ads that get noticed. Otherwise you're just wasting the client's money," Smith says.

webTitle: Graydon repays faith of the fans

fields.headline: Graydon repays faith of the fans
fields.trailText: Five wins out of five for Walsall means more than a record-breaking start to a season for their manager Ray Graydon.
fields.body:
Five wins out of five for Walsall means more than a record-breaking start to a season for their manager Ray Graydon.

Not only does it justify the vote of confidence he was given by the club's directors and supporters after relegation from the First Division, but it confirms that the team spirit and togetherness Graydon insists on is very much alive.

Despite demotion after only one season in the First Division, not one of more than 300 letters received by Graydon during the summer was critical of him. All were supportive, a view the board shared.

Instead of replacing him they allowed him to bring in eight new players, one of whom, the Portuguese striker Jorge Leitao, cost £150,000 - the most the club has spent on a player since paying £175,000 for Alan Buckley 21 years ago.

Yet for Graydon the changes could have backfired. "The disappointment of relegation plus the arrival of eight new faces could have harmed the spirit and togetherness we had," he explained. "But the fact we've won three of our games coming from behind suggests otherwise.

"This team also knows how to battle but I thought it might take longer so our good start is a real bonus."

There was plenty of evidence of the never-say-die ethos against Wigan, who are expected to be among Walsall's challengers for promotion. And there needed to be after Bruce Rioch's team, stung by two goals in the first 16 minutes, pitched camp in Walsall territory for the remaining hour and a quarter.

Leitao's early goal, after essential spadework from Brett Angell, was his fourth in five games; his comparatively hefty transfer fee is already proving a bargain. Not that Graydon had any doubts about the 26-year-old's ability to score, although one aspect of his game did trouble him.

"He scored a hat-trick in the first half of a pre-season friendly at Raith Rovers but I took him off at the break because he wasn't defending enough," Graydon said.

In terms of defending, Leitao has proved himself a quick learner, as have his colleagues. "Despite our wins we've let in some very soft goals so I was delighted we kept a clean sheet against Wigan," Graydon said.

Angell was also the force behind Walsall's second, a rare goal from Dean Keates and the side's 15th in five games.

For all Wigan's pressure James Walker had only one direct shot to save. All of which added up to an afternoon of frustration for Rioch. "The goals we conceded were soft ones and that's very uncharacteristic of our defending," he lamented. "But Walsall are a good side and I expect them to score goals against anybody."

webTitle: John Burley and Ian Williamson of HHCL & Partners

fields.headline: John Burley and Ian Williamson of HHCL & Partners
fields.standfirst: Remember the Tango "megaphone" ad?
fields.trailText: Remember the Tango "megaphone" ad?
fields.body:
The recently banned Tango "megaphone" ad was deemed to encourage bullying. This is the team responsible.

John Burley pleads convincingly that they were disappointed at public's reaction and "appalled" at the thought that their ad might encourage bullying.

Their other commercials expose a more sensitive approach to writing ads. They created the poignant commercial in which an Automobile Association employee is called to fix the car of his ex-girlfriend. But then they also created the "Jack and Jill" Iceland spots, which featured two animated figures banging their heads against a wall to demonstrate their frustration at the public's stupidity.

They have tried unemployment, graphic design and working in a tax office, but when they stumbled on a career in advertising and built a trusting partnership, they knew they had found their vocation.

Ian Williamson and Burley have also created ads for Mecca Bingo, Tate & Lyle, Bravo channel and Metz. "We take advertising seriously because it is our job and there's a lot of money at stake. But it's dangerous to get too arty about it. The most enjoyable aspect is creating radical work that actually sells products," Burley says.

webTitle: Lee in at the shallow end

fields.headline: Lee in at the shallow end
fields.trailText: "Wolves in crisis" may be exaggeration. Crises decline with age and for 16 years Wolves have been out of the top division, where their chairman Sir Jack Hayward has invested heavily for them to be.
fields.body:
"Wolves in crisis" may be exaggeration. Crises decline with age and for 16 years Wolves have been out of the top division, where their chairman Sir Jack Hayward has invested heavily for them to be.

The man in crisis may be the manager Colin Lee, approaching two years of progress without promotion or now, after five points from five games, much prospect of it. Hayward's readiness to go on funding has already worn thin. His patience cannot last much longer with a man who admitted his team "failed on basics and are not blessed with a lot of confidence". What are managers for?

Lee tried late to get the game put off for a third international call-up but Wales's Ryan Green did not count as first-team. Some of the rest, established players, barely qualified as such on this showing. "Injuries highlight how shallow we are," said Lee. The liveliness of the three substitutes he used suggested the depth was on the bench.

Temuri Ketsbaia, nominally a striker, was sucked ever deeper, as he tended to be at Newcastle, until he ended by his own left corner-flag where, frustrated by time-wasting, he delivered the centre that Gillingham were delaying.

Lee, picking up the latest managerial jargon, said: "We must take the positives from the match." These will not fill even a page of an album.

One man's grief is another's relief. Andy Hessenthaler, who like Lee stepped up into a breach, in his case caused by the summer departure of Peter Taylor to Leicester, was celebrating Gillingham's first-ever win in the First Division.

Relief had begun earlier, when the French fishermen opened up the ports to release the tailback of England hooligans on the Kentish roads to Paris. It came early in the match too as Wolves three times failed to make clearances emphatic and Junior Lewis, arriving stealthily at the far post, nodded in Nicky Southall's cross.

Lewis, 26, was one of Taylor's first signings last season from Hendon and a big influence in Gillingham's promotion. He is a leggy midfielder with a keen eye for the gap that needs plugging in defence and the other gap to burst through.

Hessenthaler talks to Taylor twice a week and admitted the club and he are still finding their feet. His own, with a fine disregard for energy tax, covered every inch of the field. "I know we've got to play to our maximum every game," he said, after leading by splendid example. It helped that Wolves were close to their minimum.

Even so, as the game wore on without a second goal, Gillingham mounted their own blockade. They had scored first in three of their previous games and grew increasingly anxious. "A dangerous score, 1-0," said Hessenthaler. With wisdom like that he will soon be calling himself Andrew. As Lee will know, 0-1 is riskier.

Andy Hessenthaler, who like Lee stepped up into a breach, in his case caused by the summer departure of Peter Taylor to Leicester, was celebrating Gillingham's first-ever win in the First Division. Relief had begun earlier, when the French fishermen opened up the ports to release the tailback of England hooligans on the Kentish roads to Paris. It came early in the match too as Wolves three times failed to make clearances emphatic and Junior Lewis, arriving stealthily at the far post, nodded in Nicky Southall's cross. Lewis, 26, was one of Taylor's first signings last season from Hendon and a big influence in Gillingham's promotion. He is a leggy midfielder with a keen eye for the gap that needs plugging in defence and the other gap to burst through. Hessenthaler talks to Taylor twice a week and admitted the club and he are still finding their feet. His own, with a fine disregard for energy tax, covered every inch of the field. "I know we've got to play to our maximum every game," he said, after leading by splendid example. It helped that Wolves were close to their minimum. Even so, as the game wore on without a second goal, Gillingham mounted their own blockade. They had scored first in three of their previous games and grew increasingly anxious. "A dangerous score, 1-0," said Hessenthaler. With wisdom like that he will soon be calling himself Andrew. As Lee will know, 0-1 is riskier.

webTitle: Rob Potts and Andy Jex of Fallon

fields.headline: Rob Potts and Andy Jex of Fallon
fields.standfirst: These two have been remarkably successful in the four years since they left Watford College, but they are modest about their achievements.
fields.trailText: These two have been remarkably successful in the four years since they left Watford College, but they are modest about their achievements.
fields.body:
During a one-week placement at Mother, Rob Potts and Andy Jex came up with a Super Noodles ad that went on to win a silver arrow at the 1999 British Television Advertising Awards. BMP DDB gave them their first proper job, but they quickly followed their mentors - Richard Flintham and Andy McLeod - to Fallon, where they have created a well-received batch of press and poster ads for Starbucks, Timex and Nando's Chicken.

"I just fell into advertising," Potts says. "I suppose I'm good at being funny. The trick is not to try to copy anything else - just do what you do."

The team hopes to make a few more TV commercials. "We've had loads of briefs to work on; we just haven't cracked any."

webTitle: Irish give up wellies to steal Dutch clothes

fields.headline: Irish give up wellies to steal Dutch clothes
fields.standfirst:
Holland 2 Talan 71, Van Bronckhorst 84
Republic of Ireland 2 Robbie Keane 21, McAteer 65
fields.trailText: After a week of exhilarating peaks and excruciating troughs it was perhaps inevitable that Mick McCarthy came away from the Netherlands with so many conflicting emotions that he did not know whether he should be elated or deflated.
fields.body:
After a week of exhilarating peaks and excruciating troughs it was perhaps inevitable that Mick McCarthy came away from the Netherlands with so many conflicting emotions that he did not know whether he should be elated or deflated.

In the early hours of Sunday the Republic of Ireland manager was still too agitated to sleep. Instead he was propped up in a leather armchair, immersed in his thoughts in a piano bar overlooking the Noorder Amstel canal. A few hours earlier his players had not only ripped up the script for Louis van Gaal's first match in charge of Holland but played with such composure that the Dutch had been ashen-faced with stage fright. The Republic should have won but were pegged back. McCarthy looked shattered.

In his mind they had been but a small hop away from their finest victory since Ray Houghton shinned a volley over Italy's Gianluca Pagliuca in the 1994 World Cup. That his players had seized a two-goal lead was a source of immense pride. That they had frittered it away late on left a smouldering sense of irritation.

Judging by the way Gary Kelly punched the air in celebration while a few yards away Gary Breen was thumping the turf in disgust, his players had still to decide whether the result called for celebration or commiseration. But the breath-taking manner in which the Irish upstaged their illustrious opponents with an elaborate passing game - "We outplayed them," stated Kevin Kilbane - was a triumph in itself.

How ironic that McCarthy has brought about this transformation. Not long ago the craggy Yorkshireman was the broken-nosed epitome of Jack Charlton's hump-and-rush ne'er-do-wells. Certainly those who predicted that the Irish tactics would be of greater danger to the Amsterdam Arena's retractable roof than the Oranje defence were soon munching their way through a sizeable portion of humble pie. "They played a very good passing game," Van Gaal volunteered. "For a long time they were the superior team."

For McCarthy there could hardly have been a better reference. His credibility had been questioned since Mark Kennedy and Phil Babb were arrested for allegedly taking a night of the frothy brown stuff too far in Dublin last Monday. This was the perfect riposte to any potential detractors.

"People have suggested my players lack respect for me," he said. "You can look at that display and judge for yourself. We came to Holland, played them at their own game and matched them all the way."

The tub-thumping was understandable. Kilbane, Mark Kinsella and Jason McAteer arguably had their best games for the Republic. In defence it was scarcely plausible that Richard Dunne and Breen had experienced only 18 minutes' competitive action this season. Niall Quinn had his usual nuisance value and the coltish Robbie Keane just keeps on improving.

"We're good players and we've got to start giving ourselves more credit," said the captain Roy Keane. "People are always saying the Irish will have a good time whatever the result, and I'm sick of that stuff. We're better than that and we should stop underestimating ourselves."

Both Irish goals originated from incisive counter-attacks. Robbie Keane hurtled into the six-yard area to meet McAteer's right-wing cross on 21 minutes with a powerful header and then the Blackburn midfielder rounded off another flowing move with a swerving left-foot finish from 20 yards on 65.

But they could not keep it going. Having stayed at the hotel where John Lennon and Yoko Ono staged their sleep-in, the Irish defence showed a similar lethargy in allowing Jeffrey Talan a sloppy headed goal. Then, six minutes from time, Giovanni van Bronckhorst scored with the most venomous of left-foot shots, albeit with a deflection off Kinsella.

Holland (4-4-1-1): Van der Sar; Reiziger (Seedorf, h-t), F de Boer, Konterman (Talan, 65min), Van Bronckhorst; R de Boer, Witschge (Bruggink, 61), Bosvelt, Bouma; Cocu; Kluivert.

Republic of Ireland (4-4-2): A Kelly; Carr, Dunne, Breen, Harte; McAteer (G Kelly, 75), Roy Keane, Kinsella, Kilbane (Staunton, 80); N Quinn (Connolly, 72), Robbie Keane.

Referee: L Michel (Slovakia).

webTitle: Instant impact of true class

fields.headline: Instant impact of true class
fields.trailText: The firework artificers of the Stade de France were already priming the fuses for their spectacular post-match display when, in the 80th minute of Saturday night's game, the slight figure in the unfamiliar No16 shirt stepped across the touchline and on to the field of play.
fields.body:
The firework artificers of the Stade de France were already priming the fuses for their spectacular post-match display when, in the 80th minute of Saturday night's game, the slight figure in the unfamiliar No16 shirt stepped across the touchline and on to the field of play.

By that juncture, for all England's pleasing contribution to an engrossingly combative and eventful match, France should have wrapped it up with a hatful of goals and sent Laurent Blanc, Didier Deschamps and Bernard Lama into international retirement on the back of a valedictory win to go with the bouquets and party bags they received before the kick-off. But for Michael Owen, there were 10 minutes still available in which to use someone else's fete to make his personal point.

Owen is too cool and too shrewd to let us know what he thinks of Kevin Keegan's consistent refusal to endorse the opinion of the rest of the world, which is that the Liverpool striker is one of very, very few Englishmen entitled to call themselves world-class players. Perhaps, as a former Liverpool striker himself, the England coach is unable to view the 20-year-old's talent without prejudice, much as Glenn Hoddle's own past seemed to obscure his judgment of the similarly gifted David Beckham - a common and perfectly understandable human trait, but one that needs as much corrective attention in a football manager as it would in a military officer.

Keegan's decision to take a look at Andy Cole and Paul Scholes working together was a perfectly reasonable notion, particularly in the light of the posting to central midfield of David Beckham, their club colleague. But having taken the decision, Keegan really should have made it his business to ensure the world understood that this did not entail a demotion of Owen. Instead Keegan allowed it to seem like a slight, in succession to those delivered during Euro 2000, when he made it clear time and again that Owen was not worth trusting over the whole 90 minutes.

Owen wisely kept his own counsel, but his eventual riposte could hardly have been more conclusive. Either side of the decisive moment, he scarcely got a touch. But when Beckham and Steve McManaman built a move that brought the ball across the France penalty area from left to right, and when Kieron Dyer exploited the momentary absence of Bixente Lizarazu to dart down into the gap and slip a lethal cross into the goalmouth, there was Owen, anticipating the ball's path and arriving a yard in front of Frank Leboeuf before turning a magnificent volley - the perfect product of instinct and technique - past the previously impregnable Lama.

There can be no doubt now, even in Keegan's mind, about which Englishman is more likely to score international goals. Beckham? One goal in 35 appearances. Cole? None in eight. Emile Heskey? One in nine. Scholes, of course, has 10 in 28, including two hat-tricks, but he is a supporting player, not a chief striker. And Owen is the only one who ever looks likely to get you a goal out of nothing, as he did against Brazil in May.

Not that the Beckham-Scholes-Cole axis did badly on Saturday night, considering they were up against the world and European champions, and a four-man defence that had never been beaten as a unit and, in their last appearance together, had no intention of surrendering that proud record. England's approach play in the first half was fully the equal of France's, and their chances were the more clear-cut, although it has to be remembered that several key members of the home team have yet to begin their league seasons in Italy and Spain, and were clearly lacking the final competitive edge.

Yet the match itself had plenty of edge, in the sense that every player seemed aware of the fact that pride, individual and collective, was at stake. No doubt the recent influx of French players into the English league - and out again, trailing clouds of acrimony, in two or three cases - has added an extra dimension to the fixture, and there was more than enough harshness in the challenges to remove it entirely from the realm of meaningless friendlies.

Not unexpectedly, it was Dennis Wise wot started it, catching Zinedine Zidane on the side of the head inside the first minute. Just over an hour later Zidane took his revenge, barely bothering to glance at the resulting yellow card as he trotted away from the Chelsea man's prone form. Barely a minute later he had both made France's goal with a typically simple and lethal square pass to Emmanuel Petit, and left the pitch, replaced by Robert Pires.

Job done, or almost. In fact Pires finished it off, in one sense, catching Wise with such a spiteful foul two minutes into injury-time that the Chelsea man had to be carried into the dressing room, which will probably ensure Arsenal's new recruit a warm welcome when he turns out at Stamford Bridge on Wednesday night - although Pires himself was quoted in a French magazine last week as saying that while there is a lot of fighting and fouling in the English game, at least it's all forgotten with a handshake once the final whistle goes.

England will be pleased with their draw, but in the second half there were long periods when France played them off the park. A wonderfully spirited display from Thierry Henry and a dashing 45 minutes from Sylvain Wiltord should have produced more goals and, in a truly competitive environment, with no unforced substitutions, there could have been only one set of winners. But on a night on which an excellent game of football took second place to a set of emotional farewells, the home players were already tasting the champagne when Owen nipped in to end the contest, if not the celebrations, on a proper note of realism.

webTitle: Vic Polkinghorn and Nathan Cooper of St Luke's

fields.headline: Vic Polkinghorn and Nathan Cooper of St Luke's
fields.standfirst: This team already stands out after only 18 months together at one of London's most creative agencies.
fields.trailText: This team already stands out after only 18 months together at one of London's most creative agencies.
fields.body:
Vic Polkinghorn studied graphic design and Nathan Cooper initially chose fashion, but they both went into advertising because they wanted the opportunity to do work that is seen by a lot of people. "It's good to bring interesting ideas to things that aren't necessarily very interesting," Polkinghorn says.

So they created a complicated pop-up ad for Boots No7, and decided the best way to advertise Sky Sports was to set a commercial in a maternity ward.

The pair have made the most of the variety that a career in advertising offers. For a campaign to promote the Body Shop's human rights awards, they travelled all over the world to look at small-scale, grass-roots projects that make a real difference to people's lives.

So what makes them work so well together as a team? "We have different areas of knowledge, but we both like talking rubbish and don't mind offending each other," Pilkinghorn says.

webTitle: Justin Barnes and Ben Callis of Saatchi & Saatchi

fields.headline: Justin Barnes and Ben Callis of Saatchi & Saatchi
fields.standfirst: This creative team has been at Saatchi and Saatchi for six years, but has only just started to be recognised.
fields.trailText: This creative team has been at Saatchi and Saatchi for six years, but has only just started to be recognised.
fields.body:
This duo is described by their creative diorector, Dave Droga, as "My angry young team."

But they say: "We're not angry or aggressive, we're determined."

They have been at Saatchi & Saatchi - their first job - for six years, but have only recently started to get noticed. When the pair joined, they were part of the "Playpen" training scheme and they are still trying to live down their image as "those nutters from the playpen".

Barnes and Callis have created ads for most of Saatchi & Saatchi's big clients, including the Army and Sony. Their trademark campaign has been for internet recruitment site Monster.com. It uses lines such as "You are the rung on someone else's ladder" and "There's someone in your way - it's you."

Barnes says: "Sometimes you have to be direct. You can't always flatter people into buying your product. We like to get into people's heads and look at things from their point of view, not from an advertising or a client point of view."

webTitle: Grant Parker and Patrick McCelland of BMP DDB

fields.headline: Grant Parker and Patrick McCelland of BMP DDB
fields.standfirst: South African Grant Parker and New Zealander Patrick McCelland have found the London ad scene a lot more challenging than the one in their respective countries.
fields.trailText: South African Grant Parker and New Zealander Patrick McCelland have found the London ad scene a lot more challenging than the ones in their respective countries.
fields.body:
This team emanates from the southern hemisphere: Parker (who studied fine art) from South Africa and McCelland (who studied to become a stockbroker) from New Zealand.

After a year and a half in this country, they have found the London ad scene a lot more challenging than where they came from. Parker and McCelland started with a stint in direct marketing, but soon landed a job at BMP, where they have earned respect from their peers for the stylish simplicity of their work for Oxfam, London Transport, Volkswagen and Brooke Bond.

When the duo arrived at the agency on a three-week placement, they "put out a lot of fires" by creating some no-nonsense ads for Vodafone and British Gas. This hard-working attitude and lack of self-indulgence won them a permanent position. Their advertising ambitions are relatively modest. They want to move up the ranks at BMP and, more immediately, succeed in getting some TV scripts accepted.

webTitle: England prosper without Shearer

fields.headline: England prosper without Shearer
fields.standfirst:
France 1 Petit 64
England 1 Owen 86
fields.trailText: So England are not so bad after all. Whether the improvement on the inept showing in Euro 2000 is quite as dramatic as their better moments in Saturday's draw with France suggested, though, will only be known when they meet Germany in a World Cup qualifier at Wembley on October 7.
fields.byline: David Lacey at Stade de France
fields.body:
So England are not so bad after all. Whether the improvement on the inept showing in Euro 2000 is quite as dramatic as their better moments in Saturday's draw with France suggested, though, will only be known when they meet Germany in a World Cup qualifier at Wembley on October 7.

Yet only a churl would deny that the manner in which Kevin Keegan's refurbished, reorganised side held the world and European champions to 1-1 here in Paris was encouraging, even invigorating at times. David Beckham's metamorphosis into a master of the midfield remains merely an attractive theory but Gareth Barry looked an England player in the making.

When Michael Owen's adroit volley brought the scores level with four minutes remaining, and six minutes after England's one goalscorer of international class had come off the bench, it was the most heartening moment for an England supporter since . . . well, since Owen's dash through Argentina's defence in St Etienne.

But this was a friendly, and despite some finger-wagging in the tunnel after the whistle, reportedly involving Martin Keown and Marcel Desailly and Beckham and Frank Leboeuf, France mostly treated it as an exhibition game.

For the French the main purpose of the evening was to welcome home the European championship winners and say farewell to Laurent Blanc and Didier Deschamps, who were making their last appearances before retiring from international football.

It is to England's credit that the quality of their passing and movement, especially in the first half, reminded the opposition that the night was not going to be all about bouquets and blowing kisses. Keegan's team did not exactly reign on France's parade but nor were they spectators to a lap of honour and when the French, having taken the lead through Emmanuel Petit just past the hour, tried to tease England by playing keep-ball they were ultimately punished for such presumption.

As Keegan said afterwards: "Our players don't mind playing against great footballers but they don't like it when it's party time. And we didn't want to come to a party just to make up the numbers."

Dennis Wise indicated as much when he whacked Zinedine Zidane around the ear after 45 seconds. Wise suffered retribution from Robert Pires in stoppage-time and had to be helped from the pitch with a bruised shin. Seconds earlier Owen had gone in very late on Leboeuf. No, it was not all jelly and balloons.

For all that, England's satisfaction does need some qualification before action is resumed against Germany, with Finland to follow in Helsinki four days later. Six of the Frenchmen, including Zidane, Lilian Thuram and Petit, that appeared against Keegan's side on Saturday play in Italy or Spain, whose league programmes have yet to start.

Hence the ring-rustiness in some aspects of the French performance. Their best player throughout was Youri Djorkaeff, who plays for Kaiserslautern in the German league which, like the Premiership, is well under way.

The Germans may not be as gifted as the French but they will be more inclined to close down space and pressure the man on the ball at Wembley. Keegan, moreover, may not be so eager to play Saturday's feathery midfield in a World Cup qualifier and if Liverpool's Steven Gerrard is fit he will surely come in for Wise.

The immediacy with which Barry's cool and imaginative use of the ball from left-back caught the eye suggested that the 19-year-old Aston Villa defender has an international future but he, like Sol Campbell, another central defender playing out of position, was exposed when Thierry Henry or Sylvain Wiltord, who replaced Nicolas Anelka after half-time, took him on at speed.

The enduring usefulness of Gareth Southgate was reaffirmed when Tony Adams, the new England captain, was forced off at half-time with a twisted ankle, having fallen heavily after being fouled by Desailly. As a result Adams is unlikely to figure in a rematch with Desailly on Wednesday when Arsenal visit Chelsea.

The idea of using a lone striker, Andy Cole, up front with Paul Scholes playing off him was reasonably successful. There was, as Keegan agreed, much better movement by the front players but he was never going to concede that this had anything to do with the retirement of Alan Shearer. Indeed, when he announced that Shearer's wife had just had a baby boy one was tempted to ask if he would be christened Kevin. By Euro 2000 Shearer had the mobility of a tree stump at international level.

Keegan is not sure if he will persist with playing one behind one for the Germany match. Either way he must surely start with Owen in the team, Cole or no Cole.

Owen chafed on the bench for 79 minutes before replacing Scholes. By this time Petit, set up by Zidane's pass, had driven a well struck but hardly thunderous shot past David Seaman, who remains capable of making outstanding saves but is more inclined to be left flat-footed by shots he used at least to attempt to save.

Cole, like the industrious Nick Barmby, had brought some leaping saves from Bernard Lama but with Beckham, far from commanding the central midfield, looking like a shy interloper, it was hard to see how England could save the game.

Then a tiring Darren Anderton was replaced by Kieron Dyer, whose pace troubled Bixente Lizarazu and Desailly and supported the contention that he should have gone to Euro 2000. In the 86th minute, as Dyer's cross dipped into the goalmouth, Owen snaked a foot around Leboeuf, who had come on for Blanc, and hooked the ball into the net.

"We wanted to take a step forward and show we could pass the ball better than we did in Euro 2000," said Keegan, "and we've done that. To have taken nothing from this game would have been a travesty."

Just so long as he does not take too much from it. Keegan keeps harking back to the goalless friendly with Argentina in February, another game in which England seemed to have got their passing right only for it all to go wrong in Euro 2000. Saturday's match will only matter if this time the lesson is fully absorbed.

webTitle: Blair pressed for inquiry into Finucane killing

fields.headline: Blair pressed for inquiry into Finucane killing
fields.trailText: The family of murdered Belfast solicitor Pat Finucane are meeting Prime Minister Tony Blair to press for an independent judicial inquiry into his killing.
fields.body:
The family of murdered Belfast solicitor Pat Finucane are meeting Prime Minister Tony Blair to press for an independent judicial inquiry into his killing.

Mr Finucane was shot dead by loyalist gunmen in front of his wife and three children in their north Belfast home in 1989. They believe alleged security force collusion is being covered up.

Irish premier Bertie Ahern, who has backed calls for a full investigation, arranged the meeting with Mr Blair.

Mr Finucane's son, John, said: "Our family is in no doubt his death goes beyond who pulled the trigger and that darker forces were behind it and the subsequent cover-up that exists to this day.

"We are dealing here with the ugliest face of the conflict. It undermines public confidence in the security forces, the system of criminal justice, and government itself.

"It strikes at the principle which lies at the very heart of good governance, the rule of law.

He added: "The only way to undo the appalling damage incurred by those behind my father's murder is to hold an inquiry sooner rather than later, so that the public may know the truth and such events can never happen again.

"We can wait for the truth but we won't live with the lies, that is something we refuse to do."

Self-confessed police informer, William Stobie, of Forthriver Drive, Belfast, faces trial after a charge of murdering Mr Finucane was reduced to one of aiding and abetting the killing.

webTitle: French pensioner prepares compensation case

fields.headline: French pensioner prepares compensation case
fields.standfirst: Jon Henley reports from Paris on a new demand for compensation for victims of the Nazis
fields.trailText: Jon Henley reports from Paris on a new demand for compensation for victims of the Nazis.
fields.body:
In the first case of its kind to be heard by a French court, a 76-year-old Frenchman is claiming some £100,000 from the German state in compensation for his two years forced labour in the factories of the Nazi aircraft manufacturer Junkers.

Rémy Aubard was one of tens of thousands of young men deported from France to work without pay in the factories of the Third Reich.

The outcome of his case, to be heard by a Paris court later this year, could revive old animosities and seriously embarrass the present German government.

Mr Aubard, then a young Citroen mechanic, was just over 18 years of age when he was arrested while trying to join Allied forces in North Africa.

With 911 others, he was held in a detention centre near Compiègne and then deported to Buchenwald concentration camp in October 1943.

"I spent 19 months there and I very nearly died," he said. "My health was seriously affected by working 72 hours a week in the factory until the camp was liberated by its inmates on April 11, 1945."

Mr Aubard was part of the camp's so-called Schonebeck Kommando, put to work by the nearby Junkers Flugzeug und Motorenwerke factory - whose shareholders included Field Marshall Hermann Goering - to make fighter parts and components for the feared V2 rocket.

"From December 1 1943 to March 10 1945, I was forced to work there every day, under the eye of the SS, from 5 am to 6pm," he said.

"There was a bowl of soup at midday and that was it. I was never paid. There were pay vouchers, but they were worthless. What could you buy in Buchenwald? Nothing."

In July, the German government and a number of large industrial conglomerates agreed, after decades of international pressure, to set up a £3.3bn fund to compensate the estimated 10m forced or slave labourers who worked in wartime Nazi factories, but all the signs are that this could take years.

Mr Aubard's claim is aimed at ensuring he gets his money while he can still make use of it. His lawyer, Emmanuel Ludot, has established that the Nazi regime billed Junkers about four marks a day for each forced labourer it supplied, at a time when the average German worker was paid 9 marks.

He has calculated that, in today's terms, Mr Aubard is owed £40,000 in back pay, and is also claiming £50,000 in damages and interest.

"It is intolerable that the forced foreign labour from which the German state benefited has never been accounted for," Mr Ludot said.

"Deported labourers were reduced to the status of slaves for months - if not years - and they deserve justice today."

Several associations of deported French labourers, who have tried for decades without success to obtain reparations from Berlin, are backing Mr Aubard's claim.

"This whole matter has never been settled," said Guy Ducoloné, a former MP and president of a group of one-time Buchenwald inmates.

"The technical obstacles, like calculating how much money is really owed in view not just of the work performed but the inhuman conditions it was performed in, have got more and more difficult to overcome as the years have gone by.

"That's why this case is so interesting: a precise sum has been named. If nothing comes of it, we'll know just exactly what we're up against."

webTitle: Leanda de Lisle: Not all Tories are opposed to the euro

fields.headline: We troubled Tories
fields.standfirst:
You would be wrong to think that all conservatives are fanatically opposed to the euro. We're not
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: You would be wrong to think that all conservatives are fanatically opposed to the euro. We're not.
fields.body:
What big teeth he has, I thought to myself as I looked at the photograph of arch Eurosceptic Conservative MEP Daniel Hannan, which grinned out at me from the front page of the Guardian. I met him years ago when he was a student up at Oxford. It seems his opinions haven't mellowed since.

Yesterday he was scheduled to deliver a speech on the evils of the euro to the annual congress of an ultra-nationalist Danish party. Whatever they made of him in Denmark, to this particular Tory girl he looks like a good reason to sit tight on the euro fence.

I remember him as a clever, ambitious and arrogant boy who offered me some rather creepy advice on a suitable school for my children. To be specific he recommended his old prep school as an excellent establishment. It was sink or swim there, he said: just the place for my sons, if they were up to it.

I was repelled by what was, apparently, enthusiasm for a kind of social Darwinism. But not surprised. It was an attitude typical of his generation.

When I voted for Margaret Thatcher in 1979, I did so because I wanted to be part of a "can do" Britain. I don't regret doing so. But somewhere along the line the "can do" Britain she created became "I can do and damn the rest of you".

If socialism was destroyed, so too was the One Nation Tory notion of capitalism with a conscience. Conservatives raised in the 80s embraced market forces as the will of mammon. For the next decade it was survival of the fittest where I live in the Tory shires, as elsewhere. Riding schools, for example, closed one after the other, broken by the new business rates that took no account of work as a way of life.

Farmers, suffering the beginnings of a general agricultural depression, were told by shires MPs that they didn't matter - until the BSE tragedy struck. When the EU banned the importation of British beef, those Conservative MPs who made a virtue of knowing the price of everything and the value of nothing suddenly began to berate us on the dangers Europe posed to good Olde England.

What on earth was going on? It didn't go unnoticed that farmers couldn't benefit from the abuse our leaders were heaping on our continental partners. They were mere fodder in an anti-euro war.

And was this the great patriotic war it was sold as? Certainly for some it may really have been about the defence of parliamentary democracy and not wanting to hand your hard-earned money to some unelected German bureaucrat, who would only use it to improve the lot of the citizens of Berlin or Bonn.

However, some of the right's attacks on the euro do seem to have been inspired not so much by a love for Olde England as by a fondness for New England. And your average educated Tory is not going to step in to a slit trench with anyone who wants to turn his country into Uncle Sam's mini me, an entity formed almost entirely from the least attractive aspects of American culture. These include the populist politics (you can shoot burglars and name paedophiles to your hearts content over there) and the estimation of a man by the size of his salary.

And there is an obvious point there that they miss. Britain isn't rich enough for Americans to love us back, or even notice us.

A professor of history at an American university explained to me recently that Hollywood has English actors playing the bad guys in their movies, not because we figure in their imaginations, but rather as a dig against their own ruling class, who are, by and large, of English descent.

There is no genuine special relationship between us and the US, only the potential for one. As senior Americans never fail to remind us, it would only be if we were powerful in Europe, which is a big place, that they might regard us as worth knowing.

Yet, on the other side of the argument, the trouble is that Englishmen did not found the EU, as we did the US. And who knows what we might lose as a nation if we gave up our currency? Who knows what we might lose personally, from our pockets, if we joined?

In common with the majority of people in Britain, I am suspicious of European institutions and have no enthusiasm for the euro. But what's the alternative? Sitting up on the euro fence I look down with trepidation at the choice between the likes of devilish Daniel Hannan and a deep blue sea.

You might think that being fanatically opposed to Britain joining the euro is the sine qua non of being a Conservative. But you'd be wrong. The latest Gallup poll indicates that only 26% of Daily Telegraph readers are in favour of it, while a further 40% are up on the fence with me saying, "wait and see".

It is not a comfortable position to be in and I'm sure most of us are willing to be tempted down. But we won't be attracted by anyone who spits when they talk. I fear that rules out the likes of Mr Hannan.

webTitle: What's wrong with one world currency?

fields.headline: What's wrong with one world currency?
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: The poor old euro cuts a sorry figure as it stumbles around the foreign exchanges. Interest rates have risen five times already this year, and will rise again during the autumn, but still investors would prefer to hold US dollars than the single currency. The European Central Bank appears to be at its wits' end, with one half of the markets decrying last week's move as too aggressive and the other half arguing that it was not aggressive enough.
fields.body:
The poor old euro cuts a sorry figure as it stumbles around the foreign exchanges. Interest rates have risen five times already this year, and will rise again during the autumn, but still investors would prefer to hold US dollars than the single currency. The European Central Bank appears to be at its wits' end, with one half of the markets decrying last week's move as too aggressive and the other half arguing that it was not aggressive enough.

With Germany and France showing the first signs of slowing down while inflation in Ireland is out of control, the strains in monetary union are showing for the first time since the euro was launched 20 months ago. For months, Europe's central bankers and politicians have been saying that the euro is fundamentally undervalued and will soon deliver a knockout blow to the over-confident dollar. But, somehow, it never seems to happen. Capital is still flowing into the US and out of Europe, and it is this rather than the counterpart, Europe's trade surplus and America's trade deficit, that is affecting currency values.

Two of the UK groups that oppose monetary union, Business for Sterling and New Europe, today launch a campaign designed to point out the benefits of staying out and the risks of going in, and they could hardly have picked a more propitious moment to do so. Talking up the euro hasn't worked, higher interest rates haven't worked, massive G7 intervention is not on the agenda because the Democrats are relying on the strong dollar to damp down US inflation, underpin share prices on Wall Street and ensure that the planned slowdown in American growth does not turn into a hard landing.

So what is to be done? One long-term answer could be to put the euro out of its misery altogether and decide that monetary union in Europe is merely a stepping stone to global monetary union with the dollar as the single currency. Inadvertently perhaps, the justification for such a move was provided by a recent pamphlet produced by Britain in Europe, the lobby group that favours sterling's entry into the single currency.

The report, quite fairly, does not pretend that euroland has a better job creation record than the UK (which it does not) and concedes that there are risks involved in both joining the euro and in staying out. But, interestingly, the reasons that it says tip the balance in its favour - the ability of businesses to sell more widely, achieving the "massive economies of scale seen in America", removing the barriers to trade represented by "separate currencies", limiting currency fluctuations, and having greater influence in decision-making would all seem to be arguments in favour of one world currency.

If the name of the game is removing barriers then why stop at Europe? The inexorable logic of the BiE report is that making life easier for business will lead to higher growth and hence all of us will reap the trickle-down benefits of higher living standards. So, in classic Thatcherite fashion, the more barriers that can be removed the better, and given that more than 60% of world trade and inward investment are between North America, Western Europe and Japan, this ought to mean just one big currency. Indeed, two of the people responsible for the BiE paper, Robert Mundell and Willem Buiter, are supporters of a world currency.

Would there be advantages to this, in addition to the obvious benefit to those in the euro zone of having Alan Greenspan and the Federal Reserve in charge of monetary policy rather than the hapless ECB? Well, it would put an end to currency speculation. Yoked together by a single currency, governments in the rich countries could settle their differences and push for a new trade round to remove any other barriers to business that threaten the ability of their multinationals to prise open new markets.

Moreover, technically speaking, this would be the perfect moment to amalgamate the three major currencies into one. Give or take a few cents, one dollar buys one euro buys 100 yen. Rebase the yen so that 100 old yen equals one new yen and the three currencies would all trade at close to parity.

Given the premise of the BiE paper, this makes as much sense as British membership of the euro, and is subject to the same two objections. The first is economic: the fact that the right monetary policy for the US at the present would certainly not be the right monetary policy for Japan, just as the monetary policy that is right for Germany is not right for Ireland.

Tower of Babel
Had Britain joined monetary union in 1999 and cut interest rates to 3%, it is clear that inflation would now be well above its 2.5% target and the government would be under considerable pressure to tighten fiscal policy to counterbalance the monetary laxity. Ireland, with inflation above 6%, has negative real interest rates, which is totally inappropriate.

The second is political: the reluctance of people to give up democratic rights even if that does involve accepting a degree of inefficiency. Europe is a case in point, here. webTitle: Misrule on the road

fields.headline: Misrule on the road
fields.standfirst: In Pakistan, air bags and side-impact bars are replaced by Allah written on the windscreen, as drivers and passengers trust to luck.
fields.trailText: In Pakistan, air bags and side-impact bars are replaced by Allah written on the windscreen, as drivers and passengers trust to luck.
fields.body:
From the smugglers' bazaars of Peshawar east to the quiet avenues of Islamabad the Grand Trunk Road must rank as one of the most dangerous in the subcontinent.

The driving is awful and we were just as bad as we raced back to the capital in a speeding, late-night convoy after a long evening at a traditional Pathan wedding in Peshawar. With our hazard lights flashing and horns honking there was less concern for others on the road than for the bride and groom who were hurrying home for their first night together.

Car crashes are frequent. Research published last week by the Johns Hopkins School of Public Health, in the US, shows that road deaths in Pakistan have multiplied 16 times in the last 40 years. Not surprisingly buses and public vehicles, which make up a third of those on the road, are the chief culprits, responsible for more than half the accidents and 90% of the deaths.

Truck drivers in old, overloaded but brightly painted lorries blunder down the GT road driving for hours at a time, kept awake by drugs and racing to meet deadlines. Coach drivers are the same. Most borrow the money to buy their buses and have to pack in as many passengers and squeeze in as many journeys as possible in a day to pay back the moneylender at extortionate rates of interest.

Car drivers don't wear seatbelts - many think it a sign of cowardice in the face of an oncoming truck. Then there are the military and government four-wheel drives. And the only decent main road is Pakistan's sole motorway that runs from Islamabad to Raiwind, the home of the last prime minister, Nawaz Sharif (now in jail for corruption).

Traffic police are ineffectual. Most people carry a handful of 100-rupee notes in their cars to fend off tricky questions about missing driving licences, bald tyres and cracked windscreens. Only 14% of crashes are investigated by police, according to the Johns Hopkins study. Up to 86% of car injuries go uncounted in police statistics, so the scale of the problem is massively underestimated.

But bad driving doesn't seem to bother Pakistanis, who appear immune to road rage. They don't shake their fists in fury and although they love to honk the horns of their Suzuki Khybers, it is rarely in anger. Mostly they stretch their arms out of the window, shrug their shoulders and flick their palms up, an intriguing gesture with a million meanings but which often just says: "This is Pakistan, what do you expect?"

"Nobody knows the rules," said Rashid, my Pakistani friend. "Me, I just ignore it."

While drivers in the west turn to air bags and side-impact bars for security, many here turn to a higher authority. Everyone has a car sticker or two, and many of them have a religious significance, perhaps a comfort for drivers. "Allah is just a prayer away," is common.

Most taxis have the name Allah written in Urdu script on the windscreen, some also have the numbers 786, taken as a numerical equivalent of the opening words of the Koran, "In the name of Allah, the most beneficent, the most merciful." Truck drivers have verses of Sufi poetry written in Urdu on the backs of their lorries next to huge paintings of the latest Islamic hero.

Saddam Hussein was a common face during the Gulf war, then Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, the Afghan mojahedin leader backed by Pakistan after the Soviet withdrawal. Osama bin Laden, Washington's most-wanted terrorist suspect, is the current hero. A portrait of a Hollywood star, like Kate Winslet, is a rare find.

Occasionally car stickers challenge touchy cultural questions. The driver with the sticker "I love black beauty" was probably criticising the fashion of skin whitening, popular among some young Pakistanis. Only a handful seem to hint at the dangers of bad driving, which is forecast to become the world's third biggest killer by 2020.

"This is my Pakistan," read one sticker on a car negotiating the potholed streets of Rawalpindi. "Love it or leave it but do not destroy it."

webTitle: Obituary: Suzanne Danco

fields.headline: Suzanne Danco
fields.standfirst: Stylish soprano of impeccable taste in both opera and lieder
fields.trailText: The Belgian soprano Suzanne Danco, who has died aged 89, was the epitome of the well-schooled, clear voiced soprano in the French tradition. She sang her wide repertory with impeccable taste, an unerring sense of the requisite style for the music, and was especially admired for her Mozart, which she sang internationally in the 1950s, her readings both thoughtful and well-groomed.
fields.body:
The Belgian soprano Suzanne Danco, who has died aged 89, was the epitome of the well-schooled, clear voiced soprano in the French tradition. She sang her wide repertory with impeccable taste, an unerring sense of the requisite style for the music, and was especially admired for her Mozart, which she sang internationally in the 1950s, her readings both thoughtful and well-groomed.

Danco was Flemish, born and brought up in Brussels. Although her family discouraged her from a career as a musician, she was helped to become a singer at the Brussels Music Academy by the Queen of the Belgians. On the advice of the eminent conductor Erich Kleiber, she went to Prague to study with the famous teacher Fernando Carpi, before making her stage debut in Italy in 1941 at the Genoa Opera, as Fiordiligi in Mozart's Cosi Fan Tutti, a role that was a favourite with her and with audiences.

After the second world war, she appeared at La Scala as Jocasta in Stravinsky's Oedipus Rex and Ellen Orford in Britten's Peter Grimes (first performances in Italy of both operas) and at the San Carlo, Naples she sang Marie in the first Italian performance of Berg's Wozzeck. These roles demonstrated her eclectic taste. She once remarked that she didn't mind what she sang and enjoyed tackling all kinds of music.

Danco's first stage appearance in Britain was at Glyndebourne in 1951, where she was Donna Elvira, a role fitted to her talents, in Mozart's Don Giovanni. That year she made her only appearance at Covent Garden, as Mimi in La Bohème. A reviewer in Opera magazine commented that she was "a convincing Mimi, really looking the part, and achieving the utmost pathos with the simplest of means". Danco was prominent in the early years of the Aix-en-Provence Festival in her Mozart roles, encouraged by the festival's presiding conductor, Hans Rosbaud, who always chose his casts with discernment.

The Swiss conductor, Ernest Ansermet, was also taken with her talents, and thought her ideal for the French repertory he had just begun recording for Decca with his Suisse Romande Orchestra; she took part in many classic performances on disc with him in the 1950s, including the much admired earlier (and better) of Ansermet's two sets of Debussy's Pellèas et Mélisande. Danco's Melisande strikes just the right balance between knowingness and innocence, a paradox at the heart of that equivocal role. Another recording triumph with Ansermet was as the sexy, scheming Concepcion in L'heure espagnole and as the Princess in L'enfant et les sortilèges, on a Ravel double-bill.

She caught to perfection the etheral tone of the soprano solo in Fauré's Requiem; produced a feted recording of Ravel's Shéhér-azade; and in Berlioz's Les nuits d'été, her slightly cool, subtly inflected reading, notable for the intelligent treatment of the text, has stood the test of time.

She gave a distinguished account on disc of Schu mann's Opus 39 Liederkreis and of songs by Mozart, Schubert and Brahms, all still worth looking for. Even more memorable are her idiomatic readings of the melodies of Fauré and Debussy. Two of her Mozart roles have just been re-issued on the Decca Legends series: Cherubino on Erich Kleiber's Le nozze di Figaro and Donna Anna in Krips's recording of Don Giovanni; a BBC recording she made with Kathleen Ferrier of Bach's B minor Mass, conducted by Enesco, has recently been found. Of her concert roles, her Marguerite in Charles Munch's fine recording of Berlioz's La damnation de Faust is a worthy souvenir. She catches the ache of the betrayed heroine's romance.

From 1960, Danco's operatic appearances were few and far between, but she continued her concert career until her final appearance, in Mahler's Fourth Symphony in 1970. After her retirement she first taught at the Accademia Chigiana in Siena, and latterly was a frequent visitor to the Britten-Pears School at Snape, where she dispensed good advice in a strict but kind manner. Her joint courses with the Swiss tenor Hugues Cuenod were entertaining events and wonderful examples of the impeccable style of which both singers had been such important advocates.

She named her villa at Fieseole Amarilli, probably to recall her 1949 78rpm recording of Caccini's song of that name. It caused a sensation among connoisseurs of fine singing and has seldom, if ever, been surpassed.

 Suzanne Danco, soprano, born January 22 1911; died August 10 2000

webTitle: Obituary: David Tinker

fields.headline: David Tinker
fields.standfirst: Artist, sculptor and campaigner for a modern gallery for Wales
fields.trailText: David Tinker, who has died aged 75, was one of the stars of the Welsh Group's 50th anniversary retrospective at the national museums and galleries of Wales. His work in that show seduced even those who had always thought themselves uninterested in op art.
fields.body:
David Tinker, who has died aged 75, was one of the stars of the Welsh Group's 50th anniversary retrospective at the national museums and galleries of Wales. His work in that show seduced even those who had always thought themselves uninterested in op art.

In 1949, Tinker had arrived, as an enthusiastic young lecturer in sculpture, at Cardiff College of Art. Over the next half century, he became one of the most prominent figures in Welsh contemporary art. He led calls for modernism and abstraction to be taken seriously amid the provincial academicism that dominated not just public taste, but the Welsh galleries and art schools.

In 1956, he was co-founder of the radical exhibiting co-operative 56 Group Wales. At the same time, he was pivotal in defeating the conservatism of the South Wales Group, blasting the "closed shop operating against the experimental painter". As chairman of the Welsh Group for 15 years, Tinker worked to create opportunities for artists, sometimes seeming high-minded in a way which belied his soft, self-effacing sense of humour.

At Cardiff, his students had included Sir Anthony Hopkins and the painters Ivor Davies and Professor Glyn Jones. In 1962, he moved to the University College of Wales, Aberystwyth, leading its growing art school until his retirement in 1986.

Tinker was born in Charlton, south London, the son of a naval engineer and an embroiderer. To this background he attributed his love of making things and his fascination with the visual. As he wrote in an essay for Artists In Wales (1977): "The sight of colour, shape and form are marvellous to me. I have always felt I must communicate to other people something of the excitement which I experience." He was educated in Rochester, Portsmouth and Canterbury, and at Winchester and Bath schools of art. Wartime naval service followed, before he took up a place at the Slade school of art in 1946; negative experiences at the Slade shaped his most important precept, which was to attune himself to students' individualism, and never to "correct" them.

When Tinker was a young lecturer, Reg Butler had advised him always to make time for his own creativity, however difficult it might be to do so. He worked continuously and was fascinated above all by colour, publishing a pamphlet, Colour Recognition, in 1982. In a series of op art paintings, he used systematic colour progressions, finely judged to hypnotic effect. He had 20 solo shows, but he was more committed to the democracy of the group show and of public art.

One of his proudest projects was the vast mural that dominates the university arts centre at Aberystwyth, commissioned by the architect, Dale Owen. Stage design also allowed him to share his ideas with a wide audience, and he revelled in designing productions for Welsh National Opera and plays for Saunders Lewis.

Tinker's later work appeared to grow from an abstract expressionist tradition, though he said recently that he realised he had been a romantic all along. This was particularly apparent, perhaps, in his last solo exhibition, Dream Places: this featured ceramic constructions in which strange architecture and disembodied facial features together conjured silent reveries.

Tinker sat on the Welsh Arts Council's art panel and the executive of the Contemporary Art Society for Wales. Chairing the general arts lobby for Wales, he gave evidence to the recent National Assembly arts policy review, stressing the need for a gallery of modern art in Wales, the only nation of the British Isles that still does not have such a gallery.

Examples of his work are held by the Arts Council of Wales and the National Gallery in Cardiff. He was awarded the Queen's Medal for Art in 1977. A retrospective of his work, in the plan ning of which he took much pleasure during his final illness, will be shown at Aberystwyth in 2001.

He is survived by his three children from his first marriage, to Mary Edwards; and by his second wife, Tracy Spottiswoode.

 David Tinker, artist, born December 4 1924; died August 25 2000

fields.headline: Iggy Quail
fields.standfirst: London jazzman who cared nothing for fame and fortune as long as he could play his piano
fields.trailText: With the death of pianist Iggy Quail, aged 74, the British jazz underground has lost a central figure and inspiration of young talents. For over 25 years, his trio was a focus for north London's weekend revellers, offering an opportunity for performers to "sit in" and recalling a golden age of jazz.
fields.body:
With the death of pianist Iggy Quail, aged 74, the British jazz underground has lost a central figure and inspiration of young talents. For over 25 years, his trio was a focus for north London's weekend revellers, offering an opportunity for performers to "sit in" and recalling a golden age of jazz.

Born in Guyana, Quail moved to London in the 1950s and on to the Latin-American circuit. In Soho, he played jazz and pop numbers with guitarist Lauderic Caton and teamed with the Guyanese Eytle brothers, bassist Julian and guitarist Tommy (otherwise Jules in BBC television's EastEnders). In 1958, he joined other Caribbean settlers in Leslie "Jiver" Hutchinson's pit band for the London run of Langston Hughes's musical comedy Simply Heavenly, and at the birth of rock-and-roll, formed the Dominoes, in which he shared vocals with Boysie Grant and "Cuddly" Dudley Heslop.

During a long association with Heslop, the first West Indian artist to appear on the early pop TV show Oh Boy!, Quail cut some of the first bluebeat recordings, and also recorded with Laurel Aitken, Cuban-born pioneer of this Jamaican dance genre. With Heslop and bassist Clyde Davies, he played long residencies, including the exclu sive Kingfisher Club. Here the trio accompanied leading comedians of the time, among them Tommy Trinder and Bob Monkhouse.

In the mid 1970s, the weekend all-comers sessions with Quail, Jamaican bassist Coleridge Goode and the veteran bebop drummer Laurie Morgan, began at The Stapleton, Finsbury Park, but their fame really spread when they started a long residency at Dingwall's in Camden Lock. Hundreds of instrumentalists shared a stage where no favouritism prevailed: when veteran trumpeters Les Condon or "Rannie" Hart queued with any lunchtime singer who knew just one song, no one had precedence.

In 1978, I took young Amer ican tenor saxophonist David Murray there on his first visit to London: he astonished all-comers with his instrumental command, but was soon waiting his turn in a line of horn players that included soca stylist Ray Carless and Jack Massaryk, the Evening Standard's jazz correspondent.

Finsbury Park's George Robey pub was also Quail's home for a while, and there were other venues before the trio settled at the King's Head in Crouch End, where they stayed for 10 years. What had started as a gig grew into something resembling a family, and the band's associates became extended family members.

Bassist Josef Koumbas was in the family, and the musi cians would head to his rambling house in Hornsey Rise Gardens when the official session was over, and the music went on into the night. Weddings were held there, christenings and funeral wakes, always with music, and young instrumentalists such as the South African trumpeter Claude Deppa learnt to play jazz with Quail's encouragement.

Once an entire Cuban band moved in for a fortnight and played with the pianist; local jazz heroes Jim Dvorak, John Stevens and Dudu Pukwana were regulars; distinguished pianists Mal Waldron and Abdullah Ibrahim also passed through.

At the centre of all this activity was Quail, stirring the pot, then tasting the results. As a facilitator and catalyst, he leaves a large gap. He was the jazzman of legend, a down-to-earth character who cared nothing for fame and fortune as long as he could play his piano. His generosity and distaste for grandstanding enabled many a young musician to learn: "A wonderful man," Koumbas once said, "he'd accommodate anyone, give anyone a go."

He married Pat, his long-term companion, shortly before his death; he is survived by her and two sons.

 Cuthbert Ignatius Quail, pianist, born March 17 1926, died August 30 2000

webTitle: Obituary: Shirley Ulmer

fields.headline: Shirley Ulmer
fields.standfirst: Queen of B-movies, as screenplay writer and script girl
fields.trailText: While making the classic horror movie, The Black Cat (1934), the director Edgar G Ulmer met his wife-to-be, Shirley Kassler, who has died aged 86. She was the script supervisor on the picture, and their collaboration lasted 40 years, during which she worked on all his scripts, although she received screenplay credits only on those from 1934-1940.
fields.body:
While making the classic horror movie, The Black Cat (1934), the director Edgar G Ulmer met his wife-to-be, Shirley Kassler, who has died aged 86. She was the script supervisor on the picture, and their collaboration lasted 40 years, during which she worked on all his scripts, although she received screenplay credits only on those from 1934-1940.

Kassler was born in New York, but went to California as a teenager after her banker-father was wiped out in the 1929 stock market crash. At the time of her meeting with Ulmer, she was married to Max Alexander, the nephew of Carl Laemmle, head of Universal Studios. Ulmer's wooing outraged "Uncle Carl" and Ulmer was blacklisted by the powerful Laemmle. Before leaving Hollywood, Ulmer directed one further feature, under the name of Joen Warner: a western, Thunder Over Texas (1934), written by Shirley, and produced by Max Alexander.

Edgar and Shirley were married soon after. During the depression, with the movie studios closed to them, they moved to New York where she modelled hats, and he worked as a cameraman for Pathé Newsreel. In 1936, producer William Steiner hired them to make a thriller, From Nine To Nine, under Canada's "quota quickie" system; it was shot in eight days during a terrible Montreal winter. They were paid so little that Shirley's appendicitis, which felled her on the last day of shooting, wiped out their earnings and they returned to New York as broke as they had left it.

Their salvation was a crazy Ukrainian, Vasile Avramenko, who wanted to make a Ukrainian musical, and hired Ulmer, with a $50 advance, to direct Natalka Poltavka (1937), shot for $18,000 in a Ukrainian village constructed overnight in the backwoods of New Jersey.

While in New York, the Ulmers met several members of the Jewish Art Theatre, who encouraged them to make pictures in Yiddish for the large immigrant community, although the Ulmers didn't actually speak the language. The first, Green Fields, an adaptation from a stage success was made on a budget of only $8,000, and Ulmer, with his wife's help, proved that he could do more with less than any other director in America. Its success led to his direction of three more Yiddish films, The Singing Blacksmith, The Light Ahead and American Matchmaker. If Ulmer could lay claim to the title King of the Bs, then his wife was the B-movie queen.

Between 1943 and 1946, at the Producers' Releasing Company, the smallest of the poverty row studios, Shirley worked on the scripts of 11 of Ulmer's good and bad films, among them Girls In Chains (set in a woman's prison), Her Sister's Secret (the secret being the taboo subject of illegitimacy), Jive Junction (a second world war propaganda musical), Strange Illusion (a film noir version of Hamlet), and an undisputed masterpiece, Detour (1946), a manic cinematic night ride, a fatalistic drama of sex and money.

Ulmer said he preferred the budgetary restraints of the minor studios to the artistic restraints of the majors. As his wife commented: "He didn't want to be connected with any boss or studio where he had to follow rules. When he made a picture, there was always something he had to say, a moral, a reason. So they were a lot more serious than the average inexpensive film."

While Ulmer was flitting from one film to another, he was also shunting between his wife and daughter, and another partner, with whom he had a child, living as head of two families. Shirley bore this with fortitude.

Though she continued to work with her husband, she also had another career as Shirley Castle, script supervisor for big league directors such as Frank Borzage, William Wyler and Douglas Sirk: in the same capacity, she worked on a number of TV series including The Lone Ranger and Batman, later co-writing a book, The Role Of Script Supervision In Film And Television.

Shirley was at her husband's side during his last years. A series of strokes left him paralysed, unable to swallow, talk or move anything but the forefinger on his right hand, with which he communicated. As his wife said: "This time it is truly his own nightmare that he endures." He died in 1972.

When interest in Ulmer's films began in the 1970s and he gained cult status, Shirley Ulmer spoke at many tributes and retrospectives, and was director of the Edgar G Ulmer Preservation Corporation. Her daughter, Arianné Ulmer Cipes, carries on the corporation's work.

 Shirley Kassler Ulmer, screenwriter and script supervisor, born June 12 1914; died July 6 2000
