webTitle: Roy Hattersley: Tories are winning more votes for Labour than for themselves

fields.headline: Keep up the good work, Mr Redwood
fields.standfirst:
The Tories are winning more votes for Labour than for their own party
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Tories are winning more votes for Labour than for their own party.
fields.body:
It is an admission which I make with some embarrassment but, confession being good for the soul, I reveal that, during the last few days, my thoughts have constantly turned to John Redwood. My aberrant behaviour began in the middle of last week, shortly after listening to a discussion on the Today programme. The topic was David Howell's new book on the politics of the global economy. The author's own contribution was, as you would expect, highly intelligent but totally uninspired. The international market had, he said, reduced politicians' ability to control national economies. They should, he argued, accept that truth and, instead of claiming powers which they do not possess, concentrate on creating a climate in which the people they represent gain most from the new reality.

That proposition is so difficult to deny that, at first, I wondered what Mr Redwood - invited onto the programme to stimulate some kind of discussion - would say, in addition to "Quite right". I should have guessed. First he denounced the government for damaging small businesses. Then he attacked the EU for imposing unnecessary burdens on companies of every size. Lord Howell had spoken in the language of the corporate seminar. Mr Redwood sounded like a bar-parlour Young Conservative. I have no doubt that diehard Tories who were listening loved every cliche.

I attributed my surprise at Mr Redwood's conduct to the early hour in which the discussion took place. Had I been fully awake I would have remembered that he always behaves in the same way. During an Any Questions? broadcast in July, he was asked his opinion about the prosecution of the headmistress who was accused (and eventually acquitted) of striking one of the children in her school. He answered that New Labour encouraged an environment in which "the wrong people get punished".

Earlier in the year, when we appeared together on a television programme called Powerhouse, I so despaired of provoking him into serious discussion that I spent my time drawing attention to his talent for repeating hackneyed slogans as if they were revelations of a previous unrecognised truth. If he were to make a guest appearance on Coronation Street, Mr Redwood would explain to Natalie that Les Battersby is the product of socialist-induced dependency culture.

Mr Redwood is, we are constantly assured, a man of formidable intellect - Fellow of All Souls, merchant banking infant prodigy and head of Margaret Thatcher's policy unit. Somewhere along the way he must have been told - and shown the opinion polls to prove - that there is nothing floating voters like less than political point scoring. They disapprove of it even during overtly political debate. When party points are made during discussion of apparently unpolitical topics, they are instantly alienated from whoever made them and the cause which he or she supports. The voters the Tories must win if they are ever to form a government admire brave Doctor Mowlam and amiable Mr Steven Norris - two politicians who are thought to be above politics. Why does Mr Redwood antagonise potential support which is essential to Conservative success?

I put aside, at once, the thought that Mr Redwood actually wants a Conservative defeat. And I discard - with almost equal certainty - the possibility that, confronted with camera or microphone, he is engulfed in a red mist which prevents him from behaving with rational calm. There is, in fact, only one plausible explanation. He knows that his party is doomed and believes it his duty to enthuse the hard core of Conservative voters who enjoy the party sniping which normal people detest. Whether he courts the diminishing band of loyalists on his own, or his party's, behalf will only be clear when the defeat which he anticipates comes about.

The one thing to be said in favour of the Redwood broadcasting style is that it is based on a strategy - a suicidal strategy, but a strategy nevertheless. So it is just possible to argue that his behaviour, although ridiculous, is more grown-up than attempts to attract support by boasting about teenage drinking exploits and identifying ex-girlfriends. But both weird Tory campaigning techniques have one thing in common. They are the product of despair.

The problem of the Redwood approach - at least for the Tories - is that, because it anticipates defeat at the next election, it makes defeat more certain at the one which follows. The people who wave union flags in time to Rule Britannia after the Tory leader finishes his address to party conference are, let us give thanks, not typical of the British public. Behaviour which appeals to them, antagonises floating voters. John Redwood must know it. Yet, because of inner compulsion or convoluted calculation, he continues to offend the people the Conservatives need most. For Labour, the more often he broadcasts, the better.

webTitle: Eyeballing a new forensic technique

fields.headline: Eyeballing a new forensic technique
fields.trailText: Forensic scientists may one day be able to identify corpses from their contact lenses, once other characteristics have begun to perish.
fields.body:
Forensic scientists may one day be able to identify corpses from their contact lenses, once other characteristics have begun to perish.

It all depends, says Margaret Cox, a forensic archaeologist at Bournemouth University, on how long contact lenses survive once they are buried. One person in 25 wears contact lenses: each has been made up to a prescription held in the records of an optician.

"Like the information we gather from teeth and other materials associated with murder victims, the data we gather from the lenses would be circulated to opticians who could be instrumental in making a positive identification," said Professor Cox.

So one of her students, Rachel Jackson, is about to embark on a series of increasingly grisly experiments. She will bury hard and soft contact lenses for increasing lengths of time in soil in the laboratory to measure the rate at which they dry out under differing circumstances.

But that will not be a proper test of scene-of-crime conditions, so she will then bury lenses with eyeballs taken from slaughtered pigs. At intervals, she will disinter them to see how they have survived.

The hope is that at least under some conditions, the lenses will tell a story. They will be rehydrated in saline solution and then measured in the hope that experts will be able to work backwards to the original prescription.

The idea grew from a student exercise.

"Some 4% of the population wear contact lenses," says Ms Jackson. "But they have never been studied as a forensic tool before."

webTitle: Texas justice: an eye for an eye

fields.headline: Texas justice: an eye for an eye
fields.standfirst:
Bush on law and order

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W Bush's Texas leads the union in several key indicators of what compassionate conservatism has meant during his five years as governor: among them, the country's most densely populated jail system and its busiest death chamber.
fields.body:
George W Bush's Texas leads the union in several key indicators of what compassionate conservatism has meant during his five years as governor: among them, the country's most densely populated jail system and its busiest death chamber.

He has signed more death warrants than any other governor, nearly one every other week since 1995. "I'm confident that each person who has been executed in our state was guilty of the crime," he said.

To that end, 141 people have been put to death during Bush's administration. Four weeks ago a man whose IQ was thought to be as low as 63 was executed, even though courts routinely consider anyone around 70 as retarded.

Mr Bush can only issue a reprieve on the recommendation of the state board of paroles and pardons. He appoints its members, who have never met and vote by fax.

Texas leads the US in its enthusiasm for locking people up: more than 163,000 of its population of 20m were in jail last year.

While crime fell in the 90s in Texas - as elsewhere - the state's prison numbers grew by 173%; again, more than anywhere else. Indeed, between 1995 and 1998 crime in Texas declined by 5.1% compared with 10% nationally.

"Texas processes inmates the way a fast-food restaurant processes hamburgers," said Steven Bright, of the Southern Centre for Human Rights.

Mr Bush, unlike his opponent Al Gore, opposes mandatory gun registration and adheres to the standard Republican line that the firearms laws are adequate but that the determination of the Clinton administration to enforce them is not.

Guns are part of the Texan heritage and Mr Bush is not willing to tamper with that. He has signed a bill making it illegal for Texan cities to sue gunmakers unless the state attorney general agrees; declined to do anything to assist a bill that would have imposed background checks on people who buy guns at firearms shows; and supported a law that ended a 125-year ban on carrying concealed weapons.

webTitle: Bell regrets promise to stand only once in Tatton

fields.headline: Bell regrets promise to stand only once in Tatton
fields.trailText: The former BBC war correspondent, Martin Bell, said yesterday that he would like to stay on as an independent MP in the Commons, but could not stand again in Tatton because of a pledge he had given to the electorate there.
fields.body:
The former BBC war correspondent, Martin Bell, said yesterday that he would like to stay on as an independent MP in the Commons, but could not stand again in Tatton because of a pledge he had given to the electorate there.

He admitted yesterday that he had made a mistake by promising he would stay for only one term as an independent MP when he defeated the disgraced ex-Tory minister, Neil Hamilton, who was forced to resign over the "cash for questions" scandal.

Mr Bell, interviewed on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost programme, said he regretted the pledge but would stick to it.

"I did it for tactical reasons, because I didn't want to lose, but I'm sorry I made it.

"I'm actually under pressure for keeping a promise rather than for breaking one, which I think is rather unusual, but it was made to the people of Tatton, it will be kept to the people of Tatton, that's for sure."

He did not rule out standing in another constituency - although he would do so only as an independent.

"I have had sort of approaches of one kind or another over the last 3 years from all three parties actually, but I think there is some virtue in being an independent."

webTitle: Leader: Church attendance amongst the elderly on the decline

fields.headline: Unfaithful unto death
fields.standfirst:
Older people are getting less credulous
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: There is a good reason, says conventional wisdom, why you see lots of older people in church. The imminence of death ups the spiritual ante. Any institution - especially the Christian church - which offers some sort of immunity against demise is bound to win greater support from those for whom the end is visible if not actually nigh.
fields.body:
There is a good reason, says conventional wisdom, why you see lots of older people in church. The imminence of death ups the spiritual ante. Any institution - especially the Christian church - which offers some sort of immunity against demise is bound to win greater support from those for whom the end is visible if not actually nigh.

This theory always had a patronising tinge to it. It implied older people are softer-headed than the rationalist-sceptical or merely indifferent population at large. But research reported yesterday said they aren't much different at all. A survey (to be presented to a British Society of Gerontology conference this week) suggests numbers of the ageing, including former believers, lose their Christian faith. The old "insurance policy" approach to church-going in later life looks less attractive than it used to. Authority dissolves as readily among those aged 60-plus as among teenagers.

If this finding holds for those now moving into the old age cohorts, it is bad news for Christian churches. Some are already congregations of the elderly where the "young old", people not long retired from paid work, do not just fill ecclesiastical offices but also care for the "old old" among their members. Some Anglican parishes and non-conformist denominations are in terminal demographic decline, unlikely ever to be revivified through new younger members. Things may get bleaker. The proportion of older people who were educated beyond the minimum level is growing, which might deepen the reservoir of scepticism. Coming generations of elderly will be relatively more affluent thanks to their private financial provision: they may have more opportunities for the social contact which, uniquely, churches once provided. Church decline may correlate with the growing diversity of life chances for older people who believe they do indeed continue to have "life" before them.

webTitle: Bush: His vision for America

fields.headline: Strong sense of purpose hides George Jr's lack of policy
fields.standfirst:
Today is Labour Day, the traditional opening of the US presidential election campaign. Some depict Al Gore and George W Bush as similar candidates, others point to big differences in their agendas. Either way, the fight between Bill Clinton's chosen heir and his predecessor's son will shape the next decade, not only in America but around the world. Guardian correspondents examine the records and the promises

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Everything George W Bush wants to do - according to the campaign slogan - is "for a purpose". He seeks "prosperity for a purpose" through a giant "tax cut with a purpose" to "renew America's purpose".
fields.body:
Everything George W Bush wants to do - according to the campaign slogan - is "for a purpose". He seeks "prosperity for a purpose" through a giant "tax cut with a purpose" to "renew America's purpose".

As buzzwords go, it is a telling choice, since a strong sense of purpose has hitherto been lacking in George W's meandering career. Until recently he took umbrage at being asked about his plans.

"I just don't worry about those things," he told an interviewer. "I kind of figure life is going to work its way out somehow."

Life has indeed worked out for George W Bush so far, but it has had a lot to do with who his father is. In 1968 the family name kept young George out of Vietnam, giving him a coveted place in the Texas National Guard.

Later the name ensured that a string of investors backed him through a string of failed oil ventures in the 80s, and put the money up for the acquisition of the Texas Rangers baseball team in 1989.

He was the well-connected face in the front office and made millions from his tiny personal investment.

Through it all he expressed scant interest in public policy. Even when he went to help his father's presidential campaign in 1988 it is said he was not particularly interested in discussing issues. But he had a keen nose for staff loyalty, and was his father's eyes and ears, and sometimes his hitman.

If there is one driving force behind George W Bush's short political history, it is loyalty. He is supremely faithful to his father and, according to those who know him well, sees this election as an opportunity to avenge the 1992 defeat by Bill Clinton.

But he also believes in loyalty to his backers, and if you were to look for a unifying theme in his years as Texas governor, it is the paying of dues to the business interests which aided his rise to power.

His main contribution to the Texan fiscal system has been to slash property taxes, which favoured the wealthy.

His proposed cut of $1.6 trillion in federal taxes is in the same mould. A married couple earning $250,000 would be saved more than $7,000; a single mother living on $22,000 would gain nothing. For all his emphasis on social and ethnic inclusion, the promised tax giveaway has brought class to the heart of the election.

His other significant impact on Texas is tangible in its grimy air and water. He pushed through the weakest environmental laws in the US, which allow the oil and chemical industries - principal contributors to his campaign - to police themselves.

He has been given credit, even by his critics, for his support of public education in Texas. His interest appears to be influenced by his wife, Laura, a teacher and librarian.

His sustained advocacy of state schools, particularly in impoverished Hispanic communities, has earned him bipartisan support in the Texas legislature.

But he is not proposing to devote much money to the country's schools: he wants to spend $26.6bn on education, compared with the $115bn proposed by Mr Gore.

The Bush rhetoric on strong defence, too, seems to run counter to the scale of his proposed tax cut. He has promised to increase pay and modernise the forces, but with a third of the funds Mr Gore is promising to spend.

To save money, he promises to withdraw troops from peacekeeping engagements. No money appears to have been allocated to the controversial National Missile Defence System he is advocating, calling into question his dedication to the project.

The paradox of George W Bush's campaign is that an unideological candidate has acquired a platform which puts class back at the heart of US politics. The explanation lies in the corporate money stacked up behind him.

But he is not proposing to devote much money to the country's schools: he wants to spend $26.6bn on education, compared with the $115bn proposed by Mr Gore. The Bush rhetoric on strong defence, too, seems to run counter to the scale of his proposed tax cut. He has promised to increase pay and modernise the forces, but with a third of the funds Mr Gore is promising to spend. To save money, he promises to withdraw troops from peacekeeping engagements. No money appears to have been allocated to the controversial National Missile Defence System he is advocating, calling into question his dedication to the project. The paradox of George W Bush's campaign is that an unideological candidate has acquired a platform which puts class back at the heart of US politics. The explanation lies in the corporate money stacked up behind him.

webTitle: Gore on foreign policy

fields.headline: Hawk has credibility Clinton lacked
fields.standfirst:
Gore on foreign policy

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore has made fewer campaign commitments than George W Bush on foreign affairs and defence, but then few American elections have been won and lost on foreign policy.
fields.body:
Al Gore has made fewer campaign commitments than George W Bush on foreign affairs and defence, but then few American elections have been won and lost on foreign policy.

Mr Gore served in the US army in Vietnam from 1969 to 1971, though he was opposed to the war. Those years give him a credibility with the defence establishment which Bill Clinton never achieved. So also do his years in the Senate, in which he gained the reputation of a conscientious independent thinker on issues such as arms control.

As America's commander-in-chief, he would not be so self-evidently a client of the military-industrial establishment as any Republican president - and certainly Mr Bush - would be. But Mr Gore is a defence hawk, and might favour more aggressive US military stances against opponents such as Iraq.

Last month, after Mr Bush said in his Philadelphia nomination speech that US forces were demoralised, under-resourced and, in some cases, unready for action, Mr Gore mounted a fierce counter-attack, accusing Mr Bush of seeking to "run down America's military for political advantage". This seems to have discouraged further Republican efforts to make defence a major campaign issue.

Mr Gore's position on the National Missile Defence System (NMD) is ambiguous. Officially, he supports the Clinton administration's plan to deploy a limited battery of interceptor missiles, and he has deliberately not attacked Mr Bush for his more ambitious views on the issue. But he is a proven believer in international arms control, and if he wanted to put the NMD issue on hold after he was elected he could do so, and would collect international acclaim for it.

A Gore administration would have the traditional close relations with Europe, but the vice-president does not have the sentimental attachments to England or Ireland which made Bill Clinton a close ally of Tony Blair.

He is probably closer to the Israel lobby than any Democratic presidential candidate in modern times, not least because of Mr Lieberman's presence on the ticket.

European diplomats expect that a Gore administration would be tougher than Clinton's on trade issues.

Mr Gore advocates free trade and the authority to negotiate fast-track trade agreements, but he has hinted at limits to free trade which would set him apart from Mr Bush.

"We must set standards to end child labour, to prevent the exploitation of workers, and the poisoning of the environment," he said last month. In the end, of course, it depends on what those standards are.

webTitle: Radiohead challenge Beatles in Virgin album survey

fields.headline: Radiohead challenge Fab Four as Bends leaves Sgt Pepper in the cold
fields.trailText: Radiohead were always the most grown-up of the Britpop bands that kicked and screamed their way into the nation's affections in the late 1990s.
fields.body:
Radiohead were always the most grown-up of the Britpop bands that kicked and screamed their way into the nation's affections in the late 1990s.

Now, thanks to a combination of inventive songwriting and a preference for examining the human condition rather than the bottom of a pint glass, the five public schoolboys from Oxford are challenging four working class Liverpudlians for the title of greatest band of the rock'n'roll era.

Two Radiohead albums have muscled their way into the top five of the Virgin All Time Top 1,000 Albums millennium edition, territory traditionally dominated by the Beatles. The Fab Four's 1966 Revolver tops the poll, with Sgt Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band at number three and The White Album at number five.

Sandwiched in between, however, are Radiohead's The Bends (2) and OK Computer (4), works which have demonstrated abiding popularity at a time when Oasis, torch carriers of the Britpop scene, are rumoured to be on the verge of collapse.

The Virgin poll of over 200,000 musicians, writers and fans was first conducted seven years ago and is now updated every three years, to reveal underlying trends in popular taste as well as separating the significant from the fleeting.

In the last poll the Radiohead albums were at 10 and 21 respectively, while Oasis was at number nine with (What's The Story) Morning Glory. This time that album has fallen to number 21 while Be Here Now sank from 36 to 459.

The only other band apart from the Beatles to have secured a spot in the poll's top five is Nirvana, whose first album, Nevermind, reached number four in the last poll. Radiohead's achievement will serve to heighten interest in the group's fourth album, Kid A, released next month.

"The rise of Radiohead is phenomenal," said Colin Larkin, who started the survey in 1993.

"No other band, not even Pink Floyd, has ever come close to giving the Fab Four a run for their money. I think we have been searching for many years for a legitimate replacement to the dinosaur bands."

Radiohead aside, very few bands that rose in the 1990s make an impression in a list dominated by the music of the 1960s and 1970s. Blur's Parklife has drifted out of the top 50 in the last three years, but the Stone Roses' eponymous album (12), Portishead's Dummy (41), Definitely Maybe by Oasis (44), and Blue Lines by Massive Attack (28) preserve some dignity for the bright young(ish) things of the last decade.

"Radiohead have followed giants like The Beatles and Pink Floyd, moving into that status of bands who will last the course. They haven't really put a foot wrong. They are bright and have got stuck into their work and we've seen a massive influx of votes for them this time.

"They did well last year along with many of the other Britpop bands, but most of those have fallen by the wayside this time," said Mr Larkin.

The list remains very male and very white. The top 100 contains just 13 albums by black artists, with Kind of Blue by Miles Davis the highest placed, at 12.

The first of the eight albums by female artists on the list is Joni Mitchell's Blue, at 24. Davis matches the Beatles' 14 albums in the full list, while Bob Dylan has 13 entries, three of them in the top 100, led by Blood on the Tracks.

Led Zeppelin, David Bowie, Pink Floyd, U2 and the Rolling Stones all have three albums in the top 100, while American bands represent almost half of the top 100, with REM the highest placed at number six with Automatic for the People.

The earliest album in the top 100 is in final place, Frank Sinatra's 1956 album Songs For Swingin' Lovers. Sinatra may have been bypassed by the rock,n,roll revolution, but he helped to make it possible.

Pop writer Caroline Sullivan said the list revealed more about the people who voted than about the bands themselves.

"The fact that there isn't a single dance album in the top 25 shows who take part in these polls: white middle-aged fans, as opposed to the kids.

"Radiohead are a good choice if you want to seem more intelligent than you really are."

She added: "They are difficult, introspective, contemplative, and an antidote to the dance music that dominates tastes today but which a lot of people don't actually understand."

Will we still love 'em, when they're 64?

webTitle: Economics made easy

fields.headline: Economics made easy
fields.trailText:
Why are the Germans and Swedes fighting over the London Stock Exchange?
The London Stock Exchange used to be owned by its members, the merchant banks and stockbrokers who buy and sell shares on behalf of investors. However, in March, it demutualised and became a publicly-listed company. Its shares can now be traded just like any other company. A Swedish technology company called OM, which owns the Swedish stock exchange, has launched a hostile takeover bid for the London Stock Exchange, which has rather complicated the lattter's own plans. The London Stock Exchange wanted to merge with the Frankfurt bourse to create a new pan-European stock exchange to be called iX, which stands for International Exchange.
fields.body:
Why are the Germans and Swedes fighting over the London Stock Exchange?
The London Stock Exchange used to be owned by its members, the merchant banks and stockbrokers who buy and sell shares on behalf of investors. However, in March, it demutualised and became a publicly-listed company. Its shares can now be traded just like any other company. A Swedish technology company called OM, which owns the Swedish stock exchange, has launched a hostile takeover bid for the London Stock Exchange, which has rather complicated the lattter's own plans. The London Stock Exchange wanted to merge with the Frankfurt bourse to create a new pan-European stock exchange to be called iX, which stands for International Exchange.

What is a stock exchange anyway?
It's just a specialised kind of marketplace - one where the goods on offer are shares in companies. Buying and selling used to take place face to face with dealers shouting bids at each other - the so-called open outcry system. Like most other exchanges, London has moved on to computer-based trading where the prices are available on a screen because it's more efficient.

Why does London want to link up with Frankfurt?
The big investors want to be able to do cross-border deals throughout Europe as easily as if they were buying a share in the same country. At the moment it costs far more to buy shares in another European country, and with the introduction of the euro making cross-border deals more common, investors don't want to pay a premium.

Who is going to win?
London has rejected the Swedish bid, but it may find its shareholders are more sympathetic. Many of the smaller stockbrokers were very unhappy about the proposal to link up with Frankfurt - which would have amounted in practice to a German takeover. They thought it undervalued the London exchange and that there was no guarantee costs would be lower. Now that OM has spiced up the competition, the shareholders hope that London will negotiate a better deal with Frankfurt.

webTitle: Monday briefing

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

TI, the engineering group, has held merger discussions with the American aerospace firm BF Goodrich, valuing the British firm at £2.5bn. At the same time, merger talks have been held with its British engineering rival BBA.

The recently formed Granada Compass hospitality group plans to sell its hotels business, including the Posthouse, Le Meridien and Heritage chains, for more than £3bn.

Centrica, which runs British Gas, will today launch its telecoms business in an effort to poach 10% of British Telecom's 28.5m fixed-line customers. The new service is expected to undercut BT by as much as 25%.

Microsoft is ready to spend $500,000 (£330,000) marketing its new Xbox games console, according to Ed Fries, vice president of games publishing at the software giant.

Sunday Business

Marks & Spencer was hit by another week of plummeting sales in the run-up to the August bank holiday. Group turnover was said to be 8% lower on a like-for-like basis.

Rank is close to selling its holidays division, which includes Butlins and Haven, to the private group Bourne End for around £500m.

Rupert Murdoch's New York Post will slash its price by half this week, launching a price war with its US tabloid rival, the Daily News.

Sunday Telegraph

Vivendi, the French conglomerate, is in negotiations to take over the rest of online directory Scoot.com, valuing the British company at approximately £1.7bn.

Euronext, formed through the merger of the Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels stock exchanges, is holding talks with a series of French banks about helping to finance a bid for the London Stock Exchange.

Jessops, the 190-strong photographic chain, is planning a stock market listing which should value the company at more than £100m.

Sunday Times

The London Stock Exchange and Frankfurt's Deutsche Börse are looking to America's Nasdaq market for a cooperation deal to see off the hostile takeover approach from Sweden's OM Gruppen .

IoS

Instinet, the stockbroking division of information group Reuters, is considering a rival bid for the London Stock Exchange. The offer, which is likely to be made in cash, may come this week.

Sunday Express

A restructuring of the store detectives at Marks & Spencer has left the stores group vulnerable to shoplifting, according to unnamed insiders.

Woman are better at investing than men, according to a survey of investment clubs by Proshare, the private share ownership promoter.

Mail on Sunday

Olof Stenhammar, the founder of Sweden's OM Gruppen, which is trying to take over the London Stock Exchange, was embroiled in an investigation into Sweden's bid for the Olympic Games .

America's Wal-Mart, which owns the Asda supermarket chain, plans to expand its range of non-food goods at 50 stores, raising the stakes in a price war with rivals such as Kingfisher.

webTitle: VSO sheds student image as average age of volunteers rises

fields.headline: VSO sheds student image as average age of volunteers rises
fields.trailText: The average age of people doing voluntary service abroad has risen to over 35, according to the international development agency, VSO. The charity is keen to bury the image that volunteering overseas is limited to students offering untrained labour.
fields.body:
The average age of people doing voluntary service abroad has risen to over 35, according to the international development agency, VSO. The charity is keen to bury the image that volunteering overseas is limited to students offering untrained labour.

Mark Goldring, the chief executive of VSO, said the proportion of volunteers over 50 has quadrupled over seven years from 4% in 1992-3 to 16% last year.

Growing numbers of people wanting a break from established careers has helped to swell applications for voluntary work overseas to record levels. The most common reasons for applying included the wish to give something back, to face a real challenge and to gain professional and personal fulfilment.

"Today a VSO volunteer can be aged up to 70, come from one of 50 professions and be posted to one of 74 countries around the world. The new VSO generation is light years away from the common image of gap-year students digging wells," Mr Goldring said.

The report drew attention to a new phenomenon of "volunteering families", with cases of parents and their adult children working abroad in a developing country on a VSO placement.

One example was the Cummings family from Penrith in Cumbria. Maureen Cummings, 61, a palliative care nurse, said she was preparing to head off to Russia to help set up a hospice volunteer movement in Siberia. Her daughter Rachel, 27, will be going at the same time to become a nurse tutor at Stung Treng in Cambodia.

The family's involvement with volunteering work overseas started four years ago when Rachel's twin sister, Rebecca, took a VSO placement teaching English in China.

Rachel took a tropical medicine diploma to prepare her for the two-year assignment teaching student nurses in Cambodia.

Her mother, Maureen, trained in her youth to work abroad for the World Health Organisation, but never continued her career and married instead. For the last nine years she has been working as a Macmillan nurse in Lancaster, becoming part time when she passed 60.

"I didn't want to finish altogether. Now I'll be working for a year on the other side of the Urals where the concept of palliative care is not yet as advanced as here,"she said.

The VSO volunteers include people who were succeeding in the commercial rat race but finding it increasingly pointless. John Grady, 26, of Hexham, Northumberland, said he was getting no sense of achievement from his £50,000-a-year job as head of software for a Zurich market-making firm dealing in options.

"I never had a good feeling about the work. I was earning lots of money, but I realised it was not doing anything for me and I was not doing anything constructive."

Mr Grady is flying out to Addis Ababa this week on a two-year assignment to help set up computer systems for Ethiopia's education programme.

"I don't know what I'll do after that. I can always get a job in computers, but part of my reason for going is to help me reassess my life and motivation,"he said.

VSO said it had a record 7,645 applications last year and 920 successfully completed the assessment process. It now has nearly 2,000 volunteers working in 74 of the world's poorest countries.

"But in the last year there were over 500 requests for volunteers from employers overseas that VSO was unable to fill. In particular, primary school teachers and skilled technical volunteers such as carpenters, builders, mechanics and metal workers are desperately needed," the organisation said.

webTitle: Carman reveals he has cancer

fields.headline: Carman reveals he has cancer
fields.trailText: George Carman QC, Britain's most celebrated barrister, revealed yesterday that his surprise decision to retire last week came after battling prostate cancer for more than three years.
fields.body:
George Carman QC, Britain's most celebrated barrister, revealed yesterday that his surprise decision to retire last week came after battling prostate cancer for more than three years.

Mr Carman, 70, the most feared cross-examiner of his generation, announced last week that he was retiring immediately on doctors' orders to undergo treatment for a "little local difficulty".

But yesterday on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost he said he had changed his mind about keeping the details secret.

Mr Carman told Sir David Frost: "I feel it important to say, to dispel rumour and for other reasons, that in fact I have suffered from prostate cancer for over three years. I mention that now publicly for these reasons.

"First, I don't want speculation and rumour to continue and so people know exactly what my little problem is.

"But much more importantly, I want to send out a message to people who do suffer from cancer, to tell them that you can work. You can help the doctors enormously by having a positive attitude, and anybody who has the misfortune to get the disease is not at the end of the road.

"I would also like to mention the fact that having looked somewhat at the government figures for cancer research in this country, we are way behind the major European countries and the United States, and I think it is time that problem was addressed by all the political parties."

Mr Carman said that during his fight against the disease, he sometimes underwent medical treatment before court. "Half past eight in the hospital, 9.45 at the Royal Courts of Justice."

He disclosed that he had been undergoing treatment while delivering some of his most memorable courtroom performances, including last year's victory for the Harrods owner, Mohamed Al Fayed, against the former Tory minister, Neil Hamilton, over claims that he took cash for asking questions in parliament.

In one of his many celebrated courtroom soundbites, Mr Carman famously described Mr Hamilton as "on the make and on the take". Mr Hamilton returned the favour in the Mail on Sunday yesterday, describing the QC's courtroom technique as like "squirting an inky jet of half-truths over me like some malign forensic squid".

The most sought-after libel advocate of his generation, he regularly featured in lists of £1m a year QCs, although his earnings were probably not quite that high. In fact, he revealed yesterday that his income was so meagre in his first few years of practice that he washed dishes to make ends meet. After five years he was earning "as much as a Manchester bus driver without overtime".

It was the conspiracy to murder trial of the former Liberal leader, Jeremy Thorpe, that first brought him to prominence. He told Sir David Frost he had pinched from Monsigner Ronald Knox one of his most noted quotes from that trial, his suggestion to the prosecution witness, Peter Bessell, that he saw the 10 commandments as akin to an exam question, only seven of 10 to be attempted.

Mr Carman said he hoped he had never been unnecessarily cruel in court. If he had been cruel it was "necessarily so".

Asked what the government could do about prostate cancer, he said: "I think research lies at the heart of advances in cancer. I think highly trained oncologists and nurses also lie at the heart of it. This country is behind others, significantly behind others, and the message I would send to the prime minister this morning is, in between your scrambled egg, think about that one."

webTitle: Demand drives US jobs success

fields.headline: Demand drives US jobs success
fields.trailText: Advocates of the US model argue that there's nothing about high unemployment in Europe that a good dose of US-style labour-market flexibility couldn't remedy. The US economic recovery since 1996, however, has provided remarkably little support for this diagnosis. The data show that the real secret is old-fashioned macroeconomic policy.
fields.body:
Advocates of the US model argue that there's nothing about high unemployment in Europe that a good dose of US-style labour-market flexibility couldn't remedy. The US economic recovery since 1996, however, has provided remarkably little support for this diagnosis. The data show that the real secret is old-fashioned macroeconomic policy.

The conventional version of the US model rests on three assumptions about job creation: first, that employers need low wages to create jobs; second, that wages must be especially low at the bottom for employers to hire "less-skilled" workers; and third, that even low wages sometimes aren't enough - employers must also be able to hire on flexible terms, including being able to offer part-time, temporary and contract work.

The US boom, however, contradicts each of these assumptions. Since the middle of the 1990s, the US jobs machine has not depended on low wages.

Although the US created jobs between 1979 and 1995, when the inflation-adjusted median wage fell by 7%, the jobs machine only started running in top gear after 1995. Since then, the median wage has risen by more than 7%.

Nor has job creation at the bottom depended on falling wages. Between 1979 and 1995, the real wage for the typical low-wage job fell 17%. Unemployment, however, reached 30-year lows only after 1995, when real wages grew faster at the bottom (more than 9%) than they did at the middle (up 7%) and the top (up 6%).

And recent US employment performance has not relied on "contingent" or "non-standard" jobs. According to US Census data, the shares of regular part-time workers, temp, on-call workers and independent contractors fell between 1995 and 1999. Many European economies already have as many or more non-standard workers than the US.

There, about 17% of workers are part-time, compared with more than 20% in Britain and 17% in France; 2% are temps, compared with 6% in Britain and 10% in France; and only 6% are self-employed, compared with 11% in both Britain and France.

If flexibility is not behind the boom, then what is? The simultaneous rise in employment and wages points towards macroeconomic demand. For better and for worse, three factors have been fuelling that demand.

The first is the rise in household debt. While US politicians have focused on eliminating the national debt, US households have been amassing a mountain of private debt. Between 1995 and 1999, household debt grew from 92% to 103% of disposable income, sparking a consumer-spending spree that has boosted employment (and the trade deficit). Debt, however, cannot grow faster than income indefinitely.

The second demand catalyst is the stock-market bubble, which has reinforced debt-financed consumer spending, particularly among the top 10% of households (which hold 85% of all shares).

Massachusetts Institute of Technology economist James Poterba concluded that, even if households spend only three cents of every $1 increase in their share portfolios, the $6.6 trillion rise in the value of equities between 1995 and 1999 would have raised GDP by 2%.

The final and most important demand factor is the Federal Reserve Board's de facto rejection of the economic profession's now embarrassing consensus supporting a 5.5% to 6% floor for the US unemployment rate. After recession hit in 1991, the Federal Reserve allowed real short-term interest rates to remain near zero for almost two years. When unemployment first fell below 5.5% to 6% in 1995, the Fed wisely adopted a wait-and-see attitude. Just as the Fed lost its nerve, the Asian financial crisis left Alan Greenspan little choice but to lower interest rates to avoid making matters in Asia even worse. (Unfortunately, the Fed appears to have lost its nerve again, despite scant evidence of inflation.)

By contrast, European central bankers have been driving their economies with one foot on the brake. Despite high unemployment, they kept real short-term interest rates at a growth-choking 3% to 4% for most of the 1990s.

The ECB continues to keep rates well above those that the Fed would use at comparable levels of unemployment. With Europe's large pool of unemployed and its respectable productivity growth, the ECB should not be afraid to follow the Fed.

Labour-market flexibility is not responsible for the US boom, demand is. Debt and equity bubbles are the wrong way to run an economy, but growth-oriented macroeconomic policy has been key to US success. Importing US-style flexibility without US-style macroeconomic demand risks ending up with the worst of both worlds: US levels of inequality and continued high unemployment.

John Schmitt is an economist with the Economic Policy Institute in Washington and co-author of the forthcoming The State of Working America (Cornell University Press).

webTitle: Women: Tim Dowling  on tears and the sex divide

fields.headline: Cry baby
fields.standfirst: What makes you reach for your hankie?  Tim Dowling  on tears and the sex divide
fields.trailText: What makes you reach for your hankie?  Tim Dowling  on tears and the sex divide
fields.body:
One thing is for certain: everybody cries. Beyond that, the reasons why we cry and the ways we react to crying change as we grow older, and differ from culture to culture. Now a new study, to be presented later this week at the British Psychological Society's conference, examines the differences between men and women in order to part the veil of tears which divides the sexes.

The findings are the result of 30 men and 57 women being subjected to something called the Adult Crying Inventory, which sounds like a box containing pictures of dead kittens, but is in fact a detailed questionnaire about the experience of weeping. Not surprisingly, the study found marked differences in the way men and women cry. Men are more likely to cry as a result of positive feelings, while women are more likely to cry as a consequence of conflict with other people, or as a result of feeling inadequate.

Some of the reasons for the differences are obvious. Most men have the crying habit drilled out of them at an early age by parents and peers. This may be why men consider crying in women to be a sign of weakness, or worse, manipulation. For men, crying is a debased emotional response, because we know that to some extent it can be controlled unlike say, an ulcer, or a skin rash. We believe women can turn the waterworks on and off at will, and we are jealous because we can only turn them off. Men also regard crying as essentially profitless, since it hasn't got most of us anywhere since we were seven.

Of course the way men cry seems fairly perverse, even to men. Abstinence is the rule from about 13 to 25, leaving most of us woefully out of practice. After the age of 30 tears begin to seep out at strange and inappropriate moments. Men routinely cry at sporting events, particularly when they are happy. Grotesque nostalgia becomes one outlet. Sad and inspirational television programmes are another.

Eventually, having children loosens some kind of screw in the male brain. Tears flow with the arrival of the firstborn and become increasingly difficult to hold at bay. Floodgates open. Fond recollection becomes dangerous territory, as does paternal pride, empathy or worrying about the future. The last time I cried was last week, while recalling my five-year-old son's unfortunate humiliation at the hands of a circus clown. The time before that was at the actual circus. The time before that, if memory serves, was during a Stars In Their Eyes final. You know how it is. They all wanted it so bad.

The study shows that women experience more complex emotions while crying, including fear, anger, powerlessness and frustration. Few men would think of crying in response to such feelings, preferring either repressed panic or choked rage. Suffice to say it was precisely these emotions which transformed Dr Bruce Banner into the Incredible Hulk. While the differences are striking, it's fair to say that men and women have more in common than not in terms of crying. Bereavement is a great leveller, as is the pain of a troubled or snuffed-out relationship. And there is nothing to unite the sexes quite like the sudden loss of a large sum of money, or the weight of an oppressive debt. The last time my wife and I really cried together was only a few days ago, when we received that scary letter regarding the future of our endowment mortgage.

The study shows that women experience more complex emotions while crying, including fear, anger, powerlessness and frustration. Few men would think of crying in response to such feelings, preferring either repressed panic or choked rage. Suffice to say it was precisely these emotions which transformed Dr Bruce Banner into the Incredible Hulk. While the differences are striking, it's fair to say that men and women have more in common than not in terms of crying. Bereavement is a great leveller, as is the pain of a troubled or snuffed-out relationship. And there is nothing to unite the sexes quite like the sudden loss of a large sum of money, or the weight of an oppressive debt. The last time my wife and I really cried together was only a few days ago, when we received that scary letter regarding the future of our endowment mortgage.

webTitle: Cold warriors keep control of Republican defence agenda

fields.headline: Cold warriors keep control of Republican defence agenda
fields.standfirst:
Bush on foreign policy

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Few recent presidential contenders have challenged for the White House with less experience of defence and foreign affairs than George W Bush. But the son of an avowed "foreign policy president" has already surrounded himself with experienced counsellors from the Reagan and Bush Sr years who seem likely to guarantee a traditional Republican approach.
fields.body:
Few recent presidential contenders have challenged for the White House with less experience of defence and foreign affairs than George W Bush. But the son of an avowed "foreign policy president" has already surrounded himself with experienced counsellors from the Reagan and Bush Sr years who seem likely to guarantee a traditional Republican approach.

If Mr Bush becomes president his vice-president will be Dick Cheney, a former defence secretary. He would clearly like to make General Colin Powell his secretary of state.

The former White House Russia adviser Condoleezza Rice seems to be earmarked for the job of national security adviser. Such veterans as Bob Zoellick, Paul Wolfowitz and the "prince of darkness", Richard Perle, are all poised for a comeback

The Bush team is not united on every policy issue, but the Republicans are committed to a package which revives many of the preoccupations of the 1980s. These include increased military spending, expansion of the US weapons and missile programme, a more confront ational approach to China and Russia, and an unconstrained approach to free trade, though many policies from the Clinton years would remain unchanged too.

Mr Bush has tried to make the poor morale of the US armed forces into a campaign issue, and he is committed to spending an extra $1bn a year on military pay, as well as "refashioning our military" with new equipment and weapons.

Chief among these is the national missile defence system (NMD), which he wants to extend well beyond the limits currently under consideration by the Clinton administration.

The Texas governor has said he supports sea- and space-based expansion of the land-based anti-missile system, a scheme which echoes the 1980s star wars project and raises issues with ramifications far beyond US borders. In the worst case, his version of NMD could sour relations with Russia and China, encourage a nuclear missile race between India and Pakistan, and create fresh tension in Nato and other US alliances.

Like Mr Clinton eight years ago, Mr Bush would become a president committed to stopping "endless deployments" of US forces in international crisis zones. "The deployment of our troops creates discontent among our soldiers," he said recently. "We can't be all things to all people."

Neither Mr Bush nor Mr Gore is an isolationist, but Mr Bush in particular intends to ration the extent to which the US becomes directly involved in peacekeeping measures around the world. He is on record as saying that there are no US interests at stake in Africa, and has made it clear that he would not have become involved in Somalia or, in a different regional context, East Timor.

He would also try to set a date for US troops to be withdrawn from the Balkans, and would insist on "exit strategies" for future commitments. Ms Rice said earlier this year that a Bush administration would demand greater commitments and higher levels of defence spending by European countries.

Mr Bush has said very little so far on Britain or Europe generally, but a Republican presidency would trigger a sharp change in relations between the Blair government and the White House after the closeness of the Clinton years - especially on missile defence.

webTitle: Comment: Bush gets rattled

fields.headline: Bush gets rattled
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: It's Labor Day in America when everyone takes a day off - everyone, that is, except the spinners in the rival presidential camps. They are haunted by the legend that he who is ahead in the polls on Labor Day always wins the White House, so with the candidates neck and neck the tempo has accelerated sharply.
fields.body:
It's Labor Day in America when everyone takes a day off - everyone, that is, except the spinners in the rival presidential camps. They are haunted by the legend that he who is ahead in the polls on Labor Day always wins the White House, so with the candidates neck and neck the tempo has accelerated sharply.

To paraphrase Harold Wilson, 24 hours is a long time in the lavishly financed presidential politics of the internet era. Keeping track on just one day is like watching Agassi and Clement.

On August 31, Bush serves at 8.30am with proposals on higher education. Half an hour later, he challenges Gore to detail his education budget. At 9.30am on CNN, he widens the assault, with an online, on air attack on Gore for doing nothing about Medicare while vice president. Forty love.

At 10am Gore comes back with his detailed plan for Medicare, and at 10.15am volleys the Bush ball on what he did as vice president by citing the administration's success in prolonging the solvency of the Medicare Trust Fund from 1999 to 2025. A federal judge in Texas jumps into centre court, finding in a civil suit that Bush has not done enough in the state to care for poor children receiving Medicaid benefits. Deuce.

At 10.30am Gore highlights that morning's Bush admission on CNN that he has no plan to eliminate the national debt, then follows up at 1.30pm, citing new figures that Texas is doing less well in educational tests.

Set one for Gore, maybe, but that is only for starters. It goes on like that throughout the day. When the rest of us are thinking of bed, at 11.50pm, Gore is on web and wire comparing education budgets.

The exchanges represented a reversal for Bush. He had planned to spend the second of a two-week tour entirely on education. Instead, he has had to stage impromptu press conferences to cope with a growing unease about how he would honour all the promissory notes he has been issuing in open-handed Texas style.

In the flurry of the primaries and the spectacle of the conventions, few in press or public bothered about the small print; indeed, the commentators and the chat show jokers kept complaining that Al "Bore" should lighten up instead of worrying so much about the polar ice cap and the wisest way to handle the projected $4 trillion federal surplus. They were more concerned with the earth tones of his suits than the cogency of his arguments. The carefully plotted happy talk campaign that won Bush a second term as governor of Texas seemed to be working on the national stage with a double-digit lead for Bush after his fine performance in the vacuous nominating convention in Philadelphia.

A study by the Pew Research Center found that the press had been "far more likely to convey that Bush is a different kind of Republican, a compassionate conservative, a reformer, bipartisan than to discuss Al Gore's experience, knowledge or readiness for office". Fully 40% of the assertions about Bush proclaimed that he was a different kind of politician, one of Bush's key campaign themes. In contrast, only 14% of the time did the press assert the message that Gore wanted to convey about his experience and competence.

Yet despite the partiality of a generally sour press, a parallel study by Pew finds that the public seems now to have discerned Gore's solid qualities. And according to Gallup, Gore's improvement on 19 issues and personal characteristics is "part of a more generally positive reassessment of the vice president".

Now, with only two months to go, even the conservative press is fretful that Bush has not done his arithmetic. He cannot explain how he would save Social Security and Medicare, spend more on defence and finance prescription drugs for the elderly, while also enacting a $1.6 trillion across the board tax cut. Stumbling responses from Bush, with the usual malapropisms, are a striking contrast to Gore's explicit explanations of programmes targeted to appeal to the working middle class.

Bush is rattled. His managers expected Gore to enjoy a post-convention bounce, but the very latest poll gives Gore a 10-point lead - more than they bargained for. The Bush campaign has panicked. At the end of the week, he approved millions of dollars for 30-second commercials in 16 states - not to explain his policies more thoroughly but to defame Gore. Bush has made it an insistent theme that he renounces the "petty politics of personal destruction", yet that is precisely what he will attempt with sarcastic commercials that mock Gore's character and truthfulness.

It will remind the crucial independent voters that personal nastiness was the Bush way when he had his back to the wall against McCain. It might even provoke the question: Is GW fit to be president?

webTitle: American raiders go for Wolves breweries

fields.headline: American raiders go for Wolves breweries
fields.trailText: American arbitrage firms have been dipping into the market for shares in Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries, placing multimillion pound bets on the company succumbing to an imminent takeover.
fields.body:
American arbitrage firms have been dipping into the market for shares in Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries, placing multimillion pound bets on the company succumbing to an imminent takeover.

Transatlantic raiders have bought nearly 3% of the regional beer group, which is under siege from the venture capital-backed entrepreneur Robert Breare. The biggest seller of stock has been Credit Suisse Asset Management.

However, there is little sign yet of a hostile bid for the company, which makes Banks's, Pedigree and Marston's ale. Mr Breare is hoping that shareholders will exert sufficient pressure to force Wolves' management into friendly discussions.

Mr Breare last month made a tentative offer of 500p-a-share, valuing the business at £472m. He has indicated that he is prepared to raise this to 550p. His backers are reluctant, though, to let him go hostile without access to detailed information about Wolves' pubs, which will reveal exactly how poor summer trading has been.

Wolves' managing director David Thompson has refused to open up the company's books, saying he cannot disclose commercially sensitive data to "every passing venture capitalist".

He has complained that Mr Breare has asked for unusually detailed facts - he wants to know, for example, the number of times the emergency services have had to attend incidents at each of the group's 1,700 pubs.

Mr Breare's financial backers include Botts & Co, Bank of Scotland and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. He is likely to make public his willingness to pay 550p a share. Artbitrageurs, who are buying at the current price of 510p, are likely to want more than this.

Many Wolves shareholders are waiting for a trading update, due at the end of this month, before exerting further pressure on the company to enter takeover talks. The update will include the results of a review of the group's brewing capacity, which is likely to centre on plans to sell breweries at Mansfield and Hartlepool.

Mr Thompson let loose his frustration with the City last week, complaining that the recent weakness in the company's shares was down to prejudice against the Midlands: "It is easy to write off the Midlands but there is plenty of prosperity here and it is an area where people love drinking beer and going to pubs."

webTitle: Women: Caroline Sullivan asks why more and more couples are choosing to live separately

fields.headline: Together apart
fields.standfirst: If you share your lives should you share a home?  Caroline Sullivan asks why more and more couples are choosing to live separately
fields.trailText: If you share your lives should you share a home?  Caroline Sullivan asks why more and more couples are choosing to live separately
fields.body:
Moving in together, setting up home or whatever cosy name you want to give it is, for most of us, a significant marker in the life of a relationship. Mutual domesticity has been universally regarded as a statement of commitment, an inevitable step in a serious relationship.

But according to Jan Trost, a sociologist at the University of Uppsala in Sweden, a growing number of couples are opting out of moving in together. "Living apart together", as he calls it, is already a recognised phenomenon across Europe, where it's well-known by the acronym "lat". While there are no figures for Britain, the growing number of single-person households - currently 16% in England and Wales, with a projection of almost 50% by 2010 - suggests that many will be committed couples who choose not to share their space.

Living apart can be the involuntary consequence of having high-flying careers, like the banking couple I know whose jobs have taken him to London and her to Zurich. They see each other at weekends, and admit it's less than ideal. But living separately is also an increasingly viable choice for people in the same city who simply don't want to explore the netherworld of shared toothpaste. Writer Margaret Drabble and her husband were married for over a decade before finally moving in together - and still insist on a show of independence by occupying different floors of the same house. Woody Allen and Mia Farrow famously had apartments within sight of each other across Central Park for years.

Living together forces a rearrangement of the mental as well as physical furniture which some just don't want to negotiate. Living apart together, on the other hand, doesn't necessarily imply lack of commitment, but instead an acknowledgment of boundaries. The Posh and Becks model of extreme interdependence (where does she end and he begin?) may be the romantic ideal, but those who have opted for autonomy can't praise it enough.

"Two people might be mad about each other, but living together doesn't always feel like a natural progression," observes Karen Frayn, 28, a publisher in a three-year relationship with a co-worker. "It wouldn't exactly be unbearable being in the same living space, but I want to be able to do exactly what I want, when I want. I want to be financially autonomous, and when you're on your own you can prioritise what you do with your money." For her, the biggest boon is "getting to see what I'm like. Maybe it's a control-freak thing, but if I want to do something crazy to the bathroom or something, I can. I don't want to amalgamate personalities."

Her sentiments are echoed by Helen Morris, a 34-year-old nurse, who met her current boyfriend when changing careers five years ago. "Studying for my nursing exams took up 99% of my attention, and even though I loved him I knew I had to make something of myself. It was more important to me than the relationship. So moving in has never come up. I've never wanted to get married or have kids, so this is perfect for me."

She admits that living together would be practical, as she's in a cramped studio flat and he owns a large house, but can't bring herself to compromise. "I wouldn't want to have someone else's things around the house, and I can't bear anyone telling me how to live. People think that by living together they're going to be secure because someone's there looking after them, but it doesn't work that way."

Denise Knowles of Relate, predicts that separate establishments will become increasingly common as women gain financial independence and have less incentive to split the rent. "Women are putting more time and energy into business and haven't got as much energy to put into the domestic side. So they live alone, and when they do see their partner it's special."

As a teenager, living with someone was a milestone that ranked up there with leaving home, and I couldn't wait to have a go. Any hygienic male would have done, but fortunately the first person to suggest it was someone I actually wanted to live with. But within a week of installing myself in his junior-sized flat, we knew it was a mistake. Cramming two adults plus assorted junk into three tiny rooms, though we persevered for a year, ruined the relationship.

I've never tried it again. When another boyfriend suggested buying a place together a few years later, I was enticed by the idea of coming home to someone who knew me well, but realised I needed not just Virginia Woolf's room of one's own, but a whole flat. We ended up living separately for all our six years together, and I'd recommend it to anyone. You enjoy the pleasures of commitment without the boredom and bickering over bills, and if it ends, there's none of the trauma of buying each other out or splitting up possessions.

This alternative to cohabitation also avoids what sociologist Patricia Morgan calls the "rotten deal" women get out of cohabiting. Her book, Marriage Lite, published last month, argues that living together without marriage is financially and emotionally disadvantageous for women - though she's not totally sold on living apart, either. "You might get a better deal out of keeping your own home, I suppose," she concedes. "It's like the aristocrats of the past, occupying separate wings. You'd get some of the advantages of marriage, but is it really commitment?"

My former boyfriend now wonders the same thing. "If you don't live with someone, it makes the long-term prognosis less secure," he says. "Living together means you might lose out on the thrill you feel when you only see someone occasionally, but you gain by getting to know each other better and having greater expectations for the relationship." It seems to be men rather than women who want the security of a shared address. "Well, you do expect at some stage to live together, or you might live alone for the rest of your life," he says.

It's a hard one to get right, as wanting separate places can be taken as a rejection. As Karen Frayn says: "I was anxious that it might ruin the relationship, as he'd worry that I didn't care and didn't love him. He's been incredibly brilliant, but he does want us to live together in the end." Just so long as she's free to do what she likes with the bathroom.

fields.headline: Rentokil plans plant hire sale to start refocus
fields.trailText: Rentokil Initial, the security guards to pest control group, is understood to be close to announcing the sale of its plant hire business to an unnamed buyer.
fields.body:
Rentokil Initial, the security guards to pest control group, is understood to be close to announcing the sale of its plant hire business to an unnamed buyer.

The move comes in the wake of last week's badly received full-year figures. Chief executive Sir Clive Thompson will have to step down if the company fails to meet a new target for earnings growth of at least 8% annually and the proposed sale marks the latest attempt to refocus the sprawling group as a true businesses services specialist.

Sir Clive has been keen to accelerate the group's restructuring, which he blames for a sharp slowdown in earnings growth, and he is likely to use news of the disposal as evidence that Rentokil has finally turned the corner.

The plant division includes rented scaffolding, lifting equipment and specialist cranes used in the offshore industry. Its sale will help Rentokil meet a promise of raising some £600m from disposals before the end of the year.

Sir Clive, who lost his "Mr 20%" soubriquet two years ago when growth faltered and who has watched his share price fall from 470p to a low of 116p over the past 18 months, has promised to spend the proceeds either on fresh acquisitions or on extending the group's share buy-back programme, which has already returned £1bn to shareholders. The shares have subsequently recovered to 157p.

He has refused to be anything other than upbeat on Rentokil's prospects, declaring his resignation from the presidency of the Confederation of British Industry in July as the point at which the "fightback" would begin. "I see this as a born-again Rentokil," he said at last week's results presentation.

But the City has remained wary of Sir Clive's chances of success, with several institutional fund managers privately calling for his early retirement after 18 years as the group's chief executive. Sir Clive is due to stand down in 2003.

webTitle: Persistent sales figures leaks exasperate M&S bosses

fields.headline: Persistent sales figures leaks exasperate bosses
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer's bosses are becoming increasingly frustrated at a series of damaging leaks of weekly sales figures, which are intended for internal circulation only.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer's bosses are becoming increasingly frustrated at a series of damaging leaks of weekly sales figures, which are intended for internal circulation only.

The latest numbers to appear over the weekend revealed that like-for-like sales fell 8% in the seven days to August 26, with key women's wear sales down 17%. This followed a leak last week showing that clothes sales at branches of M&S in Britain had slipped 6% in the week to August 19.

The apparent deterioration in the high street chain's trading could trigger another fall in M&S shares this week. The price fell to a 10-year low of 207.5p last week, amid fears that despite new initiatives, such as advertising and new packaging, the chain's sales trend continues to point downwards, rather than upwards.

M&S has refused to say whether any of the leaked data is accurate, although company insiders insist that the weekly statistics are irrelevant when taken out of context. One M&S source said yesterday: "Week by week sales figures vary depending on the weather, people's moods and how well England are doing at the cricket. You can't plan a business on a week-by-week basis."

Insiders claim the current period is not directly comparable with last year, when M&S was holding a clearance sale. The company insists that the real test of its recovery strategy will come when a £60m refurbishment programme has been completed to revamp 21 stores by the end of the year.

M&S has been dogged by detailed leaks throughout its long-running crisis, which began after former director Keith Oates launched an unsuccessful public attempt to unseat the company's autocratic chairman Sir Richard Greenbury in 1998. Sir Richard eventually agreed to take early retirement, amid signs of an alarming deterioration in the high street chain's performance.

webTitle: Boom towns mask plight of state's have-nots

fields.headline: Boom towns mask plight of state's have-nots
fields.standfirst:
Bush on tax and economy

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Nestling deep in the sun belt of the south, Austin is booming. The Texas state capital is light on regulation, light on tax and, according to Forbes magazine, one of the best cities in the US in which to do business. One of the titans of the new global economy - Dell computers - has its headquarters in the city.
fields.body:
Nestling deep in the sun belt of the south, Austin is booming. The Texas state capital is light on regulation, light on tax and, according to Forbes magazine, one of the best cities in the US in which to do business. One of the titans of the new global economy - Dell computers - has its headquarters in the city.

It is this side of the Texan economy that George W Bush will be seeking to exploit in this his campaign.

He would like to convince voters that the whopping increases in real incomes enjoyed by workers in the computer sector are the result of his hands-off economic management of the state. Since he became governor, 1m new jobs and almost 50,000 new businesses have been created.

However, as with the US economy as a whole, there is another side to the story. Texas may be one of the handful of states not to levy its own income tax in addition to the federal income tax, but it has also seen a marked increase in inequality and poverty under Mr Bush.

In 1990 it was ranked by the census bureau as the eighth poorest state; the latest figures show that it is now the fifth poorest, with only Louisiana, Mississippi, New Mexico and West Virginia ranked lower.

Mr Bush's supporters argue that he has made a success of welfare-to-work policies; critics say that the emphasis on pushing people into low-paid jobs has left education and training neglected. Despite the presence of world-beating companies such as Dell, Texas produces fewer scientists and engineers than the average state, and ranks 48th in basic literacy.

One of Mr Bush's main policies in the election is his tax-cutting plan to help ordinary working families, working mothers and other low-income Americans.

The Democrats say that the governor's record in his home state has been one of failure, leaving low-income Texans worse off than working families in other states.

In 1998 Texas ranked 50th -last - in the union for women without health insurance and 43rd for women living in poverty. Almost 18% of Texan working parents had low earnings - defined as too meagre to lift a family of four out of poverty despite full time work - and Texas ranks third in the US in hunger.

The environmental impact of Mr Bush's economic policies are likely to become a campaign issue.

Houston has become the smog capital of the US, and the Republican presidential candidate has removed restrictions on development in Texas, opposes any curbs on trade in genetically modified food, and would completely repudiate the aims of the Kyoto climate agreement.


Texas facts :

 Unemployment rate 4.5%

 48,000 new businesses created under Bush

 Almost £3bn in tax cuts

 Fifth largest proportion in US of population living in poverty

 25%of Texan children (1.4m) lack health insurance

webTitle: A Country Diary

fields.headline: Close encounter
fields.standfirst: Queen Elizabeth National Park, Uganda
fields.trailText: The Chambura Gorge on the south-eastern edge of Uganda's most popular wildlife reserve has to be one of the most atmospheric locations in this primate-rich country to see chimpanzees. Move just a 100 metres from the edge and you could easily imagine that the grassland flanking it on two sides forms a continuous open plain. Only when you stand on its very lip can you appreciate how the gorge runs like a deep gash in the earth's crust for about 10 kilometres. The sandy tones of the savanna suddenly give way to a ribbon of vibrant green as the forest boils up on both sides almost to the rim.
fields.body:
The Chambura Gorge on the south-eastern edge of Uganda's most popular wildlife reserve has to be one of the most atmospheric locations in this primate-rich country to see chimpanzees. Move just a 100 metres from the edge and you could easily imagine that the grassland flanking it on two sides forms a continuous open plain. Only when you stand on its very lip can you appreciate how the gorge runs like a deep gash in the earth's crust for about 10 kilometres. The sandy tones of the savanna suddenly give way to a ribbon of vibrant green as the forest boils up on both sides almost to the rim.

The chimpanzees inhabiting this dramatically enclosed world once passed their lives in almost total secrecy. Until 1989 only the local healers visiting the gorge to collect medicinal plants knew of the apes' presence. Since then, however, the group of about 25 has been habituated to the presence of humans and small numbers of tourists visit daily.

Although the guides are experts at relocating them, to see them well is by no means straightforward. The chimps easily melt away in the dense forest and after several hours of trekking we were delighted to see two dark shapes ghosting into the undergrowth. After much manoeuvring we were able to watch two youngsters sleeping off their morning's exertions, while a full-grown adult sat just five metres away, stripping lengths of vine and grinding up the fleshy pith.

An unavoidable part of any response to chimps is the sense of encountering another mammal species so closely resembling ourselves: the dexterous hands, the easy manipulation of food, the facial gestures animated by a whole range of recognisable emotions. But one of the most resonant parts of this encounter was to hear the guides describe how chimpanzees with a cold or cough, which they can catch from us, habitually use a particular tree as medicine. I now have a small flake of the wood and just a few fibres release a powerful menthol taste and fiery burning sensation on the tongue. It would be fascinating to know if this had any cross-over benefits for humans.
