webTitle: Leader: Welcome decision by Clinton to delay national missile defence

fields.headline: Delayed fuse
fields.standfirst:
The world is safer - for five months
The NMD explained
fields.trailText: With the announcement that he is not going ahead with national missile defence (NMD), Bill Clinton did two immensely welcome things. He made the world a safer place, at least for the five months until his successor takes over and possibly for longer if his action has strengthened his vice-president, Al Gore. For he has given the electors of the United States further evidence that Bush and Gore do differ.
fields.body:
With the announcement that he is not going ahead with national missile defence (NMD), Bill Clinton did two immensely welcome things. He made the world a safer place, at least for the five months until his successor takes over and possibly for longer if his action has strengthened his vice-president, Al Gore. For he has given the electors of the United States further evidence that Bush and Gore do differ. Mr Gore's response to the president's statement was warm, welcoming the chance to take stock. So a gulf opened between him and his Republican opponent: a vote for George W Bush in November thus becomes a vote to destabilise international relations, to squander American treasure and to enhance a sense of magical emancipation from the world's troubles that can only, given the global asymmetry of economic and military might, be dangerous for us all.

Mr Clinton's hand was forced by technology. The "hit-to-kill" interceptor rockets fired in South Pacific tests failed to connect. Will they ever? Mr Clinton said deferment would not necessarily affect eventual deployment. But he must know the cost-benefit case for NMD has been weakened. Even Star Wars-weaned Americans can see that unless NMD offers 100% security it is worthless; yet the cost of attaining 100% could be infinitely greater than reaching even 90%-plus.

In the circumstances he did what a lame duck president had to do - kick the dossier into his successor's in-tray. But Mr Clinton's role does not end there. He understands, as the Republican contender cannot or will not, that NMD offers nothing towards the long-run accommodation the United States must make with China. There is a "rogue state" problem but it is inseparable from the large question of American engagement with regional theatres of conflict, in the Middle East as in east Asia. Because he has superior understanding Mr Clinton must use the next few months to educate his fellow countrypeople, for example about NMD's dangers for the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty. This entails an active role in the election campaign. Who else is equipped to explain just why the Texas governor's glib offer to extend NMD to Europe and the Middle East is ridiculous? To call differences between Democrats and Republicans life and death is hyperbolic - Mr Gore affirms he still wants some kind of missile system. But after the president's wise deferral, the choice is much clearer cut.

webTitle: War leaves golfers teed-off and bunkered

fields.headline: War leaves golfers teed-off and bunkered
fields.standfirst: Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: The fourth hole of Freetown's golf course has long presented an interesting array of obstacles. A couple of years ago someone planted a landmine next to the "brown" - the sand substitute for a green. On Saturday, the challenge came from a machete-wielding man and two dogs in pursuit of a monkey for the pot.
fields.body:
The fourth hole of Freetown's golf course has long presented an interesting array of obstacles. A couple of years ago someone planted a landmine next to the "brown" - the sand substitute for a green. On Saturday, the challenge came from a machete-wielding man and two dogs in pursuit of a monkey for the pot.

Still, there is nowhere else for the diminishing band of golfers to play. The Freetown club is the last surviving of six courses once dotted around Sierra Leone. Most simply fell into disuse and disrepair as the nine-year-old civil war grew more brutal, and the expatriates fled in droves. The course at Yengema was dug up by miners in search of diamonds.

The Freetown club house is a sad reflection of the country, but also of a budding optimism. Where once there were trophies now there are bullet holes after soldiers of the defunct military junta looted the place. The lists of trophy winners carefully painted on varnished boards come to a grinding halt in 1997, the year of the coup that marked another downturn in Sierra Leone's fate.

The mine at the fourth hole was planted by soldiers of the former military junta who were resisting a Nigerian-led intervention force that reinstated the elected government of President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah. The captured soldier who showed the Nigerians the mine was promptly shot for his trouble.

After that the army used the course as a training ground. Still the club did not close.

"The only time we could play golf at that time was on a Sunday when they weren't training," said James Lebbie, Sierra Leone's most successful professional golfer.

The war is not as intrusive as it was. The police have pitched a tent next to the eighth hole as a guardpost for the neighbouring road. It is less intimidating than the days when the Nigerians had a machine-gun post in the bunker.

But membership has more than halved from a peak of about 250. Most of those who play today are expatriates, many serving with the United Nations. The Sierra Leoneans are generally "drinking members", who spend their time in the club house.

Freetown golf club was founded by British colonists in 1904 and moved to its present location overlooking a glistening white beach 70 years ago. Sierra Leoneans were not permitted to join until independence in 1961.

James Lebbie was not the first black player in the country but he is certainly its most renowned after a profitable career on the "Safari Circuit" of professional tournaments from South Africa to the former Zaire, Kenya and Nigeria.

Mr Lebbie was drawn into golf as a caddie to earn pocket money. He started playing when he was 15 and two years later turned professional with the encouragement of two Scottish players at the Freetown club who helped to arrange sponsorship from a Scotch whisky distiller.

He won the Sierra Leone open every year between 1985 and 1990, and was the first African to win the Nigerian open. But pride of place in Mr Lebbie's living room is a picture of him with Spain's Seve Ballesteros, a memento from when they were opponents in the first Africa versus Europe golf competition seven years ago.

"I made myself a bit of money. It was from golf that I built this house. I don't have any debts. I educated my kids. But for any professional now it is much more difficult. There are no sponsors any more," he said.

But what optimism there is in Freetown is reflected in the golf club. Once it was a nine-hole course, then 12. Mr Lebbie redesigned it and raised the number of holes to 17. Some serve a dual purpose. Hole number five is a knockabout football pitch on a Sunday.

None of this discourages the young caddies who are allowed to play on weekday mornings when the members are at work. Among them is 15-year-old James.

"Everyone says that this is a very difficult course because of all the problems we have. If I can be good here I will be able to win anywhere," he said.

 More than a week after 11 British soldiers were kidnapped by a renegade military force, and days since half the group were freed, negotiations were continuing yesterday to gain the release of the six remaining soldiers, a British official said.

Lieutenant Commander Tony Cramp, a spokesman for Britain's military force in Sierra Leone, said negotiators were in contact with the West Side Boys, the ill-disciplined army gang that seized the soldiers on August 25, but there was no prospect of immediate release.

webTitle: Germany's CDU tainted by new corruption claim

fields.headline: Germany's CDU tainted by new corruption claim
fields.standfirst: Special report: the German corruption scandal
fields.trailText: A leading figure in Germany's Christian Democrats faced pressure to resign yesterday amid fresh corruption charges alleging that the opposition party had accepted an illegal £140,000 payment from big business.
fields.body:
A leading figure in Germany's Christian Democrats faced pressure to resign yesterday amid fresh corruption charges alleging that the opposition party had accepted an illegal £140,000 payment from big business.

Roland Koch, the rightwing prime minister of the central state of Hesse, was accused in two media reports of accepting the donation from the German Industry Insurance Association (HDI), which allegedly paid the cash to a political academy to avoid detection.

Another report by Hesse radio accused Mr Koch of running an illicit bank account to store illegal donations to the party.

Yesterday Mr Koch denied the reports and insisted that the HDI payments to the Hesse Academy for Political Education had not been used by the CDU for electioneering or other political purposes. "The academy is not a money-laundering machine," he said

However an HDI spokesman confirmed that the payment was intended as financial backing for Mr Koch: "We wanted to support Mr Koch's work, but we did not want to make unfocused payments into CDU party accounts," he said. The spokesman denied that the donation was illegal.

In response to the latest in a series of corruption allegations levelled at Germany's main conservative party since November, the Social Democratic (SPD) chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, said: "A fish stinks at the head. The CDU is dragging its feet in clearing up the mire caused by its illegal party funding arrangements."

Other SPD and Green party politicans in the government coalition demanded Mr Koch's immediate resignation.

"Koch's credibility is shattered," the finance minister, Hans Eichel, said yesterday.

The allegations appeared certain to accelerate the decline of the CDU's popularity. Last year the party elected an east German politican, Angela Merkel, as leader to try to lessen the damage caused by the corruption scandal surrounding former Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

However, an opinion poll broadcast at the weekend by ZDF television showed that the CDU was almost 10 percentage points behind the government coalition.

Meanwhile, Ms Merkel joined colleagues and industry leaders yesterday in blaming Mr Schröder's government for the decline of the euro. "The government has been either playing down or staying silent about the continuing weakness of the euro," Ms Merkel told the newspaper Welt am Sonntag.

She said the currency's weakness was caused by the failure of EU member states, including Germany, to make radical economic reforms.
fields.bodyText: A leading figure in Germany's Christian Democrats faced pressure to resign yesterday amid fresh corruption charges alleging that the opposition party had accepted an illegal £140,000 payment from big business. Roland Koch, the rightwing prime minister of the central state of Hesse, was accused in two media reports of accepting the donation from the German Industry Insurance Association (HDI), which allegedly paid the cash to a political academy to avoid detection. Another report by Hesse radio accused Mr Koch of running an illicit bank account to store illegal donations to the party. Yesterday Mr Koch denied the reports and insisted that the HDI payments to the Hesse Academy for Political Education had not been used by the CDU for electioneering or other political purposes. "The academy is not a money-laundering machine," he said However an HDI spokesman confirmed that the payment was intended as financial backing for Mr Koch: "We wanted to support Mr Koch's work, but we did not want to make unfocused payments into CDU party accounts," he said. The spokesman denied that the donation was illegal. In response to the latest in a series of corruption allegations levelled at Germany's main conservative party since November, the Social Democratic (SPD) chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, said: "A fish stinks at the head. The CDU is dragging its feet in clearing up the mire caused by its illegal party funding arrangements." Other SPD and Green party politicans in the government coalition demanded Mr Koch's immediate resignation. "Koch's credibility is shattered," the finance minister, Hans Eichel, said yesterday. The allegations appeared certain to accelerate the decline of the CDU's popularity. Last year the party elected an east German politican, Angela Merkel, as leader to try to lessen the damage caused by the corruption scandal surrounding former Chancellor Helmut Kohl. However, an opinion poll broadcast at the weekend by ZDF television showed that the CDU was almost 10 percentage points behind the government coalition. Meanwhile, Ms Merkel joined colleagues and industry leaders yesterday in blaming Mr Schröder's government for the decline of the euro. "The government has been either playing down or staying silent about the continuing weakness of the euro," Ms Merkel told the newspaper Welt am Sonntag. She said the currency's weakness was caused by the failure of EU member states, including Germany, to make radical economic reforms.

webTitle: Travel tips

fields.headline: Travel tips
fields.trailText: How on earth did Elizabeth Cripps (Alone in a man's world, Travel, September 2) manage to experience so many problems on a short holiday to Egypt? I have made many visits to the country and have never run into so much bother. For a woman travelling alone, a little common sense and forward-planning are enough to prevent most annoyances.
fields.body:
How on earth did Elizabeth Cripps (Alone in a man’s world, Travel, September 2) manage to experience so many problems on a short holiday to Egypt? I have made many visits to the country and have never run into so much bother. For a woman travelling alone, a little common sense and forward-planning are enough to prevent most annoyances.

To avoid harrassment on public transport, for example, Ms Cripps could have jumped into one of the women’s carriages on the Cairo underground. She may have enjoyed “opening her eyes” to see the Pyramids from a hotel swimming pool, but had she been able to keep her eyes open for the whole of the trip, she might have been able to make a more enjoyable experience of it all.

Yasmine
London

webTitle: Doubts about the power of faith

fields.headline: Doubts about the power of faith
fields.trailText: Faisal Bodi's support of the Conservative party's proposal to licence faith groups to provide welfare is not sensible (Getting religion, August 31). He justifies his support by pointing out faith groups' involvement in public projects for their neighbourhoods. Such involvement does indeed exist and on a large scale. We have such projects in Bristol: Active Communities Together is trying to broker a link between Lloyds Bank and a building and drugs project, and we are involved in a project with schools to improve the quality of education delivered to their children.
fields.body:
Faisal Bodi's support of the Conservative party's proposal to licence faith groups to provide welfare is not sensible (Getting religion, August 31). He justifies his support by pointing out faith groups' involvement in public projects for their neighbourhoods. Such involvement does indeed exist and on a large scale. We have such projects in Bristol: Active Communities Together is trying to broker a link between Lloyds Bank and a building and drugs project, and we are involved in a project with schools to improve the quality of education delivered to their children.

But Mr Bodi is quite wrong to deduce from all this that faith communities can or should take on national responsibility for caring in the public sector. First, faith communities have no monopoly on compassion; second, it is unlikely that nation-wide they would be able to put in place and keep in place the bureaucratic structure for such general provision; third, the Conservative party's proposal would make faith communities dependent on government money. One-off grants is one thing, continuous funding another. The response that faith communities are making to local public need is based on their own initiatives and their links with their local communities. It would damage their relationships with their neighbourhoods if they were to become agents of government with a formal obligation to provide care. They have their own proper power and are beginning to use it. They should not look to get power from the state. Religion and politics can mix; faith groups do have parts to play in the public arena; but this is not the way it should be done.

Michael Birtchnell
Bristol

 Faisal Bodi excludes people like me, committed atheists, from any compassionate concern for the welfare of children, the poor, the disadvantaged or, indeed, for society in general. It isn't the atheists, Mr Bodi, who advocate in the US and elsewhere the most illiberal and draconian social, educational and penal policies.

Being caring and compassionate is an essential part of being human and is not dependant on adhering to any religious dogma.

Rose Galt
Cumbernauld, Glasgow
rose@kildrum.demon.co.uk

 Faisal Bodi makes the all too common, and depressing, mistake of equating religion with morality. A glance at religious behaviour through the centuries, or a reading acquaintance with the harsh and frequently cruel worlds of the Bible and the Koran should be enough to convince anyone that religion is not always a good example to set before a caring society.

Dr Diana Bishop
London
dibishop@llyn.demon.co.uk

 In Australia the public Jobseeker services (and their staffs) were sub-contracted to the religious organisations - at least one of which promptly decided it would only employ people committed to their faith. And the "compassionate conservative" minister could see nothing wrong.

Patrick Wallace
London E14 3TG
pat@pjw74og.u-net.com

 Can you imagine the ghetto-isation that would result if churches took over hospitals and other public services? Religious groups seem to hate each other quite passionately. Is it likely that they would treat members of other religious communities properly and fairly?

If I have an accident or fall sick, I want to be treated by health professionals with modern attitudes, not by someone who thinks that praying for me is as effective as surgery. I shudder to think what might happen if my local hospital were to be run by Jehovah's Witnesses.

Geof Branch
London
geofbranch@cs.com

 From my experience with a local charity which finds emergency overnight accommodation for homeless young people, I am more and more alarmed at the state's increasing reliance on voluntary bodies to do work that is properly that of the state. The fact that there is a mismatch between the government's public targets and the capacities of a myriad of small voluntary bodies is neither here nor there. This sort of cynicism one expects from Conservatism, especially when labelled "compassionate". What a pity we're seeing it from New Labour also.

Barry Thorpe
Cheadle, Stockport
barrythorpe@beeb.net

 If you ask the average Yusuf Bloggs living in a run-down area what their number one priority for the government is, the answer is not likely to be "greater involvement of Muslim-faith organisations in provision of publicly funded services". It will be health, education and crime and so the question one needs to ask oneself is surely whether one should support the party that attacks foreign doctors' language skills in the NHS, is lukewarm about the Lawrence Report and whose school funding policy could lead to yet more language-support teachers being cut. All these issues will affect the poorest Muslims far more than the technicalities of public funding regimes, and as women and men of faith, we Muslims are supposed to think about those in greatest need.

Joe Ahmed-Dobson
London

webTitle: Doctors in need of speech therapy

fields.headline: Doctors in need of speech therapy
fields.trailText: In the debate about language tests for foreign doctors ('Knowing English does not make you a good doctor', September 2), some questions are mysteriously missing from the argument .
fields.body:
In the debate about language tests for foreign doctors ('Knowing English does not make you a good doctor', September 2), some questions are mysteriously missing from the argument .

Why is the UK so heavily reliant on foreign doctors? Is it just a question of money? If so, Britain is paying the high price of putting patients at risk: in almost three years in this country I have seen enough appalling foreign doctors to justify this statement.

While it is true that most overseas non-EU doctors speak English to a degree, their abilities are often merely academic. They might be able to discuss the latest papers in the BMJ, but they cannot communicate with patients because they cannot understand the everyday language. While Dr Shanmugadasan is right that speaking English well does not make you a good doctor, he overlooks one aspect that is very important in the doctor-patient relationship: the ability to relate to the socio-cultural background of patients.

It is true that there is racism in the NHS, but it is not only the British who are guilty of it. I have seen departments with exclusively Asian consultants that will only employ other Asian doctors. The only white doctors were recruited through a rotation where the consultants had no influence.

Therefore it is the EU doctors who find it most difficult obtaining a post, because there are very few German, Dutch or Spanish consultants who exercise control over who is employed.

Dr Ralf Genthe
(State Exam Berlin Medical School 1996)
Westcliff on Sea, Essex

 The doctors quoted in your article might be excellent speakers of English, but on the evidence of their comments their comprehension skills are dangerously inadequate. They have misunderstood almost everything Liam Fox said. He did not say that speaking English well makes you a good doctor: he said that speaking it badly makes you a danger to your patients, a claim which everyone would surely accept.

David S Collins
Harpenden

fields.trailText: In attributing to Transport 2000 the figure of 5,000 deaths on the roads in Great Britain, page 9, September 1, we omitted the words "and seriously injured". In 1999, a total of 3,423 people were killed on the roads in Great Britain. This included car occupants, cyclists, pedestrians, motorcyclists and those killed in buses, coaches and HGVs.
fields.body:
In attributing to Transport 2000 the figure of 5,000 deaths on the roads in Great Britain, page 9, September 1, we omitted the words "and seriously injured". In 1999, a total of 3,423 people were killed on the roads in Great Britain. This included car occupants, cyclists, pedestrians, motorcyclists and those killed in buses, coaches and HGVs.

In our leader, Heated exchanges, page 19, August 31, we said that in the first quarter of this year direct investment abroad at £125.25m had already matched that for the whole of last year. That should have been £125.25bn.

In a roundup of "the news in numbers", page 4, The Editor, September 1, we said "11 people [are] thought to have died from the meningitis C vaccine since mass immunisations were introduced last year". We should have said 12 people had died "after" rather than "from" taking the vaccine and made it clear that whatever suspicion of links it was not possible to say that anyone had been killed by the vaccine.

In an article headed Fit for a prince, page 12 (Arts), G2, August 30, we said that the National Theatre's recent visit to Elsinore was the first since the 1930s. That was our addition to the author's original copy and, in fact, wrong. Among performances of Hamlet there since then was a notable one in 1979 starring Derek Jacobi.

webTitle: Our new generation gap

fields.headline: Our new generation gap
fields.trailText: As James Meek suggests (Home-made answer to generating electricity harks back to the past, September 2), the idea of using a Stirling engine in combination with a central heating boiler would save the consumer up to £300 a year on his electricity bills.
fields.body:
As James Meek suggests (Home-made answer to generating electricity harks back to the past, September 2), the idea of using a Stirling engine in combination with a central heating boiler would save the consumer up to £300 a year on his electricity bills.

As the person who initiated practical work in the UK on this concept, perhaps I can add that the development of "Micro CHP" (combined heat and power) has shown British initiative at its worst. For a start, there was no Stirling engine at an advanced design stage in this country. I had to visit, on behalf of British Gas, Sweden, the United States and New Zealand to locate a viable machine. And despite the fact that the UK is uniquely suited, in terms of population, gas supply and climate, to this form of home based power, it has proved impossible to attract the level of funding necessary. At least £30m was necessary for proper commercialisation. Instead a fraction of this came, in dribs and drabs. It was R&D on a drip feed.

One can only contrast this with the hundreds of millions that still go into nuclear power, either directly or as hidden subsidies. For a fraction of this the UK could begin to switch over to home based generation of electricity, and in its train, a completely new set of energy saving, manufacturing industries.

Fred Starr
Ashtead, Surrey
starrfred@yahoo.com

webTitle: UN's corporate partners

fields.headline: UN's corporate partners
fields.trailText: I must protest at George Monbiot's article (Getting into bed with big business, August 31). To our knowledge, never has any president of the general assembly or any UN secretariat official ever announced that business would be given a formal role in UN decision-making. The idea is preposterous.
fields.body:
I must protest at George Monbiot's article (Getting into bed with big business, August 31). To our knowledge, never has any president of the general assembly or any UN secretariat official ever announced that business would be given a formal role in UN decision-making. The idea is preposterous.

The secretary-general did not launch the Business Humanitarian Forum, it is a business NGO; nor has he ever attended any of its meetings; nor is it co-chaired by the UN high commissioner for refugees.

The UN development programme project referred to did not include Nike or Shell, and no logo was developed for it.

The secretary-general's Global Compact, which is intended to identify and promote good corporate practices in the areas of human rights, labour standards and the environment, is an equal partnership among business, organised labour and NG0s - not merely a UN-business partnership. The partners in the compact are no more entitled to use of the UN's logo than anyone else.

Relatively few of the corporate partners in the Global Compact could be described as "most controversial corporations" (the list is posted on our website, www.unglobalcompact.org) But surely the idea is not that we should limit our efforts to promote good practices by working only with companies that have spotless records. What would be the point?

Readers of the Guardian deserve better commentaries than they have got from Mr Monbiot - and so, too, does the United Nations.

John G Ruggie
Assistant secretary-general,
UN information centre, London

webTitle: Germans 'should vote on EU enlargement'

fields.headline: Germans 'should vote on EU enlargement'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European Commission
fields.trailText: The European Union's grandiose plan to admit as many as 13 new countries in the next decade was thrown into confusion last night after the man in charge of the process suggested that the sceptical German public should vote on the matter.
fields.body:
The European Union's grandiose plan to admit as many as 13 new countries in the next decade was thrown into confusion last night after the man in charge of the process suggested that the sceptical German public should vote on the matter.

In an interview which will anger countries such as Poland who are anxious to join the EU as soon as possible, the EU's enlargement commissioner Günter Verheugen said that a referendum should be held in Germany to ensure that the public there are not presented with a "fait accompli".

Controversially, Mr Verheugen, a German national, claimed that the euro had been introduced "behind the backs of the population" and said that there should have been a referendum on the single currency to "force the elites to come down from their ivory towers and campaign for the euro in a dialogue with the people".

Germany should not, he stressed, make the same mistake with enlargement as it had with the single currency.

His comments, reported in Saturday's Süddeutsche Zeitung, prompted his boss Romano Prodi, the EC president, to demand an explanation. Mr Prodi promised to "clarify" what he described as "a small misunderstanding" in the coming days.

Mr Verheugen was also criticised by the French, German and Finnish foreign ministers although his own spokesman later claimed that he had only been expressing his personal views and was not seeking to delay enlargement.

EU commissioners traditionally refrain from speaking so openly about their home countries but Mr Verheugen even went so far as to suggest that German fears about an influx of cheap labour and a crime wave as a result of enlargement were "valid".

Several EU foreign ministers, attending an informal meeting in France, spoke darkly about a plot by Berlin to delay expansion and suggested that Mr Verheugen was taking orders from the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder.

The EU is negotiating with 10 eastern european countries and two Mediterranean island states. Turkey is also a candidate for membership, although is unlikely to be admitted any time soon.

Although it is estimated that these newcomers would swell the EU's 370m-strong population by 30% it is also reckoned that they would increase the bloc's income by a paltry 8%.

Several EU foreign ministers, attending an informal meeting in France, spoke darkly about a plot by Berlin to delay expansion and suggested that Mr Verheugen was taking orders from the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder. The EU is negotiating with 10 eastern european countries and two Mediterranean island states. Turkey is also a candidate for membership, although is unlikely to be admitted any time soon. Although it is estimated that these newcomers would swell the EU's 370m-strong population by 30% it is also reckoned that they would increase the bloc's income by a paltry 8%.

webTitle: 'I paint forms as I think, not as I see'

fields.headline: 'I paint forms as I think, not as I see'
fields.standfirst: Was this a headache for Picasso?
fields.trailText: Ever since Picasso became famous after the first world war, cartoonists have joked that he saw things in a funny way. No other painter has so systematically attacked the way we think we look at the world, and especially the human face, transposing noses and eyes, depicting people from front and back at the same time. Picasso said: "I paint forms as I think them, not as I see them."
fields.body:
Ever since Picasso became famous after the first world war, cartoonists have joked that he saw things in a funny way. No other painter has so systematically attacked the way we think we look at the world, and especially the human face, transposing noses and eyes, depicting people from front and back at the same time. Picasso said: "I paint forms as I think them, not as I see them."

In 1906 Picasso was working on a portrait of his friend, the writer and art collector, Gertrude Stein. It was a conventional painting, with echoes of Ingres, but Picasso could not get the face right. Eventually he rubbed out this part of the painting, went on holiday to Spain where he saw primitive mask-like faces of ancient Iberian sculpture, went home and painted her face as a mask sutured to her body. Picasso did not say he saw Stein like this - although he joked it was how she would come to look. And as it is the most famous image of her, she has. This was the beginning of the Cubist revolution, a term first applied by a contemptuous critic to the almost colour-free, multi-angled paintings that Picasso and Georges Braque made in the 1900s.

The first Cubist paintings are obscure visual puzzles, but not just a tease. They dismantle the Renaissance idea of a painting as a coherent picture seen from a fixed point of view, replacing it with a succession of glances.

These paintings were seen by contemporary admirers, and art historians since, as conducting the same revolution in art that Einstein was carrying out in science. Cubist paintings do not assume the observer to be someone outside the picture but place us in a complex world whose nature is determined by our attempts to make sense of it.

That is one way people have seen Cubism. Yet Picasso was dismissive of critics who saw his Cubist paintings as philosophical exercises and tried to understand them through "mathematics, trigonometry, chemistry, psychoanalysis and whatnot". He was even more dismissive of the idea that he was an abstract artist.

Picasso's visual distortions are always poetic, never more so than in the 1937 series of Weeping Woman paintings that Michel Ferrari interprets as inspired by "migraine aura". Whether or not he did get migraines we know these paintings were made in response to the suffering of Spain in the civil war; the brutal, traumatic distortions of this woman's face are marks of pain. The time was out of joint. And that is what the distortions tell us.

webTitle: Weekend TV

fields.headline: Mash landing
fields.trailText: Anchor Me | Last of The Blonde Bombshells
fields.body:
So now we know. All it takes for Iain Glen to give you a tingly, toe-curling snog is a good dollop of mashed potato in your hair. Forget yon Aveda rosemary and mint equalising conditioning rinse. For a smooch, get Smash.

Well it worked in Anchor Me (ITV, Sun), in which Glen played Nathan Carter, a well-to-do architect returning to his home town upon news his mother is terminally ill. In doing so, he reawakens old family resentments, stirs the festering silence surrounding the death of his youngest brother and, with his own son in tow, demonstrates the joys of dysfunctional relationships, the perils of class mobility and Things Not To Do in the Kitchen After Dinner.

Chief among those being kissing your surviving brother's wife. Of course, had she - Jackie - not ended up with mashed potato in her hair (thrown by husband Billy), the snog might never have happened. But Billy has a chip on his shoulder about Nathan's social clambering and truancy from family events. So, as is the way, Billy lashed out with the mash at his wife, who also happens to be Nathan's ex. Hence, it was tubers all round. Tonight, they might throw croquettes.

Potatoes aside, Anchor Me was a bit of a limp biscuit. While all the signs of pedigree were there - a fine cast of actors and a script from Ashley Pharoah - it just wasn't good enough, ambling along like podgy labrador.

Admittedly, Anchor Me had potential. Thematically, class mobility was always to the fore. The wallpaper borders and own-brand washing-up liquid of working-class Billy and Jackie, a dinner-lady with a nifty wee bob, were set against the white walls and Range Rover lifestyle of Nathan and his wife Sarah, a tously-haired osteopath, who buy organic and don't think about the price. The suffocation of living in a small town was eloquently articulated, as was the miscommunication that passes for normal human behaviour, especially within families. To be fair, some of Anchor Me was achingly true.

There were also a couple of standout performances, from Andrew Lee Potts and Laura Sadler. As the third generation of Carters, doe-eyed Michael and his cousin, feisty Cassie, they were like Bambi and Thumper. A truly charming combination dealing with their own teen traumas as well as those inherited from their forebears.

But a lot of Anchor Me was flabby and rambling. From the outset, there simply wasn't enough oomph or complexity. Twenty minutes in and many of the characters still weren't engaging, with the men espe cially coming over as pathetic and, worse, uninteresting. With little investment in the characters, the flashbacks building up to the death of the youngest Carter brother were redundant: telling us nothing the storyline in the present didn't.

In the end, these characters simply weren't likeable or intriguing enough, whatever their dilemmas. Billed as dark and daring, Anchor Me was ashen and adrift.

There was plenty of oomph, not mention pep, vim and verve in Last of The Blonde Bombshells (BBC1, Sun). With a cast of Judi Dench, Ian Holm, Joan Sims, June Whitfield, Billie Whitelaw, Olympia Dukakis, Leslie Caron and Cleo Laine, to some, it may have been sentimental and obvious with a overly starry cast. To others (including me), it was wonderfully acted, superbly written and great fun.

Like Anchor Me, it was concerned with "the good old days" and the empty new ones, but Last of the Blonde Bombshells was awash with colour and packed with vibrant characters while still thoughtful, retrospective and optimistic. Thus Dench and Holm's attempts to reunite the nearly all-girl swing band made for a deceptively gentle look at history, regret, loss and friendship, full of clever details, smart one-liners and some lovely scenery.

It also counselled that, regardless of much we deny it, eventually all our dance halls are turned into discount carpet warehouses, and it earnestly challenged the way youth-centric culture sees older people. "Old people are just young people who've been round a lot longer," Dench's Elizabeth noted and, however unlikely, it was oddly satisfying that in Last of the Blonde Bombshells, children and grandmas knew what mattered while everyone in between was just a bit too self-obsessed and uptight.

And here, flashback provided exactly the right counterpoint to the present action. While not as "darkly" dramatic as the analepsis in Anchor Me, it complemented the current story perfectly.

And not a spud in sight.

webTitle: Crime boast may haunt Democrats later

fields.headline: Crime boast may haunt Democrats later
fields.standfirst:
Gore on law and order

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Crime has been falling across the US for the past eight years, which dovetails conveniently with Al Gore's term as vice-president.
fields.body:
Crime has been falling across the US for the past eight years, which dovetails conveniently with Al Gore's term as vice-president.

Many reasons for this are advanced - some of them overlapping: a virile economy, better police methods, an ageing population and the end of the crack cocaine epidemic are among them.

But the US has deferred yesterday's problems until tomorrow: tougher sentencing means the nation's prisons contain a sizeable proportion of a generation that must be released at some point.

The number of people in jail went above 2m last year, despite the slowest growth rate in crime in 20 years. The prison population has increased by 600,000 since 1990, fuelled by stricter sentencing policies, particularly against drug offenders.

The rate of incarceration in the US is five times that of any country in Europe.

In particular, while Mr Gore relies on the black vote to help him win the White House, the system is considered to discriminate against the African-American community, which account for 6% of the US population but 50 % of those behind bars and 42% of those on death row. One black American man in every 11 in their late 20s is serving a sentence of a year or more.

Rev Jesse Jackson, the civil rights leader, said: "We have 2m people in prison. That is an international scandal."

Mr Gore at least pays lip service to the death penalty, in keeping with those Democrats who started to realise 20 years ago that opposition to executions was making them look weak on law and order. Support for the measure has fallen but still stands at 66%.

The vice-president supports more stringent checks to keep guns away from criminals and 18 months ago he used his casting vote in the Senate to keep alive a bill aimed at doing just that.

He said in his speech accepting the Democratic nomination that he would propose a victims' rights amendment to the constitution, granting victims of crime a guarantee that they can testify in trials and be notified when a criminal is being released from prison.

Other initiatives promised by Mr Gore include 50,000 more community police officers and tougher penalties against those who misuse the internet to target children and compromise privacy.

A prison state

webTitle: Gore: His vision for America

fields.headline: Gore: His vision for America
fields.standfirst:
Today is Labour Day, the traditional opening of the US presidential election campaign. Some depict Al Gore and George W Bush as similar candidates, others point to big differences in their agendas. Either way, the fight between Bill Clinton's chosen heir and his predecessor's son will shape the next decade, not only in America but around the world. Guardian correspondents examine the records and the promises.

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore has never uttered a more important sentence than the one which came just minutes into his presidential nomination acceptance speech at the Democratic convention in Los Angeles last month.
fields.body:
Al Gore has never uttered a more important sentence than the one which came just minutes into his presidential nomination acceptance speech at the Democratic convention in Los Angeles last month.

"I stand here tonight as my own man," Mr Gore told the delegates, "and I want you to know me for who I truly am."

After two terms as Bill Clinton's vice-president, the 52-year-old Al Gore is now two months away from becoming only the third man in American history to win the presidency at the end of an eight-year apprenticeship in the deputy's job.

If he is to emulate Martin Van Buren and George Bush Sr, Mr Gore faces three tasks. He must define himself as his own man. He must tell America - and the world - what a Gore presidency would be like. And he must win an election which, until recently, he seemed likely to lose.

Mr Gore seemed to stumble so often in the early months of the 2000 campaign because he was failing in the first two tasks. He has seemed anonymous - an occupational hazard for any vice-president - and too calculating. His political positions have seemed to owe more to fear and focus groups than to his principles.

His lowest point came in early summer, when George W Bush seemed to be running away with the election. Afraid of losing Florida on November 7, Gore dithered on the Elian Gonzalez question, losing more support than he won in Florida and across the US.

A month later, fearing that a run of high-profile executions in Bush's Texas might make capital punishment, which both candidates support, into an issue, Gore froze when an interviewer asked him if he would ever authorise the execution of a pregnant woman. That week, the Green nominee Ralph Nader reached the highest position he has yet achieved in the polls.

Since then, Gore has fought to define himself - one of his catch phrases is that he is a "principled fighter".

Nothing has helped him more than selecting Joe Lieberman of Connecticut as his running mate. From the moment the Democrats' fiercest critic of Bill Clinton's affair with Monica Lewinsky joined the ticket, Mr Gore recovered steadily in the opinion polls.

Like Mr Lieberman and Mr Clinton, Mr Gore has a long record of centrist politics. All three men are on the right of the Democratic party, though all would insist that they are modernisers rather than conservatives. Mr Gore's record shows he is the most traditional Democrat of the three.

As a congressman for eight years from 1976, and as a Tennessee senator between 1984 and 1992 - positions which his father held before him - Mr Gore was a classic "cold war liberal". He was pro-labour on government programmes at home, tough on foreign policy abroad, and in the middle on social issues like abortion. Mr Gore's speech to the convention this year was consistent with these positions.

As with any US politician's legislative record, there are defining moments. In 1984, Mr Gore voted for a ban on federal education funds for school districts which discriminated against school prayer groups - a mark of the Baptist faith which repeatedly surfaces in Mr Gore's self-presentation.

That was also the year that Mr Gore broke with many Democrats by voting to keep the MX missile programme, although he later voted for a nuclear freeze resolution. In 1990, Mr Gore was again in the minority of his party in voting to keep the B2 stealth bomber programme alive.

Probably the most significant single vote Mr Gore ever cast came in 1991, when he voted in favour of the Gulf war in the senate, joining a mainly Republican majority to support action against Iraq. Even then, Gore went into the Senate with a gap in his speech where his decision - still unmade - would come.

During his years on Capitol Hill, he laid out some of the stances most characteristic of his agenda. He may not have invented the internet, as he once appeared to claim, but he was unquestionably the most scientifically-minded senator of his era. No one on Capitol Hill has a better perception of the potentialities and problems of innovations such as biotechnology and superconductors - and none campaigned more intensively on threats to the environment.

Perhaps the most significant shift in his thinking over the past decade has been from universalism to targeting in benefits policies. In 1988, when he first ran for the presidency, Mr Gore was a big government man, defending the traditional rationale for non-means-tested benefits. This year, in contrast to Mr Bush, targeting and incrementalism are the central themes of his tax and benefit proposals.

On the broad canvas, a Gore presidency would represent continuity with the Clinton years, but his tone and instincts are more populist and class-conscious than Mr Clinton's. His appeal to "working families" may be focus group-tested, but it corresponds to a strong theme in Mr Gore's background, and could herald a retreat from some of the more overt "third way" approaches of the man he hopes to succeed.

webTitle: Work experience

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: The stars before they were famous
fields.body:
Molly Ringwald in Spacehunter: Adventures In The Forbidden Zone (Lamont Johnson, 1983)

Who? The star of definitive 80s teen flicks The Breakfast Club (1985) and Pretty In Pink (1986). California girl Ringwald made her acting debut in a production of Annie. Sixteen Candles (1984) and The Breakfast Club really boosted her 80s iconhood, and she even made the cover of Time magazine. Sadly for Ringwald, her career took a turn for the worse with Fresh Horses (1988), where she played a 16-year-old in a sexually obsessive relationship, and teen pregnancy drama For Keeps (1988). So Ringwald wisely took time off, went to live in Paris, got married and returned with arthouse project Office Killer (1997). Dawson's Creek creator Kevin Williamson gave her a role in his directorial debut Teaching Mrs Tingle (1999). She'll next be seen in the Australian horror Cut (2000) alongside Kylie Minogue.

The role: Niki The Twister, a teenage girl who's the only survivor of a medical expedition on an alien planet. She links up with an intergalactic warrior to fight an evil dictator. This Boy's Own yarn in space regularly appears on lists of very, very bad movies. Deservedly.

Best line: When asked who she is. Niki replies in an incredibly high-pitched squeal, "What do you think I am you scrawny earthbag? I'm a woman. You'd better not skizz my home or I'll get my father to split your face, and all your brothers' too!"

Cringe factor: Middling. The outfit of black rags isn't too chic. But she's definitely good for a few (intentional) laughs.

Other wannabes: Ernie Hudson, who stars as Sector Chief Washington, went on to play the fourth Ghostbuster.

Critical judgement: Leonard Maltin dismisses it as "Boring and obnoxious, even in 3D."

Also not starring in: The Facts Of Life, the long-running American TV show.

 Spacehunter: Adventures In The Forbidden Zone, Sci-Fi, Saturday September 9, 8pm.

You'd better not skizz my home or I'll get my father to split your face, and all your brothers' too!" Cringe factor: Middling. The outfit of black rags isn't too chic. But she's definitely good for a few (intentional) laughs. Other wannabes: Ernie Hudson, who stars as Sector Chief Washington, went on to play the fourth Ghostbuster. Critical judgement: Leonard Maltin dismisses it as "Boring and obnoxious, even in 3D." Also not starring in: The Facts Of Life, the long-running American TV show.  Spacehunter: Adventures In The Forbidden Zone, Sci-Fi, Saturday September 9, 8pm.

webTitle: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Hidden History: Mary Seacole | Cloak and Dagger | The Fisher King | A Fistful Of Dollars
fields.body:
Hidden History Mary Seacole

9pm, BBC Knowledge

Florence Nightingale's reputation as a hero of the Crimean war is assured, but this lively polemic refocuses attention on another life-saving nurse: Mary Seacole. When the Crimean war broke out in 1853, Seacole paid her own passage out and set up a medical centre at the battle front. News of Seacole's work reached the British public in reports for The Times, making her every bit as celebrated as Nightingale, yet one woman has been forgotten, while the other represents the pinnacle of nursing achievements

Camilla Redmond

Cloak and Dagger

(Fritz Lang, 1946)
3pm, Carlton Cinema

A minor Lang, with Gary Cooper as an American professor on a secret mission to free an atomic scientist held by the Nazis. In Italy he finds romance with Gina (Lilli Palmer) and a deal of intrigue and murder. There are snatches of the real, grim Lang, but the studio disliked his gloomy ending and cut out the film's dark substance.

The Fisher King

(Terry Gilliam, 1991)

10pm, Sky Cinema

Two burnt-out cases - Jeff Bridges' crumpled ex-DJ; Robin Williams's mad ex-professor - cross paths in New York and find salvation in the latter's quest for the Holy Grail. (He is barking.) While it looks great - the city is dark and deeply gothic - you can work too hard at being whimsical, and Williams's twinkling life-affirmations are, well, depressing.

A Fistful Of Dollars

(Sergio Leone, 1964)

12.55am, FilmFour

The spaghetti western that breathed new life into a fading genre. The plot is freely borrowed from Kurosawa's Yojimbo, with Clint's laconic, gunman playing off two warring factions against each other in a dusty Tex/Mex border town. Gian Maria Volonté, another Leone favourite, is the villain who always aims for the heart, and Ennio Morricone's score perfectly complements the simple, heavily stylised drama of the lone horseman in a hostile landscape, the lone gunman stalking the street.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Waking The Dead

fields.headline: On the case
fields.trailText: Mark Lawson on Waking The Dead
fields.body:
Although crime fiction is an exceptionally flexible genre - probably the most influential literary form of the 20th century - the detective story is limited by two conventions. The first is that the crime must be solved. In order to ensure a satisfying final page, fictional detectives have a 100 per cent clean-up rate, although in some recent cases readers or viewers may be given the hint that they have got the wrong man.

The second - related - restriction is that the culprit must be found quickly. Most literary murders are solved within days or weeks; the form of the novel demands that major scenes are relevant to the outcome. If there are seven suspects, they will all have either motive or opportunity. Detective fiction finds it almost impossible to depict the tedium and repetition which mark real-life detection: the case that takes years to solve, the weeks or months spent following false leads.

Television's latest police procedural series Waking The Dead (tonight, 9.30pm, BBC1) tries to stretch these conventions by dealing only with unsolved crimes. Trevor Eve plays DCI Peter Boyd, head of a team bringing new forensic methods to casebooks still open. The first story calls him back to the murder of a teenage girl five years earlier.

But, because we're meeting the character for the first time, there's still no sense of the frustration and ageing of those thwarted years. Eve is like any other copper on the first day of the case. And - because the producers clearly feared that the pursuit of cold clues was undramatic - the uncaught killer conveniently chooses to abduct a second victim on the opening day of the reinvestigation.

A cold investigation - the intriguing aspect of police work which the series promised to portray - therefore becomes suddenly a hot one of the kind neatly solved most weeks on TV. Despite its attempt to capture the tedious reality of detection, Waking The Dead is doomed to be, in the literal sense, conventional.

webTitle: Connery 'wooed' behind Dewar's back

fields.headline: Connery 'wooed' behind Dewar's back
fields.standfirst:
Special report: devolution in Britain
Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: The Scottish National party leader, Alex Salmond, yesterday claimed Peter Mandelson clandestinely recruited Sean Connery into the 1997 devolution campaign behind the backs of senior Scottish MPs.
fields.body:
The Scottish National party leader, Alex Salmond, yesterday claimed Peter Mandelson clandestinely recruited Sean Connery into the 1997 devolution campaign behind the backs of senior Scottish MPs.

Mr Salmond said the Northern Ireland secretary - who was then minister without portfolio - set out to woo the famous Scottish actor after Labour in London became concerned that the "yes-yes" campaign (yes to a Scottish parliament, yes to tax raising powers) was losing impetus.

According to Mr Salmond, there was such concern in Downing Street that Labour's showcase devolution policy was floundering that Mr Mandelson made a personal request to Connery to intervene.

The initial approach to the film star is said to have been made without the knowledge of the Scottish first minister, Donald Dewar. The disclosure will open the Scottish Labour party up to fresh nationalist taunts that it is controlled from London.

Labour and the SNP called an uneasy truce during the devolution campaign, which eventually delivered the Scottish parliament. Political differences were put to one side as Mr Salmond and Mr Dewar shared a platform in support of the parliament.

The departing SNP leader made his revelations in a valedictory series on his 10-year leadership of the party in Scotland on Sunday newspaper. The comments are the first time light has been shed on the inner workings of 1997's unhappy, albeit temporary, marriage of convenience.

Mr Salmond concedes that Connery's intervention cannot solely account for the comfortable margin in favour of the "yes-yes" vote, but he says it was important in achieving such a resounding victory.

webTitle: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Composer Of The Week | The Celluloid Psychiatrists
fields.body:
Kurt Weill is Composer Of The Week (9.0am, Radio 3), marking the centenary of his birth and the 50th anniversary of his death. He had already become fairly well-known in Berlin by the time he was 25. But his career rocketed once he began collaborating with the playwright Berthold Brecht, most notably in their stunningly successful Threepenny Opera. It was staged in more than 100 German theatres within months of its 1928 premiere. Donald Macleod starts with examples of Weill's earliest work.

I have always thought journalists got the rawest deal from Hollywood but I now learn that the real victims have been The Celluloid Psychiatrists (3.45pm, Radio 4). Throughout the week, Mark Thomas offers examples of how film scripts have repeatedly rapped shrinks. Where they are not shown seducing their patients they are, like Hannibal Lector, portrayed having them for lunch. Thomas argues that such exaggerated depictions can seriously affect the public's view of the profession.

webTitle: Tv and Radio: The Secret Life of Richard Nixon

fields.headline: Tricky business
fields.standfirst: A new two-part documentary portrays Richard Nixon as damaged, paranoid and a possible wife-beater. And, says  Mark Lawson  , it also proves TV biographies can reach the parts the written word cannot
fields.trailText: A new two-part documentary portrays Richard Nixon as damaged, paranoid and a possible wife-beater. And, says Mark Lawson , it also proves TV biographies can reach the parts the written word cannot
fields.body:
For all the commonly accepted signs of ageing - policemen looking young, more frequent urination, finding pop music incomprehensible - one of the most poignant is the moment when television history documentaries start featuring scenes you saw at the time they occurred.

Reputations - The Secret Life Of Richard Nixon deals with a figure of recent enough vintage to have had a funeral address from President Clinton. And watching this two-part profile - based on a provocative new biography of Nixon by Anthony Summers, featured in this paper last Saturday - it strikes you that one of the consolations of old age will be the Reputations special on Clinton.

These graceful compilations of archive and arthritic reminiscence are among television's most seductive forms. Although written history digs deeper psychologically than the television biography, there is one effect - that cut from the young ambitious faces on newsreel to the drained and wattled features of the elderly negotiating their place in history - for which the page has no equivalent. Shut your eyes and you can imagine the bald Lord Blair of Sedgfield remembering his times with Bill at Camp David.

Dealing in the Year 2000 with Nixon - Clinton's only rival among modern American figures as a dramatic character and psychological case study - producer William Cran and director Guy Evans face the problem that his story has been told so often. There was a five-part TV documentary on Watergate alone; Oliver Stone made a three-hour movie. Nixon's life is at least a ten-parter. Here they have to do him in two.

Accordingly, what results is not a primer on Nixon but a provocative epilogue to other biographies, centred on two startling claims about the President's private and public conduct respectively.

The first contention is that the politician whose campaigns presented him as a safe pair of hands in fact possessed shaky and sweaty fingers. Where Clinton and Reagan were natural politicians - refreshed by pressure and publicity - Nixon had the terrible dichotomy of being a shy and private man who wished to run the world. An aide recalls that, even as President, he would blush when meeting strangers.

And so, say these films, he sought various masks. There is first-hand evidence that he was a patient of a New York psychiatrist and regular taker of sedating medication. Hearsay allegations further suggest that he was an ugly drunk and wife-beater.

In a book, you make your judgement from the authority of the writing. In a visual biography, such claims instantly sharpen your eyes. To me, Nixon does look drunk or drugged during some key TV appearances but Pat Nixon shows no obvious sign in their joint appearances of being wary of her husband. I realise that this doesn't disprove the claims but my point is that the documentary doesn't prove them. The first part having presented Nixon as an unstable paranoiac, next Monday's second attempts to show the historical consequences of his condition. Nixon's obsessive belief that Kennedy stole the 1960 election from him through electoral fraud is shown as motivating his decision to steal the 1968 rematch from Hubert Humphrey.

Declassified documents and testimony from an Asian go-between Anna Chennault suggest that Nixon prolonged the Vietnam War to the gain of his own campaign by secretly persuading the South Vietnamese to boycott Johnson's Paris peace talks.

But - in a fashion befitting classic tragedy - the means by which Nixon secured power are seen to have prompted his loss of it. The greatest mystery of the Watergate burglary was always why a President certain to be re-elected was so interested in files kept by his Democrat rivals.

Why steal the secrets of a doomed Democrat campaign?

In these films (as in his book), Anthony Summers plausibly suggests that Nixon was obsessed by an intimation from the outgoing President Lyndon Johnson that the Democrats had evidence of his thwarting of the peace talks. Summers surmises that the President believed that there might also be incriminating papers kept at the Democratic National HQ in the Watergate building.

These complicated claims are perhaps more suited to a book. But televisual material frequently brings unique pleasures. It's startling that Nixon now seems so obviously false - the mirthless mid-sentence smile. And there is the genetic spookiness of the President's brother Ed Nixon wearing an innocent version of that much-photographed face and Henry Kissinger whose delivery, always metallic, now resembles an electric shaver. "Al had brok lude", he recalls of a time when all hell broke loose.

"You won't have Nixon to kick around anymore", the press were told in 1962 by a failed gubernatorial candidate supposedly retiring from politics. But, six years after his death, we still have Nixon's reputation to kick around. And these documentaries are, in two senses, a good kicking.

I hope that this series' Clinton will be a hit in the 2025 schedules.

 The Secret Life of Richard Nixon, tonight, 9pm, BBC2

webTitle: Arts: Soviet design

fields.headline: Before the fall
fields.standfirst: A summer of disasters can't erase Russia's revolutionary past, when it's architects were among the most daring and influential in the woerld. By Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: A summer of disasters can't erase Russia's revolutionary past, when it's architects were among the most daring and influential in the woerld. By Jonathan Glancey
fields.body:
The Soviets were the first to put a satellite into orbit and the first to send a man into space. The first to launch a dog into space, too, but that's another tale. The Soviet Union that died nearly a decade ago was riddled with faults, yet this extraordinary state was responsible for some of the most radical and fascinating design of the 20th century. Think, comrades, of Vostok rockets, Mig Foxbat fighters and the P36 4-8-4 locomotives that hauled the Trans-Siberian express into the late 1970s. Or, if not of these, then the fashion, graphics and, above all, architecture of the period between the October Revolution of 1917 and Stalin's crack down on Modern buildings in the early 1930s.

The ultra-capitalist Russia of today appears to have neither the money nor the will to maintain a public infrastructure that was once among the world's most impressive. Planes fall from the sky, a nuclear submarine gives up the ghost, a sky-piercing television mast, three times as high as London's British Telecom Tower, bursts into flames, while all around Moscow, meretricious postmodern architecture is thrown up to satisfy the swinish luxury of New Russians. This is tragedy and farce.

Even so, it would be unwise to demean the Soviet achievement. Soviet architecture continues to inform the designs of some of the world's most intelligent and adventurous architects. Look at Daniel Libeskind's iconoclastic design for the Spiral wing of the Victoria & Albert Museum, or Zaha Hadid's up-and-coming Museum of Comtemporary Art in Rome. Look back half a century, and you'll find that the design of London's Royal Festival Hall is based in part on a Moscow concert hall of the early 1930s.

The list of Soviet-inspired buildings in decidedly non-revolutionary Britain is as long as the Ostankino Tower was tall. Modern Movement architecture, as it arrived in Britain on the boat from continental Europe, was a fusion of ideas that had criss-crossed somewhere on the way from Moscow through Berlin and Paris. Some of the architects themselves came here, too. The most celebrated practitioner was Berthold Lubetkin (1901-90), a Georgian educated in Moscow, who brought with him an elegance of style, a sharp intellect and the labyrinthine emotional depths of the land of Dostoevsky. He designed the Penguin Pool (1934) at London Zoo - a modest proposition, yet in Lubetkin's hands one of the iconic international designs of the 1930s. Its swirling helical ramps and graphic impact call to mind the spirit that electrified such pacemaking Bolshevik designs as the vertiginous steel spiral Monument to the Third Communist International (1919) by the artist Vladimir Tatlin (1885-1953).

Not far from London Zoo are the Isokon flats in Hampstead (1934), an experiment in collective housing designed for left-wing intellectuals by the journalist-turned-architect Wells Coates. Complete with a club room designed by the Bauhaus emigre Marcel Breuer, the Isokon building was modelled on the Moscow housing block built for employees of the Finance Commisariat designed by Moisei Ginzburg (1892-1946). This ocean-liner housing was to inspire Le Corbusier, whose ideas on urban mass housing and, later, his Unite d'Habitation in Marseilles (1946-52), were to have a profound influence on social housing around the world.

Le Corbusier, like many progressive architects of the 1920s and 30s, visited Soviet Russia; he designed the Tsentrosoyuz office building (1928-36) in Moscow, and was one of the many international architects who entered the competition for Stalin's new Palace of the Soviets held between 1931 and 1933. The palace was never built - which was just as well, since the winning design was for an abomination of a building, capped with a 300ft statue of Lenin.

The sheer inventiveness of the architects of the early "heroic" Soviet era, between the end of the first world war and 1932, remains both remarkable and a visual treat. It was a brief flowering, yet it sowed its seeds internationally. How did such an extraordinary architecture emerge? After the fall of the Romanovs in 1917 and the German surrender a year later, there was an outburst of can-do passion and energy and much the same sort of feeling that must have been experienced in Paris in 1789: with the old order turned upside down, anything could happen.

The work of Soviet Modernists was characterised by a love of breaking the grid of conventional buildings, by the intrusion of sudden diagonal or spiralling elements, by a daring use of giant, sloganeering graphics, by dramatic intersections and even collisions of the various parts of wilfully abstract buildings. This was architecture as Soviet propaganda for liberation from bourgeois norms, a way of building as shocking at the time as the new wave of Soviet cinema and graphic design.

The first physical expression most foreigners saw of this new spirit was the Soviet pavilion at the 1925 Art Deco exhibition held in Paris. Designed by Konstantin Melnikov (1890-1974), this was a cleverly deconstructed red, black and grey timber box shot through with an inside-outside diagonal stair. The entrance was topped with a hammer-and-sickle motif. Melnikov went on to build the only private house allowed in Moscow at the time. This was his own home and studio (1927-9), a curious circular concrete tower pierced with elongated honeycomb pattern windows. It survives; the architect's son lives there today.

More importantly, Melnikov was responsible for the development of a series of distinctive workers' clubs for political education and training in Moscow. His aggressive Rusakov Club (1927-9) for employees of the Moscow City Soviet, and the brilliant geometric play that is the Zuev Club (1927-9) for Moscow's tram workers, designed by Ilia Golosov (1883-1945), set a new standard for public buildings. Which city now would commission such radical and intelligent architecture for workers? Certainly not today's dizzy, disco- and dollar-crazy Moscow.

Radical designs just made it into the 1930s before Stalin squeezed the country in his lethal bear hug. He imposed his school of Socialist Realism in architecture - as in music, art and literature - by decree in 1932; individual architectural practices were abolished and all work was to be organised through the Union of Soviet Architects. The revolutionary dream was officially over.

Of course, many exuberant, if bombastic, buildings were constructed between 1932 and Stalin's death 21 years later: the Moscow Metro, richer than any babushka's plum cake; the seven wedding-cake towers encircling Moscow's city centre; the grand apartment blocks of Moscow, Leningrad and Stalingrad (the last obliterated during the Great Patriotic War of 1941-5). The breathtaking Lomonosov State University complex of the early 1950s was designed by a team led by Lev Rudnev (1885-1956); previously he had also designed the daunting Frunze Military Academy (1937), Moscow, to symbolise the might, real or not at the time, of the Red Army.

Almost all of these buildings, Constructivist or Classical, Suprematist or Stalinist, are still standing. They should remind us not just that the former Soviet Union is not as crumbly as so many like to believe this disastrous summer, but that it once challenged the world with its revolutionary architecture.
