webTitle: Stepanovs, Stepping up, Stepping down

fields.headline: Stepanovs, Stepping up, Stepping down
fields.trailText: BODY BEAUTIFUL
fields.body:
BODY BEAUTIFUL

Imagine, Arsenal fans, that you were Dr Frankenstein. Imagine you had enough demonic power - and, of course, electricity - to create your perfect central defender. Obviously he would be big, strong and able to shoot his hand up for offside even in his sleep. That much goes without saying. And a penchant for near-post flick-ons and the West End play 'Art' would be nice too. Hang on a minute though, that's a perfect synthesis of Tony Adams and Steve Bould - and surely that's impossible!

Well think again, because that defender already exists. His name is Igors Stepanovs, he's a Latvian international and - control yourself you Gooners - he's signed for Arsenal. "Igors can definitely do a job in the Premiership. He is in the same mould as Tony Adams, which is why he will fit in so well at the Arsenal," said Graham Johnson, Latvia's English coach (who, in case you're wondering, used to manage Cambridge). "The lad was magnificent against Scotland [at the weekend]," Johnson went on. "Steve Rowley [the Arsenal scout] was full of praise for the lad and thought there was a bit of Steve Bould in his game as well."

That's some billing, and the 6ft 3ins centre-back could prove his worth as soon as this Wednesday. Because with Tony Adams out - reportedly for a month - and with a fresh-smelling work permit arriving at Highbury this very morning, Stepanovs looks likely to be hurled into the lions' den (well, Stamford Bridge). Not that Johnson, Stepanov's one-man fan club, is worried. "I have told him if he plays like he did against Scotland in the Premiership he will soon be a millionaire in England," he twittered. But what will Stepanovs do with the money? Buy Lee Dixon's thigh muscles, we would wager.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NOT-SO CLEVER TREVOR

The Fiver loves the Sunday papers. They're as important a part of the weekend as the Saturday fry-up and the Friday night vomit. The Sunday papers are what make this country great. After all, where else could you read about the latest in light fittings, catch up with the movements of your local paedophile, get the recipe for a meal comprised entirely of artichokes, or read Birmingham City chairman David Sullivan having a pop at his manager, Trevor Francis, over two pages?

Sky pundit Francis declared over the weekend that there is a conspiracy aimed at forcing him out of St Andrews. Sullivan told the Birmingham Sunday Mercury that Francis should stop talking like that, if he doesn't want to be forced out of the club. "I would describe Trevor's reaction as paranoia," Sullivan said. "His nature is one of pessimism. He paints a gloomy picture and has a policy of talking the team down. That way if we do badly he can say 'I told you so'. But if we do well he can tell us all what a wonderful manager he is."

Francis, when not making Richard Keys look like an erudite afficionado of the game, has over the course of the past four seasons used porn magnate Sullivan's millions to steer the Blues away from promotion and acquire a complete collection of Mediocre Players . Not that Sullivan believes Francis would cut it even if he did make it to the Premiership. "The task of staying there would be phenomenal and he might say 'I don't need this in my life'," Sullivan said. So, all in all, a ringing endorsement. That Trev should just chill out - he'll do himself a misfortune.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"It's a lie. I am not a crook, I do not have to hide in my house. These accusations make me upset and I cannot allow them."

Brazil manager Wanderley Luxemburgo responds to allegations that he accepted bribes and forged documents about his age. He certainly sounds innocent to us.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NWANK-WOE

Arsenal's Nwankwo Kanu has written to the Nigerian FA asking to be left out of their squad for the Olympic games. The Nigerian FA were not best pleased by the request. A spokesman said: "We are very unhappy about this development - more so when the player had given us his word that he would play in Sydney. Kanu should not work against his country." It is now expected that Kanu will not travel to Sydney. In a (parallel) world exclusive The Fiver reprints the letter in full below.

Dear Mr Nigerian FA

Hallo, my name is Nwankwo. I have been picked in your 22 man squad to play in the Olympics in Sydney. I have always liked Australia. It looks pretty in Neighbours, the television programme that I watch by myself after training. I am so lonely.

Anyway, Mr Nigerian FA, I am writing to say that I will not be coming to Sydney because Mr Wenger doesn't want me to. Oh, what have I said? I mean to say that I will not be coming to Sydney because my dog ate it. Oh, how silly! Of course I meant that I will not be coming to Sydney because of pressing concerns at home (it is very big, I have no cleaner, the smaller dining room is getting dusty etc).

I wish you all the best in your Olympic endeavours.

Yours truly,

Nwankwo Kanu

PS If you are ever in London, please do not hesitate to contact me. I am free every afternoon. And evening. And most mornings too. Don't be a stranger! * * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Shay Given has expressed an interest in re-joining Celtic. "I've been in negotiations with Newcastle about a new contract but nothing has been sorted out," he told the Daily Record. "If Celtic came in for me I would definitely consider moving back."

Southampton have denied they will sell Marian Pahars, despite rumoured interest from Celtic.

Dutch side Roda are lining up a bid for Sheffield Wednesday striker Gerald Sibon, after missing out on Erik Meijer.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Jesper Blomqvist faces another lengthy spell on the sidelines after suffering another knee injury. The Swedish international will have an exploratory operation on his other knee and will be out for at least a month.

Huddersfield striker Clyde Wijnhard has undergone an operation to pin a compound fracture of his arm after he was involved in a serious car accident. The 26-year-old was involved in the accident when his Mercedes jeep left the road on the A1 in the early hours of yesterday.

Uefa have fined Aston Villa £5,200 for "the improper conduct of the team" during the two legs of their Intertoto Cup match with Celta Vigo. Meanwhile Aberdeen have been fined £4,000 for the same offence after their second leg against Bohemians.

Moldovan side Constructorul-93 Chisinau have been banned from European club competitions for a year after a member of the club threatened the assistant referee with a gun, following their tie against CSKA Sofia last month.

Celtic's chief executive Allan MacDonald has announced he will quit the club after only 18 months in the post. An announcement to the Stock Market read: "Mr Allan MacDonald has informed the board of his intention to resign from his position as chief executive of Celtic plc and return to a career outside the football sector."

The draw for the third round of the Bell's Challenge Cup is: Airdrie v Clydebank, East Stirling v Stenhousemuir, Stranraer v Arbroath, Livingston v Brechin.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

fields.bodyText: BODY BEAUTIFUL Imagine, Arsenal fans, that you were Dr Frankenstein. Imagine you had enough demonic power - and, of course, electricity - to create your perfect central defender. Obviously he would be big, strong and able to shoot his hand up for offside even in his sleep. That much goes without saying. And a penchant for near-post flick-ons and the West End play 'Art' would be nice too. Hang on a minute though, that's a perfect synthesis of Tony Adams and Steve Bould - and surely that's impossible! Well think again, because that defender already exists. His name is Igors Stepanovs, he's a Latvian international and - control yourself you Gooners - he's signed for Arsenal. "Igors can definitely do a job in the Premiership. He is in the same mould as Tony Adams, which is why he will fit in so well at the Arsenal," said Graham Johnson, Latvia's English coach (who, in case you're wondering, used to manage Cambridge). "The lad was magnificent against Scotland [at the weekend]," Johnson went on. "Steve Rowley [the Arsenal scout] was full of praise for the lad and thought there was a bit of Steve Bould in his game as well." That's some billing, and the 6ft 3ins centre-back could prove his worth as soon as this Wednesday. Because with Tony Adams out - reportedly for a month - and with a fresh-smelling work permit arriving at Highbury this very morning, Stepanovs looks likely to be hurled into the lions' den (well, Stamford Bridge). Not that Johnson, Stepanov's one-man fan club, is worried. "I have told him if he plays like he did against Scotland in the Premiership he will soon be a millionaire in England," he twittered. But what will Stepanovs do with the money? Buy Lee Dixon's thigh muscles, we would wager. * * * * * * * * * * * * * NOT-SO CLEVER TREVOR The Fiver loves the Sunday papers. They're as important a part of the weekend as the Saturday fry-up and the Friday night vomit. The Sunday papers are what make this country great. After all, where else could you read about the latest in light fittings, catch up with the movements of your local paedophile, get the recipe for a meal comprised entirely of artichokes, or read Birmingham City chairman David Sullivan having a pop at his manager, Trevor Francis, over two pages? Sky pundit Francis declared over the weekend that there is a conspiracy aimed at forcing him out of St Andrews. Sullivan told the Birmingham Sunday Mercury that Francis should stop talking like that, if he doesn't want to be forced out of the club. "I would describe Trevor's reaction as paranoia," Sullivan said. "His nature is one of pessimism. He paints a gloomy picture and has a policy of talking the team down. That way if we do badly he can say 'I told you so'. But if we do well he can tell us all what a wonderful manager he is." Francis, when not making Richard Keys look like an erudite afficionado of the game, has over the course of the past four seasons used porn magnate Sullivan's millions to steer the Blues away from promotion and acquire a complete collection of Mediocre Players . Not that Sullivan believes Francis would cut it even if he did make it to the Premiership. "The task of staying there would be phenomenal and he might say 'I don't need this in my life'," Sullivan said. So, all in all, a ringing endorsement. That Trev should just chill out - he'll do himself a misfortune. * * * * * * * * * * * * * QUOTE OF THE DAY "It's a lie. I am not a crook, I do not have to hide in my house. These accusations make me upset and I cannot allow them." Brazil manager Wanderley Luxemburgo responds to allegations that he accepted bribes and forged documents about his age. He certainly sounds innocent to us. * * * * * * * * * * * * * NWANK-WOE Arsenal's Nwankwo Kanu has written to the Nigerian FA asking to be left out of their squad for the Olympic games. The Nigerian FA were not best pleased by the request. A spokesman said: "We are very unhappy about this development - more so when the player had given us his word that he would play in Sydney. Kanu should not work against his country." It is now expected that Kanu will not travel to Sydney. In a (parallel) world exclusive The Fiver reprints the letter in full below. Dear Mr Nigerian FA Hallo, my name is Nwankwo. I have been picked in your 22 man squad to play in the Olympics in Sydney. I have always liked Australia. It looks pretty in Neighbours, the television programme that I watch by myself after training. I am so lonely. Anyway, Mr Nigerian FA, I am writing to say that I will not be coming to Sydney because Mr Wenger doesn't want me to. Oh, what have I said? I mean to say that I will not be coming to Sydney because my dog ate it. Oh, how silly! Of course I meant that I will not be coming to Sydney because of pressing concerns at home (it is very big, I have no cleaner, the smaller dining room is getting dusty etc). I wish you all the best in your Olympic endeavours. Yours truly, Nwankwo Kanu PS If you are ever in London, please do not hesitate to contact me. I am free every afternoon. And evening. And most mornings too. Don't be a stranger! * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Shay Given has expressed an interest in re-joining Celtic. "I've been in negotiations with Newcastle about a new contract but nothing has been sorted out," he told the Daily Record. "If Celtic came in for me I would definitely consider moving back." Southampton have denied they will sell Marian Pahars, despite rumoured interest from Celtic. Dutch side Roda are lining up a bid for Sheffield Wednesday striker Gerald Sibon, after missing out on Erik Meijer. * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF Jesper Blomqvist faces another lengthy spell on the sidelines after suffering another knee injury. The Swedish international will have an exploratory operation on his other knee and will be out for at least a month. Huddersfield striker Clyde Wijnhard has undergone an operation to pin a compound fracture of his arm after he was involved in a serious car accident. The 26-year-old was involved in the accident when his Mercedes jeep left the road on the A1 in the early hours of yesterday. Celtic's chief executive Allan MacDonald has announced he will quit the club after only 18 months in the post. An announcement to the Stock Market read: "Mr Allan MacDonald has informed the board of his intention to resign from his position as chief executive of Celtic plc and return to a career outside the football sector." webTitle: England reclaim Wisden Trophy

fields.headline: England reclaim Wisden Trophy
fields.standfirst:
England beat West Indies by 158
                                                    runs.
                                                    They win the series 3-1
fields.trailText: England beat West Indies by 158 runs. They win the series 3-1
fields.body:
Thirty-one years of hurt were finally overturned at The Oval today, when England beat West Indies in a Test series for the first time since 1969.

Despite a valliant innings from Brian Lara - and some late-order thrashing from Nixon McLean and Curtly Ambrose - no one could stop England sweeping to victory in the September sunshine. Their 158-run victory was sealed when Dominic Cork trapped Courtney Walsh lbw for 0 in probably his last Test innings.

Today's victory gives them a 3-1 series win, and an England captain, Nasser Hussain, proudly lifted the Wisden Trophy for the first time in a generation. The outfield at The Oval was flooded with cricket fans as the historic moment occurred: they cheered Nasser this year, and also saluted Mike Atherton, who picked up the Man of the Match award for his crucial innings of 108 on Sunday.

England's bowlers took five wickets in the afternoon session to rip through the West Indies batting one last time this series. Caddick (4-50) made the breakthrough with the key wicket of Jimmy Adams (15) in the second over after lunch. He added Ridley Jacobs later on too.

England were on the charge, though for a short while it had looked as though Brian Lara would perform the sort of heroics we saw against Australia at Bridgetown in March 1999, when his unbeaten 153 saw West Indies home by one wicket. He skipped lunch to stay on the outfield practising, and when he pulled Craig White for four with a fierce shot in the first over after the break, the signs were ominous. With 20-year-old Ramnaresh Sarwan, the pair put on an almost run-a-ball 46 - at just the rate needed if West Indies were to reach their unlikely target of 374.

But, after a flurry of runs, Sarwan was run out by Thorpe scampering in from mid-off after Lara sent his partner back. Sarwan injured his left shoulder while making an ultimately futile dive for the crease. But as he lay grounded, England's fielders were grouped together facing the big screen for the TV umpire's verdict. They were delighted when Sarwan's dismissal was confirmed, jumping up and down as they sent back one of West Indies' chief destroyers for 27. They were jumping again in the next over when Caddick forced Ridley Jacobs to edge to Graeme Hick at second slip for 1.

But the real excitement came one over later, in the 55th of the innings, when Gough won an lbw decision against Lara and the man who looked let to have batted all afternoon trooped off. England had what they wanted, and the rest will soon be history.

In the 20 minutes before tea, Nixon McLean and Curtly Ambrose found run-making a simpler pastime, sending some lusty blows all around The Oval. They hit six fours before Ambrose edged Cork to slip and Atherton held the catch. Ambrose was cheered from the field as he walked away from his last Test match innings ended by an edge to slip off Dominic Cork, which Atherton snapped up. The applause, from spectators, officials and players alike, then extended to the incoming Courtney Walsh. The England players formed two sides of a corridor to welcome Walsh.

Alas, his final Test innings was a shorter affair - he Cork thudded one into his pads after just two balls and the series was over.

Cricket fans came in their droves to The Oval to see the denouement of a gripping series; so much so, in fact, that the House Full signs went up at 11.20am. By midday the seats in front of the empty hospitality boxes were being put to good use by those who had paid the flat rate of £10 and under-16s who had got in for free.

These late-comers missed England's nervy start to the day. Darren Gough started with a no-ball and his first over went for nine runs as Sherwin Campbell thick-edged and square-drove for boundaries. It was a small step towards that distant target of 374 for victory, but when the West Indies openers advanced from 33 to 50 in just 12 minutes, England fans could be forgiven for thinking the tourists had picked up the wrong script.

Then Graeme Hick's fumbling drop at second slip reprieved Campbell off Gough and one was left wondering how costly that might prove. The verdict came instantly: next ball, an even bigger swish sent the ball flying towards Hick's face and his hands went up to take a harder catch. The relief as the fielders mobbed him was palpable. 50-1 and Campbell skulking off with 28 to his name. Lara replaced him.

Next over, Caddick found Adrian Griffith's outside edge and Alec Stewart lunged forward to clasp the catch: 50-2. The magic of the first innings had returned and the sunbathing crowd were on their feet.

Left-hander Hinds gained a life when Hick dropped him low to his left, off Gough again, but as before good news followed bad for England and though Hick didn't have another chance to redeem himself, Caddick did, thudding a full ball into Hinds's pads. 52-3, Hinds gone for 7.

Lara gave a demonstration of intent by twice swivelling to whip the ball gloriously through the leg side for four before lunch, when West Indies were 89-3.
